Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aages (Hard): Unbroken, strong.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agallon (Glorifying): Self aggrandizing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalma (Delight): Anything in which a person delights. But they say that also paintings and statues are 'agalmata'. Others (say) simply that any dedication or offering is an 'agalma', even if it should not be an image or some other such thing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adolos (Honestly): This denotes 'simply' and 'truly'. For the truth is something simple and without without cunning (dolos), but falsehood is tangled up and full of cunning.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agein kai pherein (To carry off and bear away): To spoil and plunder. But ‘agein' is also to carry away things/money and, applied to the lifeless, also to recover them, without distinction.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Korchoros (Blue pimpernel): Cheap wild greens; wherefore also the expression "and blue pimpernel in the greens"; and some explain that 'korchoros' is a sort of fish, like the dolphinfish; also as a cheap meat. It is said applying to those who are unworthy and low, but pretend to honor greater than befits them.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: To be hungover differs from being drunk. For it is said applying to the previous day's drunkenness: after the fact that one's head is still quaking. But ‘to be drunk’ [is said] of what is more recent.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Krisamis: A Koan. This man was rich in cattle. They say that an eel snatched the finest of this man's herd and that Krisamis killed it, but that appearing to him in a dream it bid him bury it; and that when he paid no attention he and his entire family perished.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hydor pararrheei (Water flowed by): Applying to those who promise to be eager with all their strength, as if they would not even have shrunk from boarding moving ships.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Abydos: The word is applied to a sycophant, owing to the fact that the Abydenes seem to be sycophants. And 'abydokomai' are those who aspire to be sycophants. The word is also ascribed to someone who is useless, and of no worth at all. Abydenoi are also satirized for their licentiousness.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigyption geras (Egyptian old-age): Sophocles: "First you will see a white budding crop, then a red round mulberry, then you [will] receive Egyptian old-age." It indicates...

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Akolasia (Intemperance): Thucydides said 'akolasia' (intemperance), and Alexis 'akolastia' (intemperance), and Aristophanes 'akolastotaton' (most intemperate), and Nicolaus 'akolastoteran' (more intemperate).

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gegonen en kalo (It was in beauty): It went very well.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Artemisia: There were two, Carian in ethnicity and both queens, of whom the first existed during the Persians wars, and the second, whom Demosthenes mentions in On the Freedom of the Rhodians, was the daughter of Hekatomnos, and also wife and sister of Mausolos.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akolaston kai hybriston pragma (Unbridled and violent deed): This construction is Attic, and there are two ways of looking at it: one, that he used 'hybriston' for 'hybristikon' (violent), being similar in type to superlatives such as 'beltiston' (best), 'kalliston' (most beautiful), 'kratiston' (greatest), and similar; the other, that 'hybriston' has been bound up with 'akolaston'. Plato used the phrase, saying in Peisandros, "For a woman, if you always chastise her, is the greatest of all possessions. But if you leave off doing so, she is a violent and unchaste thing". Pherekrates, who combined 'hybriston' with 'kobalon' (knavish), said, "you performed a violent and knavish work". The combinations belong to prose writings.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Akolouthos (Follower): Demosthenes in Against Conon for 'slave'. Likewise also Xenophon.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Brauronia: At Athens Artemis was called thus, after a place Brauron, in which she was especially honored. And the place was called after a certain hero so called. And there was a sanctuary adjacent to the river Erasinos constructed by Peisistratos.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akyklios (One who has not gone the round): The uneducated person in Plato.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Akolouthounte (Following): For 'akolouthousai' (following) in the dual. So Hermippos. For also they used the masculine participles in place of the feminine often.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aielouros (Cat): Aristophanes and Sophocles, with four syllables.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akylos (holm-acorn): The fruit of the holm-oak is called [this] by the ancients, but that of the 'drys' (oak) [is called] 'balanos' (acorn). "Those going around fetching the holm-acorns ('akylous') and the acorns ('balanous') and the wild pears" [says] Pherekrates in the Agrioi.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gauria (He prances): He struts, he exalts, he boasts.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Alcibiades: The son of Kleinias, but also his great-grandfather. But there is another Alcibiades, whom Antiphon mentions.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Autolekythoi (those who carry their own lekythoi): Demosthenes in Against Conon. Either (that they are) certain men who are well-girt and ready to do and endure anything whatsoever; or it is for 'poor and posessing nothing other than 'lekythoi'.' Or, laborers. Or, for 'those ready for blows and as it were striking and whipping and doing violence'. Or those readily paying money and ready for sexual encounters. For they also used to keep money in their 'lekythoi'. And often, after destroying the 'lekythos' they would use the leather strap for whipping.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gauron (Haughty): Stubborn, great, unmoved, undaunted.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ampreutes (Hauling): The word is useful. Sophocles: "Just like a hauling ass always being whipped".

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geganomenos (Having been polished): Having been brightened.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akymona: Undisturbed, unshaken.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithiopion: It is a place in Euboia.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Grammatokyphon (Porer over records): for 'O humble grammateus'. Since properly the wood is called 'kyphe'(?), through which they draw the neck and hands.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gegethe (He has rejoiced): He is glad.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akymon: She who is not bearing, as she who has conceived is 'egkymon' (pregnant). And a sea that is not disturbed by winds and swollen with waves is called an 'akymon' (waveless) sea.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithon (Fiery): Manly and warlike.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achane (measurement): A Boeotian measure of some great many medimnoi. So Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Endeixis (Indictment): Against those who were disfranchised or did what the laws bar. Of indictments [there were] those that the Eleven would introduce to the lawcourt and those that the Thesmothetai [would]. For example, they would introduce indictments whenever one, despite having incurred a charge, performs a magistracy or participates in the assembly or serves as a juror, and applying to similar cases.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alexandros: Whom Demosthenes mentions in the the sixth of the Philippics, is the so-called Philhellene, son of Amyntas the king and father of Perdikkas. The brother of Philip is another Alexander, whom Demosthenes mentions in On the False Embassy. The Thessalian [Alexander] is another, about whom he [Demosthenes] speaks in Against Aristokrates. The Molossian [Alexander] is another, brother of Olympias the wife of Philip. Demosthenes mentions also this [Alexander] in the seventh of the Philippics, and the speech is genuine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haloa: It is an Attic festival. Philochoros says that it was named after the fact that men spend time around the threshing floors then.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutades: Boutia is a deme of the tribe Oineis, the demesmen from which are Boutadai.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutes: This man held the priesthood and those after him were called 'Boutadai'. But the descendants of Boutes are called Eteoboutadai ('true Boutadai'); for 'eteon' signifies 'true'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Azein (To sigh): Attic [authors] call exhaling through the mouth all at once 'azein' (sighing), imitating the sound of the breath. So Nikochares.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haimorhyngchia (Bloody nose): The word is Doric, except that also the Attic [author] Hermippos used the utterance, saying, "Today, pounding your face, I shall give you a bloody nose". It denotes the nose being bloodied up. Phrynichos however does not admit the utterance.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haimodein (To grind one's teeth): One must apply the mind to this. For the masses say 'haimodian' (to grind one's teeth), just as 'kyloidian' (to have a black eye), though Kratinos in Dionysalexandros inflects from 'haimodo' (I grind my teeth): "For straightaway upon hearing the words you began to grind your front teeth". The Attic [authors say that] to feel pain in the teeth with an irritation is 'haimodein'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akosmein (To be disorderly): To do nothing in good order or arrangement, but to be intemperate. Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gamelia: Registration among and introduction to the phratrymen, which they used to call also Koureotis. But others say that 'gamelia' was a sacrifice, which those being registered among the ephebes by the demesmen used to sacrifice, also when they were about to marry. The sacrifice was to Hera and Aphrodite and the nuptial Graces.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Deilon ho ploutos (Wealth is wretched): Inasmuch as the rich safeguard their houses and raise dogs and provide themselves with many protections.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eis hydor graphein (To write on water): Applying to the useless and those who have no mind.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: A a: Applied to something great. But it is also an exclamation in anger. But when aspirated it denotes laughter, as Diogenianos says.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aadein: To disturb, to be at a loss, to wrong, to go without food.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aalion: Disorderly, powerless.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutrophous (Ox-tenders): A certain class, as they say, of priesthood that tends oxen, so that they may be sacrificed to the gods publicly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ixia: What is by some called 'kirsos' (varicocele). It is ailing blood, named after oaks in which there are masses from which the 'ixos' (oak gum) flows.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ixyn (Waist): Loins.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iodoche: Quiver.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ion (Arrow): Missile.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionion pelagos (Ionian sea): The present Adriatic. Also Ionian Gulf: for so they used to call the Adriatic.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iontes (Going): Proceeding.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionto(?) (They were eager): They were keen, they were choosing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iou: An adverb expressing indignation; for 'oimoi' (Ah me!).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ioulos: A dusting of hair; or, the first growth of beard.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ioulizon (Growing downy): One starting his beard.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iousan: Proceeding.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Lexiarchikon grammateion (Lexiarchic register): Into which those boys who had reached maturity used to be enrolled, for whom it was possible thenceforth to manage their ancestral property, from which also the name comes, owing to the fact that they 'control' (archein) their 'share' (lexeis). Both 'portions' (kleroi) and 'property' (ousiai) are 'shares'. The plaint is a 'lexis' according to which logic we say also that one 'obtains leave to bring' (lachein) suit.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athrein (To observe): To oversee and watch with intensity. The whole [corpus] is full of examples.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphainein (To exchange): To alter. From which also the 'alphoi' (dull white leprosy) on the body. For they change on the skin.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphainei (Fetches): Seeks, yields. Whence she who yields a great price is 'timalphes' (price-fetching.)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphinia: Leprosy.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphesteisin (To enterprising men): To honored men.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphita (Barley groats): Strictly, the broken bits of roasted and ground barley, but incorrectly also those from wheat and beans.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphitamoiboi (Barley meal dealers): Barley meal sellers, not for money but exchanging barley for barley meal.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ioulos: Grub in the vines. A certain many-footed creature. Also the bloom on the chin. Also the blossom on nut-trees. Also a 'ioulos' is a certain type of song, for example an 'oupingos' which is dear to Artemis. But some also call the many-footed and tangled thing that appears on water jars a 'ioulos'.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antia (Set against): Difficult, adverse.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antlos: The hold of a ship/bilge-water.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antlion: A cask.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antlia (hold of a ship): wherever they drain the water that has come into the ship out into the sea. Now also called 'kadiskos' (little urn).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antistrophous (corresponding): for 'isostrophous' (even).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antissa: A city among those on Lesbos.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Anytein (Accomplish): the Attic [authors], just as we [do, say] 'anyein' (accomplish). But a rough first syllable [makes] 'hanyein', to be eager. Homer, as we [do, says] 'anyein' (accomplish): "I accomplish nothing by grudging."

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Anymenaioun (To celebrate with nuptial odes): Sophocles in Phrygians "Will you not stop, not cease celebrating these weddings?!"

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Archethen (then): This is not among the Attic (authors), except in Aeschylus. But it is in Herodotus and the Ionian (authors).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Boleones (Dunghills): So the places that receive excrement are called. So Deinarchus and Philemon and others.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aaptous: Those who give rough breathing to the second alpha understand 'unapproachable', 'that which one could not lay ahold of', but those who give smooth breathing [understand] 'unsuccessful/unmanageable'(?). But others [understand] 'inescapable' and 'difficult'. But Apion gives rough breathing, for he wishes to interpret, 'that which one could not lay ahold of' or 'those that approach many'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasai: Signifies four things: to satiate, to fall asleep, to damage, to cause pain.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasamen: I did/went wrong, I was mistaken, I was misled, that is ‘I fell upon blindness/ruin.’

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasan: They damaged.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasato (He acted foolishly): He failed to understand, he went wrong, he grudged.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasthai (To damage): To outrage, to maltreat.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aasiphron (Damaged in the mind): Deranged. Also 'aasiphronia' (damage to the mind, i.e. witlessness), derangement. Others [say that it is] he who has a sleeping mind ('phren').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aaton (Insatiate): Great, unsated, painful. But others [say that it means] unhit, and others, slack.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aatos (Insatiate): Unharmed/unharming. But sometimes as double negative: "Indeed this decisive contest has come to completion."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aatos (Insatiate): Hurtful. Some [say that it means] insatiable, and others, dark.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakeos (Speechless): Void of understanding.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakenous: Those who have not had intercourse with a woman.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakemon (Speechless): Witless/unintelligible, speechless, voiceless.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakesai (To be speechless): To fail of having, to be hard of hearing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakesan (They were speechless): They did not perceive and did not understand; but others [say that it means] they kept quiet.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abaketon: Without reproach.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakton and abykton: Not enviable. But Dorians [say] 'anepiplektos' (not liable to be reproved) and 'amemphe' (without reproach).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abakion (Board): On which they used to play dice, and on which they used to do their accounts.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abale (Oh that!): Would that: "Oh that ..."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abalen: 'Ebalen' (he threw).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abaptos (Undipped): Untempered.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abasanistos (Untried): Unexercised or unexamined, untested. It is named after the 'basanos' (touchstone), the goldsmith's stone, on which they test gold. Aelian in On Pronoia, in the third logos, used 'abasanistos' for 'aneu odynes' (without pain).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abaton (Untrodden): Sacred, unapproachable, deserted.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abatos hodos (Untrodden road): [One] that is not possible to walk or proceed on.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abdelykta (Not to be abominated): Those that do not defile, which one would not abominate or hate. The word is rather tragic. Aischylos in Myrmidons: "verily, for I love them, these are not abominable to me."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abebelos (Untreadable): Clean. Also 'abebela': the untrodden and sacred areas, not to be walked upon by ordinary individuals but only by those who tend the gods. But those that were not holy or sacred used to be called 'bebela' (treadable). So Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abelteria (Stupidity): Mindlessness. Also 'abelteros' (stupid): one who is mindless, who does not know better ('beltion')

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abelteros (Stupid): “No, by Zeus, not the greedy and ignorant man, but the one who is mindless and simple and vapid.” Menander in Perinthia, “A servant who having caught a disengaged and easy-going master deceives him, does not know that he has accomplished a great thing by having proved stupider one who has long been stupid (abelteron).” But they also call stupidity ‘a stupid thing’ (abelterion)(?). Anaxandrides in Helen: “An anchor, a boat, what vessel you wish to call it. O Herakles of the precinct-related(?) stupidity. But a person could not speak its greatness.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abios (Wealthy): Antiphon deploys [the word] for one who has acquired a great livelihood, just as also Homer [deploys] 'axylon' (heavily wooded) for 'polyxylon' (much-wooded).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ableptemati (By oversight): By mistake.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ablechren (Weak): Without strength, for strong is 'blechron' (gentle).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abolos (Unshed): The foal that has not yet shed its teeth.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abolois polois (For unshed foals): For those who have not yet shed teeth.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aboulein (To be unwilling): Not to take counsel or not to wish. Plato.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abouleton kakon (Involuntary ill): Unwished for, what a person would not choose.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aboulia (Thoughtlessness): Lack of education, lack of understanding, rashness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aboulos (Inconsiderately): Senselessly, ignorantly, rashly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habra bainon (Walking daintily): Being wanton, being slack.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abramiaios (Abrahamite): Gigantic, befitting a sacred person. Or descendant of Abraham.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithera (Ether): So Attic authors call 'burning', after 'aithesthai' (to burn).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abios (Unharmed): He who is unharmed, from ‘bia’ (force), that is, he who is stronger than force. Also ‘abioi’ (without fixed substance): the nomads in Homer, that is, those who do not have a civic or shared livelihood. Euripides, however, used the word for ‘dysbios’ (making life wretched). But they used it also for one who has been deprived of life. But also ‘polybios’ (powerful) is called among the ancients, by way of emphasis of the alpha, ‘abios’.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agapeta ethe (Desirable characteristics): fine and good / gentlemanly (characteristics).

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agapeton: that which is beloved or unique.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agapetos pais (Beloved son): You will also say 'beloved father', 'beloved master', but also 'beloved child' for 'only.' Also applied to a girl.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelaiokomike (The art of caring for cattle): Plato used [the term].

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglauros: One of the daughters of Kekrops, whom women hold in honor and swear by, for, in honor of her father, Kekrops, the goddess [Athena] assigned certain privileges to Aglauros. Thus Bion of Prokonnesos.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoranomias (Market supervision): Office of the auditor. It is said applying to those who oversee cities' goods for sale.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agreumata (Things taken in hunting): Solon meant country property. But they also indicate spoils.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agromenoi (Assembled): Gathering together.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agona (Contest): Homer also [uses the word for] the place itself, in which they compete. Thucydides in Book 5: "having come forward into the arena, he wreathed the charioteer."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adeimanta: Without fear

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ademonein (To be troubled): In a strict sense, it is being at a loss or without resources in some land or country. Homer...

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigyptos (Egypt): The Nile river, after which the land was also called 'Aigyptos' by younger [generations].

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ainious (Aineans): Ainos is a city in Thrace, which Greeks, Alopekonnesians, first colonized, but they later brought in additional colonists from Mitylene and Kyme. The ethnic 'Aineans', at any rate, comes from 'Ainos'.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Academy: There used to be three gymnasia: the Lyceum, the Kynosarges, (and) the Academy. It was called after Akademos who dedicated it.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akedes (Uncared for): Unburied.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aleas: A Thessalian city. Its citizens [are] Aleis.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkar (Safeguard): Assistance, defense.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akyoron: A kind of charm, or a hunting-net.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopekonnesos (Fox island): It is a city, one of those in Chersonese.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ambrakia: it is a city on the Ambrakian Gulf, a Corinthian colony.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphiktyones: It is a Greek council convened at Thermopylai. They were named after Amphiktyon, son of Deukalion, for he convened the nations when he was king. These were twelve: Ionians, Dorians, Perrhaibians, Boiotians, Magnesians, Achaians, Pthiotians, Melians, Dolopians, Ainianians, Delphians, Phokians. But others say that they were named after the fact that those who were convened lived around Delphi.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphipolis: It is a city in Thrace. It was formerly called 'Ennea hodoi' (Nine Roads), but some say it was named Amphipolis on account of the fact that the place was inhabited all around.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anagkodakrys: Crying compulsively and not because of some experience or misfortune. Aeschylus [uses the term] in Xantriai.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aselgeia (Licentiousness): Prostitution, uncleanness. It is derived, as they say, from this reason. Selge is a city of Pisidia, where people used to live wickedly and have sexual intercourse with each other. And so, the act of behaving licentiously ('aselgainein') by extension [comes from the name].

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphorme: in a special sense in the Attic [authors], whenever someone gives money as capital, it is called 'aphorme.'

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ganos kai Ganiada (Ganos and Ganiada): they are places in Thrace.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Rhodopidos anathema (Dedication of Rhodopis): Many spits at Delphi. Apellas the Pontian also thinks [that it is] a pyramid in Egypt, though Herodotus refutes the notion. She was Thracian by birth and, along with Aesop, served as a slave to Admon of Mytilene. Charaxos, Sappho's brother, freed her. Sappho calls her Doricha.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achanes (Not opening the mouth): One who has not opened his mouth, who is dumb, speechless, one who has been stricken to silence.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharistous (ungracious, ungrateful): Those who do not return favors. Isocrates says "not giving favors to ungrateful people." Also one who repays a benefactor with bad things.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharistein (To show ingratitude): To not act graciously

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharistein (To show ingratitude): For 'to not act graciously'. So Antiphon.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharisteisai (To show ingratitude): To not act graciously nor render assistance.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acheiroton (Untamed): Without blemish, that which a hand has not touched.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acheron (Acheron): A river in Hades, so-called from 'achos' (pain).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achthedon (Burden): grief.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achthophoron (Porter): One carrying.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achthos (Burden): Weight, grief.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acthomai autou to rhypo (I am grieved by his filth): For 'illiberality and stinginess'. For they apply 'filth' to those who are niggardly and illiberal. Thus, at any rate, they call such men like this 'dirty-knuckles' (hypokondylous=>rhypokondylous).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achilleioi krithai (a fine kind of barley): cheap [barley]

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achilleia: The barley cake. The barley groats in it are the 'achilleia.'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achilleion alphiton (Of Achilleian barley meal): Of that which comes from the Achilleian barley, but some say 'white.'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achlys (mist over the eyes): darkness, fog, gloom, dim-sightedness.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achnai (Chaff): Fine chaff, or filth.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achrestos (Useless): A useless person. In a specific sense, a person with whom no one has any use. Thus Plato.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achrusoi (Without gold): Those who do not have gold.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Archethen (From the beginning): This is not among the Attic [authors], except in Aeschylus. But it is in Herodotus and the Ionian [authors].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Tritopator: Some [say that] Tritopatreis are winds. But Philochoros [says that they are] the first from Earth and Sky, having begun creation. And in the Orphika [that they are] children of winds.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Trittyan (Triple sacrifice): Sacrifice. Kallimachos [says that it is a sacrifice] of a ram, a bull, and a boar. Istros in Apollo's Epiphanies [says that it is a sacrifice] of male oxen, goats, pigs, all three years old.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Dysodos (Hard to pass): Rough, having difficult passage.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agan egkeisthai tode (To be too vehement against this one): As in, to oppose and strain (against). Aristophanes in Acharnians: "I know that even the Spartans, against whom we are too vehement, are not responsible for all our problems".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathou daimonos (The good spirit's): The drinking cup that is brought in after the removal of the tables is so called among the ancients.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathou daimonos poma (The good spirit's draught): The unmixed [wine] drunk after dinner among Athenians. They also used to call the second day [of the month] thus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathos phagein (Good at eating): Denotes one who eats a lot.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalmatopoiia kai agalmatourgia ereis kai agalmatopoios (You will find sculpture making and sculture work and sculpture maker). They say that he who tends rather to make images of gods is called an 'agalma'-maker ('agalmatopoios'), but that he [who makes images] of men [is called] an 'andrias'-maker ('andriantopoios'). Plato the philosopher in Protagoras calls both Pheidias and Polykleitos 'agalma'-makers. You would not be wrong in calling all craftsmen alike [this].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganakto sou (I am vexed at you): The construction is novel. For 'I marvel at you' and 'I wonder at you' are in daily use, but 'I am vexed at you' is novel and rare. One must use the figure owing to its novelty, says Phrynichos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agan egkeisthai tode (To be too vehement against this one): As in, to oppose and strain [against]. Aristophanes in Acharnians: "I know that even the Spartans, against whom we are too vehement, are not responsible for all our problems".

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theon agora (Assembly of the gods): Applying to those who dare to say something amongst their superiors.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agora theon (Gods' agora): A place in Athens used to be called [so].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agra: A sanctuary of Demeter outside the city by the Ilissos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrapha adikemata (Unwritten wrongs): As in, things about which a law does not exist.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agreutike stole (Hunting attire): The phrase is pleasant and urbane.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithale (Thick smoke): Embers, ashes, the black from an oven.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithalides: Aithalidai is a deme of the tribe Leontis, the tribesman from which is an 'Aithalides'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aithalodes (Sooty): Dark.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akalephe (Stinging nettle): Nettle ('knide'), both terrestrial and marine, which is a kind of mollusk. Aristophanes in Phoinissai: "Likely, I suppose, the first of all to grow up were also the tough stinging nettles". Pherekrates in Automoloi: "By Demeter, it was grievous to listen to him singing badly; for I would be crowned even by stinging nettles the same amount of time". The marine nettles also Aristotle [mentions] in the first book of On Animals, and Theophrastos [mentions] the terrestrial in the seventh book of Physika.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akampios (Unbending): The straightaway course and walk.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ake: A city in Phoenicia, which some say the city that is now called Ptolemais was so called long ago, but Demetrios [says] that the city was not [so called] but that its acropolis [was].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akmazeis (You are peaking): You are doing youthful things. So Hypereides and Lysias.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akme (Pinnacle): Sharpness, the very tipping point of the intensity of the matter. Also power. Also youth. A 'pinnacle of opportunity' is good fortune. So also Isokrates: "to lay hold of the pinnacle of opportunities". But it is taken also for 'yet/still'. So Hypereides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: To follow with him: So the Attic authors compose for 'akolouthein autoi' ('to follow with him'); for so also has Lysias used [it], and Plato, but also Aristophanes in Wealth says, "Follow with me, boy." Also Menander: "May victory always follow us with good intent". Also in the Parakatatheke he says, "he follows along with us".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aleiphobion (One who lives by anointing): One who dwells around the palaestra and is a servant. Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amma (Mother): Nurse and mother. Also Rhea and Demeter, and Artemis' nurse. And Lesbians used to call 'antliai' (ship holds, reservoirs) [so].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anagyrasios daimon (Anagyrasian daimon): Since the hero Anagyros took vengeance upon the old man who lived nearby and cut down his grove. Anagyrasians are a deme of Attika. A certain person of this [deme] cut down the grove. And [Anagyros] made his mistress fall in love with his son, who [the mistress] when she was unable to persuade the boy slandered him to his father as being licentious. He castrated him and built him into the house. For these things the father also hanged himself, but the mistress threw herself into a well. Hieronymos gives an account in On Tragic Poets, likening to them Euripides' Phoinix. Whenever, therefore, a person acts with a view to domestic evils, "you will move Anagyros" is said.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antheon (Of flowers): Attic [authors frame] the genitive similarly to the Ionians. Hermippos in Athena's Daughters: "A wax-woven new robe of flowers of the seasons". Also in the following: "brushing light robes full of flowers". And so also Xenophon distinguishes also many other things from both missiles and mountains.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antomosia (Affidavit): Having written certain documents, about which the suit [is concerned], both the accused and the accuser render them before the magistrate. It is called so since each of them would 'swear in turn' [antomnyen], the one that he would accuse true things and the other that he would say true things in defense.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Argyriou dike (Action for money): Whenever someone thought that money belonged to him from someone, he brought an action for money aganst him. And [this] used to be called an 'action for money'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrostai (Catchers): Hunters, from the verb 'I catch'. Homer: 'catching fishes'.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Antiparexagein (To lead on against): To range in battle against.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Akroreia (Mountain top): Peak, summit; for a mountain is divided into three parts: the peak, the slope, and the base. The summit is the 'akroreia' (mountaintop), the sides of the mountain are 'hyporeia' (slope), and the furthest edges are the 'terma' (base).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ages (Guilty/holy): This is left behind from the compound 'euages' or 'panages'. Empedokles says "For she watches opposite the holy disc of the lord."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agyrtes: Beggar, greedy for gain. Also 'agyrtes': a type of dice cast.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akopeton (Without an oar): Unprepared. It has been borrowed from ships that do not have 'kopas' (oars) or things prepared for sailing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agyrmos (Gathering): Assembly, meeting.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adephagoi triereis (Hungry triremes): Those receiving full pay and consuming a lot [of resources] would be called [so], by way of metaphor of full-grown race-horses. And Alkaios in his Komoidotragoidia (Tragicomedy) called tippling lamps 'hungry' (adephagous).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnotas (Unknown): Not known; "And he brought forth a man unknown to me, who also happened to be unknown to himself".

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphiboloi (Being thrown at from both sides): Being thrown at from all sides or being at a loss; constrained by different reasonings in ignorance of the choice whether they are to do one thing or another. They are also called 'amphiboloi' who were surrounded and are surrounded on all sides by something.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoge (Carrying away/guidance): Behavior, manner. Or conveyance. Also weight that is carried.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Akodoniston: Unexamined, not approved. So Aristophanes.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoras (Assemblies): Hyperides for 'assemblies'. For he says in the Against Polyeuctus "These men often hold assemblies." But the word also indicates other things.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Hala: Sea. Or the sharpness of claws.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agogion (Load): Weight that is carried on the wagon. So Xenophon.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gametion (Wedding cake): The cake from weddings.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agogimos (Capable of being carried): Leading, being led.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Nikochares for 'pig dealer' γένῃ(?)

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alabaston: Menander, without the rho in Orge: "And Lamprias behind, bringing the 'alabaston'." And it signifies an unguent box.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Haden (Gland): This is among the things that are in the body. It is around the groins and armpits, and also beneath the jaw bones. And the word is pronounced with an acute accent and it is irregularly aspirated, as Herodian says.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achuno: A certain herb is so named.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gampsonychas (With crooked talons): Having curved talons.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agogimon (Of things carried): Of mercantile freight.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Animon tois dorasin (They were drawing up with spears): For 'they were drawing up'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agonia (Competition): Rivalry. Also 'agon' (contest). Also said thus is 'the art of contest.'

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Aden: Enough. Plato used it in many places. Or to satiety, sufficiently, abundantly. In Charmides: "But when we had enough of such things."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphissa: It is a city in Lokris. Amphissa was named after the fact that the place is surrounded by hills.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Adoulos bios (Slaveless life) you will say, that is, one who does not have a slave. And you will also say 'conversationless life' and 'laughterless life' and 'unmarried life'. Phrynichus in Monotropos: "My name is Monotropos, and I live the life of Timon, unmarried, unwed, choleric, unapproachable, laughterless, conversationless, holding my own opinion."

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Adoulos (Without slaves) you will say, as Euripides, but also 'adouleutos' (not having been a slave), as Hypereides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adasmos (Without tribute): Paying out no tribute, nor apportioning tribute from one's household. So Aischylos.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Ganymene (Being happy): Rejoicing.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Barathron (Pit): A deep place, into which the wicked are thrown.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alabastrothekas (Perfume-bottle boxes): Where the vessels are placed, the little oil flasks made from alabaster. The word is especially written without the rho, but some people pronounce it with the rho.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Addix: A four-choinix measure. So, Aristophanes.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Anagyrous: A deme of (the tribe) Aiantis. And 'anagyrasios' is a deme of Attika, where also a bad smelling plant grows.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Adynata einai (To be impossible): For 'adynaton' (impossible). For often Thucydides used the plurals for singulars, and especially applying to this this word.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adees deos (Fearless fear): It is deployed applying to those who fear things not to be feared. Or safe, not to be feared.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Athymein (To be despondent): Applying to having fallen in spirit. It appears often in tragedy. So Aeschylus.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Ganysthai (To beam): To be cheered, to rejoice and to be put in good humor.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Barathron (Pit): It is a pit, into which the deme of Hippothoontis used to throw those sentenced to death. But in the Phillipics Demosthenes does not use the word in a strict sense, but by way of metaphor, as in 'ruin'.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alazon (Vagrant): Arrogant. Strictly, a cheater.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Akraiphnes (Pure): Clean, lofty, perfect. Or 'akraiphnous' (pure); as in intact, ('akerophanous') unharmed; for death is a blemish ('ker').

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gargara (Heaps): The word signifies a multitude.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alazon kai kompos: Liar and a braggart. Thus Kratinus.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antipalon (Rival): Denotes three things; opposed and equally matched and equal.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Tritogenes: Athena, either because she came out of the belly {and the womb} and the head of Zeus, or beause she was born next to Triton the river of Libya, or on the third [day] of the waning [month], as the Athenians also maintain; or because she was born third after Artemis and Apollo; or since the Athamanes call the head 'trito'; or since she was born beside Triton; or the reason is from 'to flee' ('trein') and to take care; or she is generative ('gennetike') because she washed herself in the river 'Triton' of Libya.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Basanizein (to interrogate, test): Not to apply torture and exact vengeance, among the Attic authors, but rather to examine and find the truth by questioning through speeches.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alazoneuesthai (To make false pretensions). They say that 'to lie' [is this]. And [they call] a liar an 'alazona' (braggart) and a 'phenaka' (cheat).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiparexagein (To lead on against): To range in battle against.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Tritomenis: They used to call the third of the month 'tritomenis'. Athena seems to have been born then. Istros also says that she is called Tritogeneia, since she is considered the same as Selene.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alalagmos (Loud clamor): Victory song.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gastroiden (Belly-shaped): They call him who has a big stomach ['gastroiden'].
Notes: Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Halaieus (From Halai): The name of a deme.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Torone: A city in Thrace.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antirrhopon (Counterpoise): Equipoise.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Antigrapheus. The one making check-copies of monies contributed, in the manner of a secretary, whether he be slave or free. There were two, the one for the general administrative fund, the other for the council, as Demosthenes says and Aeschines.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Basanos (Touchstone): it is a stone, on which they test gold when rubbed against it. Thus Antiphon and Pindar. But Hyperides called what was said in examination (basanois) by those being examined (basanizomenon), and written down, 'basanoi.'

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akinakes: A small Persian spear.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gegonon (Sonorous): Audible, clear in voice. Also 'Gegoniskein' (To proclaim): To say audible things.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiochis: Name of a tribe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pyroi epikalamoi (Wheats on the stalk): Those that have not yet been harvested; or those on the threshing-floor not yet threshed, but being in the sheafs; also called 'wheats on the stalk' are those sown in the same ground, which has not got a fallow period; that is, whenever grain is sown upon grain without interval.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alaleton (War-cry): A clamor.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alapaxai (To have drained): To have ravaged, emptied, leveled.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gegonein (To shout): To have shouted audibly.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Arche andra deiknysi (The office reveals a man): It is proverbial. Solon says it is an apophthegm. Aristotle and Theophrastus [say it is] of Bias.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Basanisas (Having examined): For 'having tested'; pretty much all the worthy writers used it.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gegonokomai (Those filling the village with clamor): Women who fill the villages with shouting.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastor: Nikochares [said it] in the feminine: "the sinning Sphinx".

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geision kai geisos (Parapet and cornice): The top of a roof. Or the crowns of a house. And 'geisa' (cornices), tops of roofs.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: The Attic (authors) call 'boleonas' (dunghills) where the excrement of cows and of draft animals and of sheep is thrown.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pylai kai Pylaia kai Pylagoras (Pylai and Pylaia and pylagoras): Thermopylai is called 'Pylai' (gates); it was so called on account of the fact that this entrance, for those journeying from Thessaly to Phokis, is narrow. The meeting of the Amphiktyons at Pylai was called a Pylaia. And certain men used to be sent by the cities that had a share in the Amphiktyony, who were called 'pylagoroi'.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geisipous kai geisipodisma (Cornice support and cornice supports): Thus is called the wood that lies under and supports the cornice. And the cornice is also called the porch and the crown, by which the gutter is also supported.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastor: A certain spirit that takes vengeance on those who have done 'alasta' (insufferable things) is also called [this]. Also the one himself who has done some such thing, especially murder by his own hand. Menander in the Perikeiromene says, "But I am an 'alastor' and a jealous man." And in the Orge it is shown that [the word] was just recently a local expression. "And what is this word 'alastor' you are saying?" he says. Therefore this was a new meaning/saying, unless he is speaking against certain tragic poets, since they use the word excessively.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nomophylakes (Guardians of laws): A certain magistracy among Athenians was so called, differing from the 'thesmothetai', who used to compel the magistrates to use the laws.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geiorai (Sojourners): Those guarding the land.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Dainu: Feast!

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gelaseionta (Being ready to laugh): Being able to laugh, willing to laugh.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Dainymenos: Feasting.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geisipous kai geisipodisma kai geisopodizein (Cornice support and cornice supports and to support a cornice): The projection of the beam, on which the cornice is, is called 'geisipous' (cornice support) and 'geisipodisma' (cornice supports). And 'geisopodizein' (to support a cornice) is to do this.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gelgithes: Heads of garlic.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastoron: For 'alastora' (avenging spirit), from the nominative 'alastoros'. Aischylos said "great 'alastoron'."

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Genethlialogia (Astrology): Prophesy about birth.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoi Molottikoi (Mollossian gods): Gods of the underworld, since there was a place in Molossus where souls were conjured up.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geloios (Amusing): The most absurd, accented with a circumflex on the penultimate. And 'gelotopoios' (ridiculous) is accented with an acute on the ultimate.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastora prosbalein (To procure Alastor): As in defilement and impiety. Euripides: "I do not advise you, contriving evil things against hostile men, to procure your own Alastor."

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genarxou (Of the founder): Of the father.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoklytesantes (Having called on the gods): Having heard a god, having summoned a god.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haima nipsai (To purge blood): So the Attic [authors] used to say to refer to purging away ('eknipsai') homicide, as Demosthenes also [says].

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastor: He who has dared such things that it is not possible to forget.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Elikteres (Something twisted): A type of earrings.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoklytoumai (I am inspired): I am initiated by the will of the gods, possessed by the gods, I am held in honor by the gods.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Gennetai (Clan members): Not those related by clan and by blood, but those from the clans associated together into the phratries. These are just as deme members and phratry members, having fellowship by a certain custom. The clan has 30 men. And the phratries are called trittyes (third-parts), because, being four tribes, they divided each part into three, making four tribes imitating the seasons of the year, and twelve phratries and trittyes, just as the months, and 30 clans in each phratry, just as the 365 days.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastor: A murderous spirit avenging and doing unforgettable things.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gennaios ei ek balantiou (You are noble as a result of the purse): For those seeming to be well born because of wealth.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alastor: The one doing all wicked things.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ages (Guilty/holy): This is left behind from the compound 'euages' or 'panages'. Empedokles says "For she watches opposite the holy disc of the lord."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akkizomenos (Affecting indifference): Being coy, pretending, acting like a woman, or foolish, after a certain stupid woman who was called Akko. But it also denotes one who is willing, but pretends not to be.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genethla (Races): Those born.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Makran timesin (Big fine): To the jurors a tablet used to be given, on which they used write a big mark, whenever they convicted someone in the act, but a short one, whenever they released and did not convict.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoras (Assemblies): Hyperides for 'assemblies'. For he says in the Against Polyeuctus "These men often hold assemblies." But the word also indicates other things.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alitria (Sinfulness): For 'hamartia' (fault, guilt). Aristophanes.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Adoulos bios (Slaveless life) you will say, that is, one who does not have a slave. And you will also say 'conversationless life' and 'laughterless life' and 'unmarried life'. Phrynichus in Monotropos: "My name is Monotropos, and I live the life of Timon, unmarried, unwed, choleric, unapproachable, laughterless, conversationless, holding my own opinion."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aklero (To/for one without a share): To/for one who does not have a share or property, a beggar; for property is a share, whence also 'epikleros' (heiress).

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alitemon: Sinning.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genethlia (Birthday): The festival of the living occurring each year.
Notes: Edited by Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>, John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Adynata einai (To be impossible): For 'adynaton' (impossible). For often Thucydides used the plurals for singulars, and especially applying to this this word.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Koinon grammateion kai lexiarchikon (Common and lexiarchic register): The common [is the one] into which they used to be enrolled among phratrymen and clansmen; and the lexiarchic [is the one] into which those enrolled in the demes used to be enrolled.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Aliterios (Offending): Unholy, one bound up with pollution and having erred against the gods. Aristophanes in Knights: "I say that you have been born from unholy people."

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Akraiphnes (Pure): Clean, lofty, perfect. Or 'akraiphnous' (pure); as in intact, ('akerophanous') unharmed; for death is a blemish ('ker').

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Es korakas (To the crows): The god directed the Boiotians by means of an oracle to settle wherever white crows were seen. And after seeing crows, which had been chalked over by kids who meant no harm, flying around the Pagasetic Gulf...of Apollo...they settled there, having called the place 'Korakes' (Crows). But later, after the Aiolians had expelled them, they began to send their exiles to the same (place). Others [say that the expression is] on grounds that the animal is shameless and ill-omened for mankind. Aristotle says that when a plague took hold and many crows appeared, people, capturing and purifying them completely, left them alive and said to the plague, "Flee to the crows." Aesop [said' in one of his fables that a big jackdaw, thinking that he was equal to the crows, went to go see them, but after being bested, went back to the jackdaws. But they, since they were irritated, chased him away, saying, "Flee to the crows". Aristides suggests that we say, "Flee to the crows", on account of the fact that they nest in rough and precipitous places.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Katalogeus: At Athens there were certain men giving a catalogue of names of those who were able to administer public affairs; the same were also called 'syngrapheis', because they used to write in that certain persons should partake in citizenship.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genesia (Day kept in memory of the birthday of the dead): The remembrance of the dead occuring each year.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adelphizein (To call 'brother'): To call someone 'brother' frequently and obsequiously. Not only comedy, but also the orators use this term. So Isocrates.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adephagoi triereis (Hungry triremes): The big [triremes] used to be called so, or ones carrying full loads. Also hungry chariot teams: the big and full-grown ones. And [the term] is formed from eating 'to one's fill' (aden) or abundantly.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Therapnai: It is a place in Lakedaimonia, which Isocrates and Alkaios(?) mention.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: (?) Habrodiaite (Living daintily): Luxurious living, and soft and full of pleasure. (?)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Age (Amazement): Wonder, delight, disbelief and zeal in Herodotus and jealousy. But in Homer, astonishment, shock, breaking up, fracture, destruction. Some [say] sacrificial animals.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelatein (To drive out a cursed person): To drive out a curse and cursed people

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agos (Leader): Leader.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agos: Zeus, among Troezenes.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathoergoi (do-gooders): Men selected according to manly virtue. Spartans (call 'agathoergoi') those retiring from the cavalry, five in each year, as Herodotus (attests) in book 1, but others (call so) archons' underlings. Attic (writers call so) those who have done some good deed. And the 'agathoergoi' are also a certain magistracy in Lacedaemon; they are in charge of deportations of and those who have broken the laws, both inside the city and outside the city, as Didymus says in Figurative Speech.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Attic [writers] call kindness 'agapesmos' (affection) and 'agapesis' (affection). In Synaristosai Menander [says], "The mutual affection arising with a view to evil, such as it was".

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agein (Perform): For ‘to play a part’. Also ‘agein’ for ‘to honor’ and ‘to toast’, which Attic [writers] used to say as ‘epagein’(?).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agênôr (manly, heroic): an exceptionally/excessively manly person. Or one admirable in bravery. But it also denotes someone overweening/arrogant. And it is also a proper name.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnaptos (Unfulled): They used to say the word both with a gamma and with a kappa. And it denotes not being fulled. And it is said as masculine and feminine and neuter: masculine, as in 'agnaptos chiton' (unfulled tunic), feminine as in 'agnaptos chlaina' (unfulled cloak), neuter as in 'agnapton himation' (unfulled himation). Certainly Plato the comic also calls a cloak 'unfulled', however not every cloak is unfulled as well. And a cloak is a thick himation, either unfulled or having been fulled.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ebrotothe (He was made mortal): He became mortal. This word is suitable for usage. On the one hand, [applied] to a god, as in ‘to become human’: “For because of us god was made mortal,” for ‘he became human.’ On the other, [applied] to witless and mindless men, we’ll say that he has been made mortal who from mindlessness ascends to health and reasoning suitable for men. For in reality a human is one who possess a mind that is undisturbed and sensible and swift and scientific.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Akesasthai kai akesai (To heal): To mend, whence Attic [writers] also call a seamstress 'akestria' (mender).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ebrotothe (He was made mortal): He became mortal. This word is suitable for usage. On the one hand, [applied] to a god, as in ‘to become human’: “For because of us god was made mortal,” for ‘he became human.’ On the other, [applied] to witless and mindless men, we’ll say that he has been made mortal who from mindlessness ascends to health and reasoning suitable for men. For in reality a human is one who possess a mind that is undisturbed and sensible and swift and scientific.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Akoretos (Unswept): Unorganized, for to sweep is 'korein' in Attic [writers].

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Alelimmenon (Having been anointed): Attic [writers] say such words, reduplicating [them], for 'eleimmenon'. So Thucydides.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Hamaxa (wagon): Ship, among the Attic [writers]. And perhaps they liken it to a wagon after 'to reap' (aman) the sea. The word is in Aeschylus.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Amaryssein kai amaryzein (To dazzle): Both Attic and the Ionian [writers say] it in two ways. Also 'aphassein' and 'aphazein' (feel).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Hamartian (fault), the Attic [writers say]; 'hamartada',  Herodotus and the other Ionian [writers].

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Amorphotos (Unshaped): Uncorrected, unformed, unarranged.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achri, achris (until): for 'mechris' (as long as), 'eos,' (until).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achromatos (Without color): Shameless.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agos (Any matter of religious awe; transf. a curse, defilement): By antiphrasis, 'defilement' (to musos). And 'enagês' (accursed) [is] someone held in defilement. And 'agêlatein' (drive out one accursed) [is] to drive out those accursed. But 'panagês' (all-hallowed) denotes one holy and pure. And whereas the word 'enagês' is derived from 'agos,' the word 'panagês' [is derived] from 'hagnos' (holy) and 'katharos' (pure). And it also denotes expiation and sacrificing.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achurmiai (Chaff heaps): The places to which the chaff is carried off when it has been separated from the grain.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiaphoria (indifference): indifference without observation.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Antirropon (Counterpoise): Equipoise.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiastaton (Continuous): Not yet separated or distinguished. Antiphon said [it].

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Anymenaioun (To celebrate with nuptial odes): Sophocles in Phrygians "Will you not stop, not cease celebrating these weddings?!"

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiabatos (Impassable): What cannot easily, or at all, be crossed.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiaglypton (Uncuttable): Which it is not possible to cut and pass through. "For a grip," he says, "[is] inescapable [and] uncuttable".

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Aner de pheugon ou menei lyras ktypon (A man when he flees does not wait for the din of the lyre): Aristophanes in Daitaleis, as a kind of saying.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiallakton echthron (Irreconcilable enemy): Demosthenes said [this], and Xenophon [said] 'adiapauston' (incessant).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adialyton (Indissoluble): Not destroyed, as Plato [says] in On the Soul.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alabastron: A stone vessel of perfume without handles. Or an unguent box made of marble.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Bakteria (wand) and Symbolon (token): Those who were chosen by lot to serve as jurors used to receive from the public attendants a token and a wand, and thus they served as jurors. The court used to have the same color as the wand. As for the token, however, having given it back after the trial, they used to receive three obols, which they used to call the 'dikastikon' (jury pay).

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Balantion (Bag): A pouch.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Athlon (Prize): An object of competition, or an honor. The reward, the baton given as the prize for the competition.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Athlos (Contest for a prize): In the masculine, the deed and the object of competition and the prize. But it differs from the neuter, because the neuter refers properly to the prize, but this [form refers to] the competition.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nabla: A type of instrument.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Glykon (Sweet one): One who is good-hearted. Dull, relaxed.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Gennetai (Clan members): Those sharing the same clan. For Athenian citizens had been divided into parts, and the greatest parts were called 'phylai' (tribes), and each tribe had been divided again into three, of which each part was called a 'trittys' (third-part) and a 'phratria' (phratry). And again each of the phratries was divided into 30 clans, from which the priesthoods belonging to each were allotted. And those of the same and the first clan of the 30 clans, whom Philochoros says were formerly called 'homogalaktes' (those who drank the same milk) were 'gennetai'. Isaios, however, calls 'gennetai' simply kinsmen by blood.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Ather (Barb): The tip/edge of a sharpened iron tool, by metaphor from the spike ('ather'), which is the uppermost and finest part of an ear [of grain], after which the words 'athereloigon' (winnowing fan) and 'atherizein' (to make light of) are made. So Philonides.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adoleschia (Idle talk): Impropriety, chatter, gossip.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiounios tauros (Adiounian bull): Apollo is called thusly by the Cretans. For they say that when he relocated the polis he led the way likened somehow to a bull.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Admetou logon (Story of Admetus): Start of a lyric round, which some say is by Alcaeus, and others by Sappho.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiexiteton: Lacking an exit.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adikiou (for wrongdoing): that is, 'adikêmatos' (intentional wrong). And it a word for a suit. And this pays out singly, if ever it is rendered before the ninth prytany; but if not, a double payment is made.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adikos dike (Unjust suit): One that arises out of sycophancy, as Cratinus [says]: "so as to win unjust suits for shameful gains".

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adikiou (For wrongdoing): The suit against those who wrong the city is called [this]. And its penalty is money paid out singly.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adikomachous hippous (Obstinate horses): Xenophon calls the disobedient ones [this]. And he calls the obedient one 'dikaion harma' (a right team).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiopon (Without a commander): Unruled and unprotected.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Anagyrous: A deme of (the tribe) Aiantis. And 'anagyrasios' is a deme of Attika, where also a bad smelling plant grows.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agleukes (Unsweet): Bitter. Xenophon said [it] in the Oikonomikos. The word appears to be foreign, Sicilian, and at any rate, it is common in turn in Rhinthon.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agora Kerkopon (Knavesmarket): In Athens near the Heliaia, in which especially things acquired by theft are bought and sold, for we have ascertained [that] even the Kerkopes were such: [namely,] thieves and knaves.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agora ephoreia (Border assembly): The assembly that met at the shared borders ('horois') of the [civic] neighbors used to be called so, for when they came together here, neighbors used to deliberate at the same place concerning shared matters.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agousin heorten hoi kleptai (The thieves are holding a festival): The phrase is very charming and sufficiently jokey, in keeping with comedic charm. But it also denotes those who steal fearlessly. Thus Kratinos.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adonia: It has the penultimate short, as Aristophanes and Pherekrates attest through their verses. The Adonia is a festival, which some say is celebrated in honor of Adonis, others for Aphrodite. It is Phoenician and Cypriot.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Kollytos: deme of the tribe Aegeis

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adephagon harma (Hungry chariot team): full-grown.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aapton (Invincible): Strong, weighty, difficult. But others [say] insatiable. Also "invincible hands," [that is] great, unapproachable, which one could not take ahold of. But if it is given smooth breathing, [it means] undaunted [hands]. But others [say that] 'aapton' is boundless, infinite.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Haimatopotes (Blood-drinker): The Attic [writers] pronounce the word by lengthening the omikron, just as also 'oinopôtes' (wine-drinker) and 'hydropôtes' (water-drinker), since whereas some also write 'poma' (lid, cover) with a short omikron, Attic [authors write it] by lengthening it.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Alyein (To be deeply stirred): Some deem fit to pronounce it with a rough breathing: "if you are distraught (halyeis) that you have vanquished Irus". But with a smooth breathing, it is to grieve (lypeisthai): “thus he spoke, and she departed in grief (alyousa)”. But Didymus says that both ought to be pronounced smooth, for he says that while the former comes from the verb 'aleainesthai' (to grow warm), the latter comes from the noun 'ale' (roaming). But it is more Attic to pronounce both with a rough breathing, for the Attic writers aspirate 'haleainesthai' and all similar words: 'hamis' (chamberpot), 'hamaxa' (wagon), 'hamnos' (lamb), 'Halaeis' (Haleians), 'hanyein' (to accomplish), 'hamos' (mine/ours).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Physiologeitai: Discourses on nature.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Physke (Large intestine): The thick bowel, or the belly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Physte (Pastry): With the accent as 'hephthe' (boiled). Barley cake that is kneaded in bowls and soaked.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Physta: Barley groats mixed up with honey.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phytalies (Of a vineyard): Of vine-growing land.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phytalizei: plants, nears.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phytekomos (Plant-tender, gardener): Plant-worker/gardener. Also thickly wooded place, owing to the fact that is plumed with plants.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pho: Let me say.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phoides: Blisters from flame.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pholadi: Lurking in a hole.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phokaeon ara (Phokaians' vow): Phokaians when they left their city during the siege by Harpagos, set out for Italy, having thrown lumps of metal in the sea and sworn that they would not return to their own city before these [lumps] were brought back up.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phokou eranos (Phokos' potluck feast): Phokos, as they say, having a daughter in her prime, assembling a potluck feast from the suitors, kept saying that he would marry off his daughter, to whomever the god advised. They, out of anger, despatched Phokos. And the expression applies to those who furnish unprofitable potluck feasts.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
