Translation: Phrynondas: A proper name. He was an Athenian notorious for wickedness no less than Eurybatos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Philepsios: Demosthenes Against Timokrates. The poets of old comedy mention Philepsios for telling tales in the middle of speeches to the people. He was also satirized for knavery.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hypophonia (Were-geld): The money given for the homicide to the relatives of the one who was killed, so that they not prosecute. So Deinarchos and Theophrastos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Tis tropos hippon (What is this horse play?): An expression applying to weird things. Metagenes in Thouriopersai: "What is this horseplay? My how they dance in barbarian style".

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesthai (To place): Hyperides [uses it] for 'to receive a deposit'. Demosthenes only uses it for 'to approve' or 'to ratify [a law]' in On the Tax Exemptions. However, in Against Stephanos he says, “establishing laws ('themenon') for himself” for 'having established' ('thenta').
Notes: Edited by Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com> and Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Gorgon's lock of hair: the Gorgon's lock of hair [which was] given to Asterope, daughter of Kepheus, at the time when Kepheus marched out against Lakedaimon together with Herakles, so that the city might remain unravaged while he was abroad.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hypobibazousin: They descend.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalma Hekates (Image of Hekate): Aristophanes has said that the dog [is] such [i.e. Hekate's image], on account of the fact that dogs are brought forth to Hekate, or because they also model her with a dog-head. But there are also those who [say that] she turned from a woman into a dog in accordance with the anger of Artemis, then was restored again after being pitied by her, then hanged herself from her belt because she was ashamed of what had happened. And [they say that] Artemis, having taken off her own finery, bestowed it upon her and addressed her as Hekate.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gennadas (Noble): High-born, the most well-born.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gennaios (High-born): One who has been born well.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thimbron: This man was a Lakedaimonian, sent to Asia as a governor after the Peloponnesian War.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thoimation: ‘To himation’ (outer garment).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thladias: A eunuch.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thoinatai: He is feasted.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thoeros(?): Having been confused.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thranos (bench): Footstool. They also say ‘thranidion (little bench).'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abrai (Favorite slaves): Young slave women. But, they say an 'abra' is not simply a handmaiden, nor a pretty one, but the lady’s maid who lives in the house, and is highly honored, whether born in the house or not. Menander, in his Pseudo-Herakles, says "The mother of these two sisters has died, and some concubine of their father’s is raising them, a former 'abra' of their mother. And in the Sicyonian, “He bought a beloved slave instead, and did not give her over to her to have, but he raised [her] separately as is fitting for a free a free woman”. In the Untrustworthy One: “I thought, if the old man should get some gold, a handmaiden will be purchased immediately as an 'abra'."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnomonos (Senselessly): Foolishly or ingraciously. Ignorant people are said by Plato to be 'agnomones'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnomonos (Senselessely): Demosthenes, in the Philippics, for 'irrationally', or 'ill-advisedly'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agos (Pollution): Pollution or elbow. But also what is held in honor and worthy of awe is called 'agos', from which [come] all-holy ('panageis') priestesses and other things.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agraphou metallou dike (Suit for unregistered mine): Those who work the silver mines, whenever they wanted to begin a new work, would make it known to those put in charge of those things by the people and would declare for the sake of paying the tax to the people the twenty-fourth of the new mine. If anyone, then, seemed to be working a mine in secret, it was possible for anyone who wished to charge and accuse him who had not declared.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrioi (Savages): So they used to call pederasts, either because their passion was savage, or because Pan is responsible for such people. And they also call them Centaurs. It is clear that the wild among animals are called 'agria.' Also one who is dyspeptic in disposition and irascible is 'agrios'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrious (Savages): Aeschines in Against Timarchus so named those who were very excited about the pursuit of boys. Also Menander called "savage gambler" him one who has become too zealous about gambling.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aguiai: Streets, alleys. Or long roads. From the fact that they do not have limbs ('guia') and branches and bends. Streets have throughways from either side and differ in this way.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aguias: Some pronounce with an acute accent, employing in the feminine, just like roads. But it is better to pronounce it with a circumflex, on the grounds that it is from 'aguieas'. But 'aguieus' is a column terminating in a point, which they stand in front of gates. Some say they are particular to Apollo, some to Dionysus, some to both. The complete form, then, is 'aguieus', and 'aguieas' in the accusative, and 'aguias' in the contracted form. It is characteristic of the Dorians. The altars in front of dwellings would be those called 'aguieis' by the Attic [authors], as Sophocles, transferring Athenian customs to Troy, says: "an 'aguieus' altar shines, with fire wafting drops of myrrh, barbarous smells".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agon: Indicates a proper name, as Douris observes. But it also denotes contest and assemblage and temple where people are gathered, and a place, where a mass is gathered.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adidaktos (Untrained): Demosthenes in Against Medias: "The chorus would have entered untrained".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athymos (Fainthearted): Not irascible in Plato and deeply grieved in Aeschines.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akroteleution epous (Final part of a verse): The final part of a poetic section. For Attic [writers] properly place final parts on poems. So Phrynichus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alabastothekas (Perfume-bottle boxes): Demosthenes calls boxes ('thekas') of perfume bottles ('alabaston') [this], which in common usage they call 'myrothekas' (unguent boxes). And 'alabastoi' are oil flasks which it is not possible to take hold of because of their smoothness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halipasta (Sprinkled with salt): Many people think that pickled things are 'halipasta', but Attic [writers] do not use [it] in this way, but applying to meat fresh roasted after having been sprinkled with salt.
Notes:
Edited by John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com> , 
Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alitrias (Sinfulness): A mistake. Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halios (Of the seaman): For 'halieos'. Pherekrates.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkaia: An animal's tail, and strictly a lion's, from 'alalkein', which is 'to come to aid', just as 'oura' is from 'ourein', which is 'to keep watch'. But some [understand] 'alkaian' owing to inciting to battle ('alke'), since the lion, by whipping its hips and sides with its tail, goads itself for a fight. And the bull also and the dog and many other beasts have used the tail for battle. But certain say that 'oura' said after 'orinein' (to excite) and stirring to battle.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkmaionidai (Alcmaeonids): A distinguished family at Athens [named] after Alkman.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkyon (Kingfisher): A bird of the sea, which gives birth, according to Aristotle, around the winter solstices, and the sea becomes still for 14 days. And those days are called 'alkyonides' (halcyon). The kingfisher gives birth and nourishes [them] on the fifth day. But the halcyon days don't happen everywhere, but rather around Sicily. The creature is said to be ill-omened. The Poet [Homer] shortens the ypsilon in 'alkyon', but Euphorion lengthens it. The kingfisher is also called 'alkydon' among some people. But among the Laconians a certain spirit is called 'Alkyon.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allen dryn balanize (Shake another oak): Applying to those asking for something continually or borrowing from the same people.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allos (Another): For 'heteros' (another). Homer: "He who hides one thing in his mind but would say the other." He employs it also for 'tis' (some): "Whenever some traveler, having met with you."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halmyrides: Some place on the outskirts of Attica. Aristophanes in the Tereus: "It was necessary for you, having been cast into Halmyrides, not to make yourself troublesome for this daughter of yours."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aloan (To thresh): To strike, to hit. Also to split grain on the threshing floor.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halontes: Having been taken.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halos achne: Foam of the sea.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halos theioio (Of holy salt): Honored, owing to its great and widespread usage. Or, pure and uncorrupted. Or, just and necessary. 'Just,' in as much as it is called so in the mysteries. For libations and the communion of hearth-sharing and sacrifices {and priests} and the table are observed with this. 'Necessary,' due to its permanence and convenience and vigor of useful things for men. Both fire and the sea seem to be called 'theion' for some such reasons. Or owing to the fact that it is a purifier of filth. Further still the important and good and noble or the great and the best are called 'theion.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alostatei: He serves in the army.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alokizein (To make furrows): To plow.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aloimos (Plastering):  The coating of walls.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aloiphe (Smearing): Fat.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alogian (Lack of reason): To have no 'logos' (reason), and to act thoughtlessly. Thus Demosthenes and Plato.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alypos: One who is not pained. 'Alypetos' (unpained) is also said. Theopompos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alysthainein (To be pained): To be unable.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aman: To mow down. From at the same time ...

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amadokos: There have been two, a father and a son, who, in order to be an ally for Philip, went to war against Kersobleptes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amaltheias keras (The horn of Amaltheia): To attain all things, since those praying to the heavenly goat attain [their prayers]. Aristophanes: "The city is Amaltheia's horn, only pray and all things wil be present."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amysti piein (To drink without closing the mouth): Adverbially. It is applied to those drinking without taking a breath and without pausing, as if not even closing the mouth. 'Examystisai' (to guzzle) is also connected with the same. Also 'amystizein' (to guzzle) and (words) from it are also said. And Pherekrates said 'amysti'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aneipen (He declared): He proclaimed, he stated publicly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aneireke ton chresmon (He has announced the oracle): They also say that the herald announced [it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anelesthai polemon (To take up war): For to make war.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anelousa gar ton nomon exeirotonesen auten (For cancelling the law it voted it): Demosthenes said this passage in Against Androtion. The text is transmitted in two ways, the one as written previously, the other in place of “autei” says “auten” in the accusative. And the one transmitted in the accusative has a sense of this sort: abrogating this law (or rather transgressing it) they submitted the deciding vote concerning it, that it was necessary to crown it. The one in the dative: abrogating this law it voted that for itself.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anelpiston bion (A life free of hope): The Attic [writers] said that the fairest [life was one] in which one is not stirred up into hopes, but good things are already present. Thus Pindar.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ano potamon rheousi pegai (Streams flow up-river): A saying about contrary events or utterances, such as if the prostitute calls the wiser man a prostitute. Since rivers flow down from above, not up from below. Demosthenes uses this in On the False Embassy, "it seems to me that matters are up-river."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: The Attic (authors) call 'boleonas' (dunghills) where the excrement of cows and of draft animals and of sheep is thrown.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bouzygis: A certain holy clan in Athens [named after/descended] from the hero Bouzygus, who first having yoked a cow plowed the earth and softened it for agriculture. Lycurgus was also from this clan. But also the priestess of Athena was from them.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Schoinos: A unit of land measurement, as Herodotus says in the second book of the Histories.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigyption (Egyptian): Εthnic name. Also a proper [name] belonging to the old Ithacan.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Blichon(?) (Pennyroyal): 'Glichon(?)' is said in this way among the Attic [writers]. It is a type of plant. And Aristophanes names pubic hairs in this way.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aytonomoumene polis (Independent city): One which uses its own laws and is not subject to others.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Karyanda: a city in Caria

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelaion (Of the common herds): Of common things, of roaming things. Also of things belonging to a herd: the random masses. It might be by way of metaphor from herd animals or from fish, which they say feed abundantly and in schools ('ageledon').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agogeus (Lead): The hunting dogs' leash. So Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glykythymos (Sweet of mood): Tender in spirit.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Graphe (Public action): The accusation concerning public crimes and other wrongs. There are public actions for laws and decrees that appear to be introduced without advantage, which are called actions for illegalities ('graphai paranomon').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Graphe (Public action): Word for a certain public plaint. Not only whenever someone charges a decree or law, is he said to file and record a 'graphe paranomon', but also over other public crimes. The use is common in the orators.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Griphoi (Riddles): Sympotic inquiries.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiosasthai: To appropriate.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Enkourades (Ceiling tiles): Painted tiles in ceilings, which some call 'anapheromena' (things placed overhead); they are the same as 'kourades,' but some [say] that the unpainted [tiles] [are called] 'kourades.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Enkyklious leitourgias (Cyclical liturgies): Those that happen every year: for the year is a circle, after the fact that it is encircled by the rotation of the days.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idion (Of private things): Of personal things.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: The Attic [authors] call the root 'enchousa', not 'anchousa', which Eratosthenes ignorantly [calls] 'phykion'. Ameipsias in Apokottabizontes: "for two obols enchousa and white lead."

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiotas (Private men): Citizens. So Thucydides.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idnotheis: Having been bent.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idrieus: He was a ruler in Caria, son of Hekatomnos, brother of Mausolos and Artemisia.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idris: Experienced.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hidrymenos: Founded.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hidrysanto (They had it founded): They set, they founded.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hidrysis (Foundation): Steadfast security.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Idyous: Witnesses. So Solon.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiei: He sends, he throws around.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiemenoi: Desiring.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ienai: To go or to have gone.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hientai: They set in motion.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hientes: Letting go.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierasthai: To perform sacred rites.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hidrysis (Foundation): Steadfast security.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hidrysanto (They had it founded): They set, they founded.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierax: This was one of the men of Amphipolis sent as ambassadors to Athens, wishing to turn over to the Athenians both their city and their land.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Edemothe (It was made public): It was publicized among the people, it became clear to everyone. Thus Dio in Roman History Book 17: “And a certain story of this kind was made public concerning these matters.” Also 'they publicized': they made public.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ethrexe (He dashed): Properly, he ran; but it is also said concerning matters under consideration, like ‘it came over’; they also say 'enthrattein' (to prick) and 'hypothrattein' (to surprise).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eidolon (Phantom): A shadowy likeness or an image of a body, a sort of airy shadow, as Bacchylides [says]: “gloomy(?) phantom of an Ithacan man”. And the Poet [says] of Anticleia: “Three times out of my hands like a shadow.” ... “he is the true substance; so that it is necessary to think that they provide images of their bodies to those who see them, but not in fact their true substance.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eipous (Weights): They call mouse-traps [this]. And a falling weight. They too had the mousetrap. In Anagyros: “Even if you don’t catch anything, set up a mousetrap.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hekates nesou (The island of Hekate): Before Delos there lies certain islet, which is called by some Psammetiche; they say it is called σο because they honor the goddess with 'psammita'. 'Psammita' are a kind of cake.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ekdeia: The remainder outstanding: for to pay a part of what a person owes, and not all, is 'ekdeia', but to pay nothing at all is 'endeia'. Or, for someone not to pay, though he has [it], is 'ekdeia', whereas not to have anything is 'endeia', so that the one is willing, the other unwilling.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eklozete (You hooted): They used to call 'klosmos' (hooting/clucking) the sound that happens in the mouth, which they used for the rejection of performances that they did not enjoy.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: They say that 'ekmartyrein' (to testify) is to speak about one has not seen oneself, but rather what one has heard from others speaking; and written testimony ('ekmartyria') is read aloud, whenever someone has died or is abroad.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ekphyllophoresai (To expel with leaves): If any of the councillors seemed to do wrong, the council would hold a vote about him, as to whether he should no longer serve as a councillor. But instead of a pebble they would use leaves, on which each would mark his own will.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Elegeinein (To be violent): Some of the ancients [use this to mean] 'go insane.' And some people think that the meter ‘elegiac’ was named after this, because Theocles of Naxos or Eretria first shouted it out while mad.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeus Eleutherios (Zeus of Freedom): On account of this Zeus is called Eleutherios (of freedom), because freedmen built the stoa next to him. Thus Hyperides. Didymos on the other hand says it’s not because of that, but because the Athenians escaped the slavery and dominance of the Medes(?).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eleutherioteros Spartes (More free than Sparta): Because of their unrestrained and noble spirit; wherefore they did not surround themselves with walls, having been educated in their customs; but they were willing neither to retreat when defeated in battle nor were they ruled by tyrants.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Elephanta ek muias poiein (To make an elephant out of a fly): Of those who magnify the smallest things in speech and make a big deal out of them. Lucian in Praise of the Fly: “lest I seem, as the proverb has it, to make an elephant out of a fly.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Helos: A very damp thicket, or mud covered by a lot of water and deep undergrowth, either papyrus or reed, growing always out of the mud and standing up over the water.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Embaros eimi (I am weighty): Sensible, prudent. At first the Piraeus was an island, whence it received its name, from 'diaperan' (to cross); occupying whose headlands Mounychos established a shrine of Artemis Mounychia. When a she-bear appeared there and was done away with by the Athenians, a plague occurred, deliverance from which the god declared in an oracle [would take place] if ever someone sacrificed his daughter to the goddess. When Baros(?) alone undertook this because his family held the priesthood for life, having dressed up his daughter he hid her in the same place(?), and then dressing a goat in clothing like his daughter he sacrificed it. Whence this also became a proverb, and it is applied to those who are out of their minds and insane.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Empoinimos (Punishable): 'Empoinios,' that is liable to punishment, as in paying the penalty for things one has done wrong. And also called 'poine' is the punishment for a murder which has been committed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Endeixis (Indictment): A type of public lawsuit, under which they used to prosecute those barred in accordance with the laws either from certain places or certain activities, if they didn’t keep away from them. Demosthenes [mentions it] in Against Aristogeiton.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Endeixis (Indictment): If one, though he has been deprived of citizenship ('atimos') or condemned to pay a fine to the state but hasn’t paid it yet, attempts to hold office or serve on a jury, a volunteer citizen points him out; it is the same for someone who lays claim to activities or places forbidden by the laws, like someone who had prostituted himself and then [lays claim] to the marketplace and to speaking before the people, or even someone who unjustly speaks ill of the dead. Then for those convicted of these things the jurors set some penalty, [that is] what he must suffer or pay.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ialemoi (With ialemos): With lament, for 'ialemos' is a type of lament. And the son of Kalliope is called Ialemos. And ['ialemos' can mean] 'beautiful(?)' and 'orphaned.' Some [say it also means] 'ill-fated.' And frigid and worthless things are 'ialemode'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iainei (He warms): He cheers.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iacchos: Dionysus at the breast; and a certain hero and the song about him; and the day on which the festival [is held] for him. Some [say it can mean] ‘uproar’ as well.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iambizein (To iambize): To mock.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iambyke: A musical instrument. It is mentioned in various authors, and it is named this, so they say, because they used to sing iamboi to it. The sambuke is more recent and was invented later by a certain Sambykos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iambykai: Triangular musical instruments, to which they used to sing 'iamboi'. Some [say] ‘sambykai.’

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ianthe (He was warmed): He enjoyed, he was pleased, he was relaxed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iapyx: A gentle wind.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iater: Doctor ('iatros').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iache: A cry, a sound; or a lament.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ibis: A snake-eating bird.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ignue (Hamstring): The place under the knee, behind the knee.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idalimos (Causing sweat): Shapely.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idarnaioi: Prophets, after a certain prophet Idarnas; but some say after a Carian city. Kallistratos [says it means] eunuchs.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ideas (Shapes): Forms. In Alcibiades. From ‘idesthai’ (to see).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ideros: One who loves ('eron') at the same moment he sees ('idein').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiais dapanais (By personal expenses): By private expenses.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiasai (To be alone): To have one's own ideas.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idian (Personal): For 'private' [fem.]. Demosthenes in Against Konon. And 'idion' [masc.] means 'private' [masc.].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ide: Any overgrown hill.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiein:To sweat. And 'aniditi': Without sweating.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiateron (More private): More personal.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idioxenos: Personal friend.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idioxenos (Private guest-friend): One who is privately a guest-friend in his own right. But 'proxenos' is a guest-friend of an entire city, with whom ambassadors stay; and he brings the embassies before public officials, and administers everything else and takes care of things in his city that are different from those in the city for which he is proxenos. Doryxenos is one who has become someone’s guest-friend because of war. Astoxenos is one is descended from citizen ancestors, but is himself a foreigner and in need of restoration, like Agamemnon in Lydia.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Idiopragei: He does his own thing, he keeps quiet.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiera hodos (Sacred Way): Which the initiates travel from the city to Eleusis.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theegoroi: Those who talk of gods.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Text: Theelatos (Sent by god): Having been sent by a god.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theia (Divine): Straight and upright and wonderful.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theiazonton (Of those being inspired): Of those who are mad.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thiasotai (Fellow revelers): Choral dancers, those singing the divine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierophantes: Mystery initiator, priest.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierophantes: He says that the first hierophant was named so who displayed the sacred things upon coming back(?) from war.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierophonon(?) (Of sacred voices): Of great voices.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieroi (By sacred): By divine; or, by big.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierosthai (To have been consecrated): Thucydides says, “having considered them to have been consecrated while they were not pure because of an ancient guilt.” For it denotes ‘to have been considered holy’ and as it were ‘to have been made sacred.’

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiesthen (They were both eager): They exerted themselves, they went for.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hietai (He is eager): He exerts himself, he goes for.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hizei: He seats or he sits.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiesin:He lets go.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithagenes: Autocthonous, legitimate.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Itheos: Straight.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithi: Come or go [imperatives].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithmata (Steps): Footsteps, paces, duties, impulses.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hipparchos: A tyrant of Eretria. And [there was] another Hipparchos, the son of Peisistratos. And another Hipparchos, son of Charmos, who was a kinsman of Peisistratos the tyrant and was the first to undergo ostracism through the suspicion of Peisistratos, because when he was a demagogue and general he established a tyranny. And another Hipparchos is an actor, whom Demosthenes mentions. ‘Hipparchos’ is also said by the Athenians for ‘the leader of the cavalry’; there were two of these.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippeas eis pedion prokalei (He calls the cavalry into the field): Obviously to wherever one is excelling; for cavalry dominate in the field. Plato used it against Theaetetus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ito: Let him come, let him go.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iygai (Shrieks): Women's cries, laments.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iynges: Narrow paths. And delights.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iynx: Daughter of Echo or Peitho (Persuasion), sacred to Nike(?) and Aphrodite. After she bewitched Zeus over Io, she was turned to stone by Hera. By some she is called ‘kinaidion.’ There is also a certain device called ‘iynx,’ which witches used to spin as if [by spinning them] they were summoning back their beloveds. There is also a certain bird, which is thought to possess the same power, wherefore they bind [them] to the little wheels.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iynx: That which draws the mind toward desire and love.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iphthimos: Strong.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iphi (By force): Strongly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iphikratides: Towels; it's a kind of shoe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iphyon: A certain wild vegetable.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichthyokentron: The trident, since they use it for big fish.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichthyoulkos kai ichthyoboleus (Angler and spear-fisherman): Fisherman.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichthyopris (Fish cooker): Grill. [This is for big fish.]

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichneutai: Trackers.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichnelatesai: To search [something] by its tracks.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ichnos: Path, way, step.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Iokas (Pursuits): Rushes, chases.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: ION: Of missiles, or 'having gone.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ion: Poet of tragedy, Chian by descent.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionia: A meadow of violets.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionia: Prostitute's name.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionidai: A deme of the tribe Aigeis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ioros: Door-warden, guard.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Katalogos (Catalogue): The register of those supposed to serve on campaign. Also their enumeration.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naukratian (Naval victory): Andocides in Symbouleutikos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naulochion en to meso (Haven in the middle): Aristophanes in Babylonians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naulochei (Lies in wait): Is arranged in the ship.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naulochon (A safe haven): Fine weather, in which ships lie in ambush, or rest.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naumacha (For a sea battle): Long spears, in order to fight from ships.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naumacheseiontes (Wishing to fight by sea): Being prepared for a sea battle.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nausipodes (Ship-footed): Islanders.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nemesis (Distribution of what is due): Blame, justice, hybris, jealousy, fortune.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nemeseis hypokriton (Allocation of actors): The poets used to receive three actors allocated by lot to act in their plays, of whom the winner was invited without test to the following year. Thus it is like distributions.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nymphai: The winged ants and the grubs in gardens.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pylagoros: The speaker sent from the cities to the Amphictyony, in order to speak there. 'Pylagoros' from speaking ('agoreuein') in the Pylaia; the Amphiktyonic council was the Pylaia. There were three 'pylagoroi'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hypoderis (Necklace): A woman's adornment, as in a necklace.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abrokomas: A proper name. And he was a satrap of Artaxerxes the king of the Persians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habros (Dainty): Radiant, luxurious, soft.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habrosyne (Daintyness): Brilliance.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habrotemon (Erring): Erroneous.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habroteti (With daintiness): With luxury, with softness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abroton (Without men): Inanimate, insensate.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habrochiton (Wearing a dainty tunic): One who wears dainty things.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habrynetai (Lives daintily): Embellishes oneself, is wanton, vaunts oneself.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abrotos (Not eating): He who is not eating.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathos daimon (Good spirit): Aristophanes: "A good spirit and good deliverance".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antipeponthotos (Contrarily): Adversely, in an opposing manner.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antitoresas: Having bored right through, having dug through a wall.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antitypesai (To resist): To be opposed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antitypia (Resistance): Opposition, hardness. It is also taken as applying to likeness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkmaionidai (Alcmaeonids): It is a distinguished family at Athens [named] after Alkman.
Notes: In previous submission, I (Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>) introduced a mistake; hereby corrected.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphos (Leprosy): The certain white variegation on the skin with certain light marks, and it is called 'white leprosy', but the blackish one is also called 'black leprosy'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphous (Leprosies): White [masc.] or white [fem.].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halo(?) (Threshing floor): For 'salts'(?). Philyllios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haloi (Be caught): Be hard pressed, be condemned.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haloa: ... on the fifth of waning Posideon.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Alphitochrotos (Barley meal colored): White. Applying to greyness of hair [lit. 'head']. Aristophanes in Telmessians.
Translation: Alphitochrotos (Barley meal colored): White. Applying to greyness of hair [lit. 'head']. Aristophanes in Telmessians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphiteis (Barley millers): Those who make barley meal. Hypereides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alphiton stoa (Barley meal's stoa): The one where barley meal is sold, in which also Zeuxis' Helen used to be set up.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopochrous (Fox colored): Grey haired.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halonetos (Bought with salt): As it were barbarian; for the Thracians used to sell slaves for salt.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halonai (To be caught): To be seized, to be bound together.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopex dorodokeitai (A fox takes bribes): Applying to those easily caught for [taking] bribes. Kratinos in Nomoi, "Each one of you is a fox taking bribes".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopex ton boun elaunei (A fox drives out the bull): It is deployed applying to things that turn out not according to reason.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopekethen (From Alopeke): Alopeke is a deme of the tribe Antiochis, and its demesman is an Alopekeus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alogiou dike (Suit for failure to produce accounts): Which magistrates were accused of when they had not rendered account of the sums administered in their term of office.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akeanoi: The round parts on lentils and pulse that are hard to cut.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigos tropon (Goat's manner): Applying to those who bring evil upon themselves. After a Corinthian expression, "The she-goat providing the blade". For so it is said. For when Corinthians were sacrificing to Hera Akraia, whom Medea is said to have founded, those who had been hired for furnishing, having hidden the blade in the ground, were alleging that they had forgotten, but the she-goat scraped it up with her feet. But others say that at Korinth after the sacrifice to the children of Medea they hide the blade, but that in the subsequent year the victim that is about to be sacrificed in turn digs up the blade with its horns.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigilips (Goatless): A lofty rock, so that even goats fall short of setting foot upon it. There is also a city in Kephallenia so called.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigides (Goatskins): Nets [made] of garlands, as Lykourgos and Herodotos [said]. But Nymphodoros says that these were called 'aigeiai' (goat skins) by Libyans.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigilieus: Aigilia is a deme of the tribe Antiochis, whose demesman is an Aigilieus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athenai ton ailouron (The cat to Athena): The expression was said applying to those who badly compare better things to worse, owing to trivial similarity, as if one should compare the cat to Athena owing to greyness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Azenieus (Azenian): Azenia is a deme of the tribe Hippothoontis, the tribesman from which is Azenian.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Azesia: So Demeter is called in Sophokles. But others [call her] 'eutraphes' (well-fed).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Azen: The beard, among Phrygians, is called [this]. The word belongs to Herodian.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Azein (To sigh): To groan. Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adiaulos topos (Place with no return): Whence it is not possible to go back. So Euripides.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thraniou: A stool.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thrattein (To trouble): To stir, to trouble, to impinge, to disturb, to abash and to suspect.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thrauetai (He is shattered): He is broken.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Threia: A deme of Oeneis.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Threktos: A race-course.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thremmata (Animals): Herds.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thria: The leaves of the fig tree.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thriai: The oracular pebbles.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thriasion pedion (Thrian plain):

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thrinkos (Fence): An enclosure, a brim, a small wall, enclosing wall.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achaia (of Achaea): An epithet of Demeter. The first [syllable] is short. From 'achos' (pain) rather than from 'ache' (sound). Aristophanes in The Acharnians says "he would not easily have suffered the Achaian herself."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achaioi (Achaeans): The Greeks. So the poet calls all of the Greeks. But, strictly, Achaeans are those who inhabit a certain part of the Peloponnese, which is called 'Achaea.' Also those who inhabit Phthian Achaea marshalled by Achilles, after whom all the Myrmidons are called 'Achaeans' by Homer.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achaneis (Gaping): Unseen, invisible for lack of light.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharis (Without grace): Something in which grace is not present.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharistia (Ungraciousness): The negative form of grace.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achthetai (He is vexed): He is grieved.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geneteiran (Mother): Mother, poetically.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gennikos: Nobly.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genete (The hour of birth): Ancestral or related to a birthday.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genus (Jaws): Chins.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agesilaos: A proper name. He was a distinguished and noble king of the Spartans, and is celebrated in many of the orators.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglauros: The daughter of Kekrops. It is also an eponym of Athena.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agleukesteron (Rather unsweet): For 'rather unpleasant'. Xenophon in Hieron.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoren (Agora): Assembly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoretai (Speakers): Counsellors, wise men.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Genoustes: As in, parent or kinsman or descendant. It is better to understand the last [meaning].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adikiou (For wrongdoing): A type of lawsuit in Athens, so called. Some say that the fine assigned for the wrongdoing is 'adikion'. For Cleidemus, too, in the first book of the Atthides writes thus: "For when a disease arose among the Aeginetans, the wrong was disclosed to them when they consulted the oracle and the penalty ('adikion') was pronounced for it".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adoleschein (To talk idly): Denotes philosophizing about both nature and everything, while chattering away. The old comic poets, however used to say that to dialogue was 'to chatter'. Also, the spots, convening at which they used to pass the day in speech, were 'chats' (leschai).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aeinos glossa' (ever-flowing speech) and 'aeinos phone' (ever-flowing sound) and 'orge' (anger) and 'epithymia' (passion), and use them for similar things. Cratinus: "and he gave you to convey among the people a speech of fine, ever-flowing words, by which you set everything in motion when you speak". And you will also say 'ever-flowing river' and 'ever-flowing spring', given that inside the word lies 'naein', that is, 'to flow'. Flowing is proper to water. But the phrase 'glotta aeinos' is altogether novel ('kainon') and is pronounced prominently for speaking distinctively.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geouchos (Landowner): He who holds the land.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geras (Gift): Recompense, honors, repayments.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geraios (Reverend): Honored.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Consider "'Atharê' (porridge) and 'athêra' and 'athera' and 'athara' they say are the same thing. Porridge is a meal made of wheat that has been boiled and liquefied just as 'etnos' (a soup). It differs from 'etnos' in that, soup is prepared from beans or peas or simply any kind of mashed legume, but porridge, as has been said, is prepared from wheat that has been boiled and liquified. And usage of the word is frequent among the Attic [writers], sometimes preferred with the eta on the end, and the alpha in the middle, but according to many others with the alpha on the end and the eta in the middle. So both Hellanicus and Sophron employed it. But they also lengthen the alpha, as if the word had been changed from 'athêra'. But perhaps, they say, the word was at first 'athera' with the epsilon, namely the food refined from chaff and boiled from wheat, but later the epsilon was lengthened to eta, just as [the lengthening of] 'ethos' to 'êthos'. And while 'athera' has become 'athara' in Doric, those who say 'atharê' are speaking Ionic. For in fact they also employed other Ionic words on account of their kinship of old, always saying 'esêmênamên' (we denoted) and 'sêmênamenos' (denoted). As a result, the word 'atharê' as said by the Attic writers kept its penult according to the Doric dialect, but its ultima according to the Ionic.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ai (Alas!): With smooth breathing and circumflex it denotes ‘would that’, by way of apocope for ‘aithe’ (would that), but with rough breathing it is the feminine article and relative pronoun. But it also denotes an adverb expressing grief when it has circumflex and smooth breathing, which is also doubled: “ai ai, miserable one."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Haimati klaiein (To weep with blood): An expression. So the ancients say, applying to those who do everything and cannot persuade anyone.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hairetizein (To choose): Those who speak earnestly about something. This [appears] often in the later comic poets.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Airein exo poda pelou (To lift one's foot up out of the mud): An expression applied to those who are unwilling to be in the thick of business/troubles. Also said: "To lift one's foot up out of the blame".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ethysas, antithysei (You sacrificed, you should sacrifice in turn): This is in Philoxenus. The Cyclops says [this] to Odysseus; for they misinterpreted the words “then kindling fire we sacrificed,” to have been said about the sheep, but not to mean 'we offered votive sacrifice(?).'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ei me pater estha (If you weren’t my father): From Sophocles’ Antigone. It is said as an abbreviated proverb, instead of ‘I would say you’re not sane.’

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eisangelia (Impeachment): Delatoria ([Latin]: Informing). 'Eisangelia' and 'graphe' are different. 'Eisangelia' is for large public crimes, 'graphe' for small ones. And properly 'graphe' is for those proposing illegal measures.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ek pantos xylou (From every piece of wood): It leaves out 'a yoke could be made.' It is said of things that are contemptible to behold, but which are necessary. Others [say] it is [said] of things which bear the appearance of good things, but which are found to be otherwise.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Elaphrotatous (Lightest): The ancients say the word in praise, for 'most mild,' the opposite of 'most severe' and 'most vulgar.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eleusinia: They used to give a prize to those who won the Eleusinia. The city was named after Eleusinos son of Hermes; others say there is a different reason and that only the festival is called Eleusinia.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hellanodikai (Olympic Judges): At first the Eleans established a single Hellanodikes, then two, and finally nine. Aristodemos the Elean [says] that the Hellanodikai who finally held the games were ten, one from each tribe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: En de dichostasie kai Androklees polemarchei (In a civil war even Androkles is a polemarch): Of worthless people who through some reversal become worthy of honor. Such is also the [expression] that says: “for in desperate circumstances even Karkinos earned honor.” “In civil war even the worst man earned honor.” “For even among(?) the unlearned the lark still sings.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hendeka (Eleven): These were magistrates chosen by lot, in charge of the prison, and, receiving wrongdoers who were hauled in for [punishment by] death, they would punish [them]; but those who disputed [the charges against them] they would introduce to a lawcourt and would execute its decision concerning them. They would also introduce [cases concerning] land and house that were declared by 'apographe' and grant to the citizens(?) property that seemed to be public. They also used to introduce some indictments.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zabron: Eating to excess.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zaeira(?): A garment worn about the shoulders.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zaes (Stormy, strong): Great, much, bright; or strong.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zaen anemon (Stormy wind): One that blows fiercely.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zambyke: A musical instrument.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zaploutos: Extremely rich.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zatosai: To suspect.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zea: A harbor at Athens.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeila: [So] The Thracians [call] wine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeira (Garment): Or ‘seira’ (cord), as some [say]. Or a certain garment that they put on after their tunics just like cloaks.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeira: It is a kind of belt.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeiros: A kind of garment.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agraphiou dike (Suit for lack of registration): Those who at the time administer these things record the names of those who as a result of a judgment owe [money] to the treasury on boards, including for how much the debt is. Whenever each person repays the annotation is removed from the board. If, then, someone had been written up as owing, and seemed not to have repaid, and his name was erased from the board, it was permitted to him among the citizens who wished to introduce the 'dike agraphiou' against him.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abythos phlyaria (Bottomless nonsense): Great [nonsense].
Notes: [Suda α 101](suda:alpha;101) (Ἄβυδος) includes, in a longer entry, "καὶ Ἄβυδον φλυαρίαν, τὴν πολλήν."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agatha (Goods): Xenophon used the word applying to food and drink that conduce to enjoyment and cheer.
Notes: First half of [Suda α 108](suda:alpha;108) (Ἀγαθά) has same.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phyle: Isokrates in On the Peace. Phyle [=> Φυλὴ] is a deme of the tribe Oineis. Menander considers Phyle to be a place, but Philochoros says that it is a fort.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Naides (Naiads): Streams or nymphs that dwell by streams.
Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>, Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nais (Nais): A certain courtesan whom Lysias and Aristophanes mention.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nai tan (Yes [by] the): They used to swear thus.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakinklison (Wag the tail!): Shake!

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakekoptai (Has been cut through): As in 'is unapproved'; for the ancients used to cut through unapproved money.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakechloidenai: To be enervated.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diaklon (breaking in two): Breaking in pieces.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diaknaiomenos (Being grated): Being scraped or being grieved.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diaknaiousi (They grate): They destroy.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakokko: The between time. Pherecrates.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakomistheis (Being carried over): Passing through.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeidoron (Life-giving): Giving things conducive to living.
Notes:
Photios ζ 16 = [Suda ζ 44](suda:zeta;44).
Edited by Joshua D. Sosin

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeugision: The tax which a ‘zeugites’ used to pay. There were three(?) classes in Athens. ‘Pentakosiomedimnoi’ (500-bushel men), knights, those paying the knight tax...also the thetic tax. The richest people used to be called the ‘pentakosiomedimnoi’.
Notes:
See also [Suda ζ 31](suda:zeta;31).
Edited by Matthew Farmer .

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageirei (Gathers): Brings together.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agerochia: Arrogance.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agerochos (High-minded): Honored, manly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agerochos (Arrogant): Bull(?), proud, disdainful, rash.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agetai (One believes): To hold and to suppose.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageustos thoines (Without a taste of food): Keeping away from urbane(?) lifestyle..

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageustos thoines (Without a taste of food) and simply 'without a taste of this', one must say.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageustoi (Without a taste): Without experience.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agema (Division): The king's advancing unit of elephants and cavalry and inantry. But others [say that it is] the best of the Macedonian force.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagiasate (Make sacred!): Prepare!, proclaim!

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agraphiou (For lack of registration): It is a type of suit against those who owe the treasury and are registered so that they owe, but have been erased before repaying. Sometimes it is applied also against those who register those who do not owe. He who has done this and is caught used to be registered himself as owing, but he who was registered inappropriately would be released from the unjust registration.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrios elaios (Wild olive): What the masses call wild-olive. It is in Pindar in Hymns.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroikein (To live in the country): Also 'agroikon' (rustics): the temperate. The verb 'agroikein' is from 'agroikos'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroikoi (Rustics): A class at Athens, which was distinct compared to the eupatrids. Another was that of the farmers. And that of the craftsmen was third.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroikos (Rustic): Hard, used to unsheltered life, as in, a workman.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroilethen (From Agroile): Agroile is a deme of the tribe Erechtheis, and its demesman in past used to be called an Agroileus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agronomoi (Country-dwellers): Those who abide in the country.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agrotas: Rustics.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aguiatides: In Euripides, altars that are in front of gates.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ademonion (Being troubled): Struggling.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aderitos (Without strife): Without battle.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adephagos (Greedy): Eating all at once, much-eating, gluttonous.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adeneos (Without premeditation): Simply and without taking pains, by negation of 'denea' (plans) and cares.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athērēs (Reckless): Perhaps someone who is unyielding (ateires), or excessively reaping (theristikos). Aeschylus in Agamemnon(?): "Laid over solid(?) stretched bronze of a shield." Or someone who is famous, or admired (athroumenos) on account of fame. Or it is someone who makes light (atherizon) of things, and takes no account of anything/anyone due to his hardness. Or one who is sharp, from 'spines' (atheras).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ather (Barb): Tip/edge of a sharpened tool, by metaphor from the spike (ather), which is the uppermost and finest part of an ear of corn. And the tip of a spear is also called an 'ather'. But wheat is also called 'ather', as Euripides in Stheneboia: "I strike into the throats of the Chimaera, but a spear of flame hits me and scorches his thick wing".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aigaleos: A mountain in Attica opposite Salamis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aidein (To sing): Attic [writers] say it applying to roosters, and do not say 'kokkyzein' (to crow) except when mocking some foreigner. And it also means 'to say' and 'to call'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amnesteutos gyne (Unwooed woman): Concubine. Euripides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amnoi tous tropous (Lambs in manners): Mild and soft.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ampotis (Ebb): Desiccation or inundation. And Attic [writers] rather say 'anaposis'. But in a special sense 'ampotides' are the narrow conditions that occur by the sea, as in the ebbing and flooding of the surf. And 'anaposis' (drinking-up) as well is called 'ampotis'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anabalou (Throw it up): The Attics pronounce it with a circumflex.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anagnosai (To persuade): To convince. Attic and Ionic [writers use it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anaptesikeros: Kite [bird] in Attic.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Andrachle (Purslane): Attic [writers pronounce it] with a lambda instead of a ny. Sophocles: "It was lit with fresh branches of purslane".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anergeto ex hypnou (Roused from sleep): This is exceptionally Attic, in Sophocles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antephilotimounto (They were moved by jealousy): For 'hemillonto' (they were contending) and 'erizon' (they were quarrelling) and 'antegonizonto' (they were at odds). And this word 'antephilotimeisthai' belongs to the first conjugation pronounced with a circumflex, and only that one. But there are some verbs which are found to belong to two conjugations, such as 'skeno' (I camp) 'skenois' and 'skeneis', and 'atolmo' (I lose heart) 'atolmeis' and 'atolmois'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiprokleseis (Counter-challenges): Disputes, counter-claims.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antipherontai: They set themselves against.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiphilotimei (Shows public spirit in return): Takes care in turn.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiphes (You contradict): for 'antilegeis' (you speak against).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antomenoi (Meeting): Coming together.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antra nychia (Dark-as-night caves): Dark caverns.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antrode (Cave-like): Cavern-like.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antrones: A city in Thessaly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antronios onos (Antronian ass): Big, as very big ones are in Antron.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antyges (Rails): Edges.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antyx (Rail): The edge of a chariot.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antopei (Looks in the face): Looks in the eye.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antopos (Facing): Looking in the face.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anydreusasthai: To draw up water; "pour out on her and draw up the vessel." Pherecrates in Corianno.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anydra dapeda (Waterless lands): About Libya the tragic poet says, "the ram-faced lord Ammon having inhabited waterless lands foretells these things."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeidoron (Life-giving): Giving things [=> τὰ] conducive to living.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zesas thymoi (Seething with passion): Having been inflamed in the soul.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Zetna: The word is Phrygian. It signifies 'gate'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thatton e Boutes (More quickly than Boutes): As in 'it was rendered [more quickly than Boutes was rendered].' For Micon the painter, having made the eye and the helmet visible, labeled [the picture] “Boutes.”
Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>, Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierato (Let him be a priest): Let him conduct rites ('orgiazeto') according to custom and make sacrifice; for sacrificers [were called] 'orgeones.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiera trieres (Sacred Trireme): The Paralos could be called [this].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiereias enypnion (Priestess’ dream): Some say that it should instead be said 'Himeraia’s dream.' Himeraia was a certain old woman, they say, who thought that she saw herself being led up into the heavens; and then when she reached the house of Zeus, she saw a red-haired man bound with an iron chain below the royal throne; asking who he was, she heard “the destroyer of Sicily.” Therein lies the dream; but at a later time when she saw Dionysius ruling as tyrant she narrated the dream to many people and proclaimed that he was the one she had seen; and growing angry with her Dionysius killed her.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiereusen: He sacrificed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippia Athena: They say that she is the daughter of Poseidon and Polyphe(?) the daughter of Okeanos. As the first to invent the chariot she was therefore called 'Hippia' (Equine).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Isai psephoi (Equal votes): The law that the accused is released if he obtains equal votes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoteles kai isoteleia (Equal-taxed and Equal taxation): Often a certain honor used to be given to those of the metics who seemed worthy, according to which there was a release from their(?) metic-tax. That the 'isoteleis' had a release also from the other things that metics did(?) Theophrastus says. And Athenians decreed tax-free status for entire cities, such as the Olynthians and Thebans. And the 'isoteles' used to pay a certain set tax.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Lykos aeton pheugei (A wolf flees an eagle): An expression; applied to inescapable things.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Lykos echanen (A wolf gapes): An expression; and they say that the wolf, whenever it wishes to carry something off, stands next to it gaping; so, whenever it does not catch what it prefers, they say that it gaped emptily. They say [it] applying to those who hope to make deals with each other, but fail. Aristophanes in Thesmophoriazousai II.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Melampygou tyches (Should you happen upon the black-bottomed one): The black-bottomed(?) were braggart sons of Limnai. And since they were being very licentious the mother said to be careful, lest ever they fall upon the shaggy-assed [man]. Thus having fallen upon Heracles, they were bound to a pole. Then, when he saw them laughing and bending down, he asked the reason. And they said that it was the saying of their mother, "that we would fall upon the shaggy-assed"; and laughing, Heracles freed them from the bonds.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Metoikion (Metic tax): A metic is one who moved house from one city to another, and not staying for a short time like a foriegner. Twelve drachmas used to be paid by them each year, which was named 'metoikion'. Isaeus in Against Elpagoras and Demophanes indicates that a man used to pay twelve drachmas for 'metoikion', but a woman six. And that the mother of a son who paid would not pay. But when he wasn't paying, she would pay. Slaves once freed by their masters used to pay the 'metoikion'. Menander says that in addition to the twelve drachmas these paid also a triobol, perhaps to the tax-collector. However, metics not paying the 'metoikion' used to be hauled before the citizens. And if they were convicted, they were sold. They also used to put the metics on [war]ships, as Demosthenes shows in the Philippics. And the comic poets used to call the metics "bowl-men," since in the processions these used to carry the bowls.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Metronomoi (Inspectors of measurements): A certain office at Athens was that [=>ἡ] of the 'metronomoi'. They were ten in number. Five in the Piraeus and nine(?) in the city. And they took care that the measurments of the sellers were just.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Mia xelidon (One swallow): This is proverbial, that 'one swallow does not make spring.' It aims to say somehow: One day does not allow a wise man to make an inroad on perfection and one miserable day [does not allow] a wise man [to make an inroad] on stupidity. And Aristotle the philosopher has mentioned this in Ethics.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>, Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Misete (Hated): They used to call a debased woman ‘hated’ For ‘misos’ (hate) is not far from ‘miainesthai’ (to be defiled). For what is hated is left alone and is unmixed (‘amiges’), as if some woman being ‘unmingled’ (amisgetes), which is also better. Also what is said in the category of a proverb, “Hated is a woman  who is thick at the ankle”, seems to have been said as such. Also Kratinos said this somewhere: “Hated women use dildoes”. But he calls the man who is simply hated ‘insufficient’; but metaphorically the word is applied also to a woman who is insatiate when it comes to food
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>, Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Mousaios: Lysias in Response to the Indictment of Mixidemos, if genuine: "and he has two slave boys, the one of whom this man calls Mousaios, and the other Hesiod." It is clear that the man being tried took care to call the house-slaves this. But regarding Mousaios, some say that the man was from Thrace, and others that he was a native from Eleusis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Mochtheros (Wretched): Painful or toilsome or bad. Also 'mochxtheria' has been applied to wickedness. So Dinarchus. But Antiphon, the most ancient of the orators, did not use 'mochtheros' applying to a man when he was bad and being led into court so as to be prosecuted, but he assigned 'mochtheros' to a father when he brought a suit on behalf of his slaughtered son. And this one says in Proems and Perorations, "and I, poor wretch, who ought to be dead, live a laughing stock to my enemies."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abyrbelon: Shameful, hated, great, in vain. But others [say that it means] hairy and vulgar.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathes Tyches neos (Temple of Good Fortune): The meaning is not unclear.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathoi d' aridakryes andres (Good are very tearful men): Applied to those who are very inclined to pity.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agamai toutou, agamai kerameion (I wonder at this, I wonder at pottery): Eupolis and Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoraios Hermes (Market Hermes): In Athens he had been established by the market.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aliterioi: Sinning. They used to be called 'aliterioi' from this. Once a famine took hold of the Athenians. Therefore certain people were seizing the ground ('aloumena') barley meal. After those people, at any rate, they call troublesome people 'aliterioi'. Also another way: 'Aliterios' is said because a famine happened in Athens, and the poor were plundering the wheat meal of the grinders ('alounton'). And those observing the grinders and plundering were called 'aliterioi.' The name extended also to those doing anything with force from the famine that took place during the Aitolian War. It is also derived from 'alitrainein', which is 'to do wrong.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopon: Not scutched.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hamaxa ton boun elaunei (A wagon is driving the ox): A saying.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apaideutoi (Uneducated): For 'senseless' (anoetoi).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apadotribetoi: Untrained.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapan (Entire): The Ionic [writers] and the Poet [Homer] pronounce it short: "And the entire (hapan) field was full of them." But the Attic [writers] lengthen the second syllable. And likewise 'parapan' (altogether), and all the words of this sort.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aparti (Completely): Among the Attic [writers] this is [pronounced] oxytone. And it denotes being completed. Eupolis and Herodotus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aparti: Completely, exactly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: "The woman 'left' the man" is said, but "The man 'sent away; the woman". So Menander.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apious (Pear-trees): Plato said it in Laws, and it is also in Alexis. The Attic [writers use it] in the feminine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Arabios auletes (An Arabian flute-player): Applied to incessant people. Cantharus, in Medea: "You stirred up this choros [like] an Arabian citharist". And the proverb: "An Arabian flute-player plays for one drachma, but stops for four".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Argeious horo (I see Argives): It is proverbial. Philonides [says it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Artyein (To make ready): To make ready.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Artyen (He was arranging): He was reigning.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Arystichous (Little cups): Wine ladles and small cups.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphya es pyr (Anchovy into fire): The expression is used for those who suffer a quick end, insofar as it happens that the anchovy is also boiled very quickly.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Achileos kai Peleos (Achilles and Peleus): The other Greeks besides the Attic [spell it] with the omicron, but the Attic writers [spell it] with the omega. But the Ionians use the change from epsilon to eta, saying 'Pelēos' and 'Achillēos.' And Homer  with the epsilon: "You are sleeping, son of Atreus".
