But they also say the genitives sometimes with -ōs, for example, also Hecataeus says at one point "Kretheōs" and "Atreōs", similarly to the Attic writers. Also the other Ionic forms with the omicron, as in 'physios', 'lexios', 'polios'."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Geraios (Reverend): Honored.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerairein (To revere): To honor, to extol.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Geraiai (Revered women): The women consecrated to Dionysus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerania: A mountain of the Megarid.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Geraron (Majestic): Honored or elder.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerdios: Weaver.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gergides: The heads of garlic.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerenios (From Gerena): Honored old man.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Geren: Female crane.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerousia kai gerontes (Council of Elders and elders): In Lacedaimon, there were 28 magistrates, who from an early age until old age used to testify to having lived well. And these men were the greatest magistracy after the ephors.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>, John-Paul Smith-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>, Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abaris: A proper name. For, when a plague, they say, had arisen throughout the whole inhabited world, Apollo responded to both Greeks and barbarians, when they asked, that the Athenian people was to make prayers on behalf of all. And when many nations were sending embassies to them, they say that Abaris also came, an ambassador from the Hyperboreans. But the time in which he was present is disputed. For Hippostratos says that he was present in the third Olympiad, while Pindar [says that it was] in the time of Kroisos, king of the Lydians, and others [that it was] in the 21st Olympiad.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Abioton (Unlivable): Bad, disagreeable, painful, not worthy of living. “For,” [someone] says, “[someone] made life unlivable for him.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathestate (O most excellent man): Euripides(?) said [it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathe Tyche: Nemesis (Retribution) and Themis (Justice).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agatharchos: This too is a proper [name]. And he was a distinguished painter, son of Eudemos, and Samian by descent.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathoneios aulesis (Agathonian flute-playing): Effeminate [flute-playing]. For the tragic poet Agathon was reproached for effeminacy.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathos (Well): Vehemently.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agaion (Enviable): Liable to envy. But others [say] 'marvellous', and others, 'jealous'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agallei (Exalts): Does, prepares, adorns, honors, offers prayers.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalmatophoroumenos: Carrying images or impressions of perceptions in one's mind. So Philon used it.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aggeliaphoros (Message carrier): Ambassador.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Angele: A deme of [the tribe] Pandionis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agein: For 'to have'. Hypereides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aguieus: The cone-shaped column in front of the courtyard gates, sacred to Apollo, and the god himself. Pherekrates in Krapatoloi: "Lord Aguieus, bear this in mind for me". Also "to fill Aguias with smoke" indicates the columns ('aguieas') by contraction, not the streets ('aguias') and ways.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allothroous: Speaking a foreign tongue.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allokoton: Strange, opposite, foreign, abnormal in shape, special, incoherent, alien. Plato also said 'allokototaton' and 'allokototeron,' and Pherekrates 'allokotos' as an adverb.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alloprosallos (Fickle): Easily changed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allotriognomos (Thinking of other things): [The word] indicates the man having the things of others in mind and not his own.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allotrios (Unfavorably): In a hostile fashion.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allos (Differently): In vain. Or, especially. Or, in a different way.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allos te (And otherwise): Especially.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allo heteron (Some other): They say [this] pleonastically. Menander in the Methe: "Then he used to not have fire, or stone, or any other thing at all." Krates in the Paidiai: "In all the tragedies this is some other holy word." 'Allos' [is here] unnecessarily.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allos houtos Herakles (This other Heracles): First said proverbially applied to Theseus, or to the Herakles who was one of the Idaian Daktyloi, or to the son of Alkmene because of the older ones.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allophasis: A turbulent noise.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allophasein (To be delirious): To be discolored, to overlook.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allophasein (To be delirious): To not bear a weight.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Allophatois (Slain by others/appearing differently): Having been mentioned by others, as in 'aneremenois' (having been slain/answered).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halma: A leap.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halmades (Brine-soaked): Pickled olives.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aloasanta (Having threshed): With the alpha, Pherekrates in the Ipnos: "after threshing to put [it] out straightaway for the beasts of burden." And 'aloesai' with the eta is 'to wear out with blows.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halonnesos: A small island in the Aegean Sea.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alope: Daughter of Kerkyon, from whom [was born] also Hippothoon son of Poseidon, who gave his name to the tribe Hippothoontis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halosydnes: Of one born in the sea. Heliodoros explained it as 'of the sea.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alourga (Sea-wrought): Sea-purple.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alourgika (Sea-purple things): Threads and fine things dyed purple.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halourgis: A purple robe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halourgopolike: So called 'porphyropolike' (purple-trade). Thus Isaios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alybas: A lake is called [this] among the Hyperboreans.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alyktein:To be in distress.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alys (Agitation): Distraction and tossing about. Also 'alyein,' to do nothing. "Why don't you do the best thing? But he does nothing, lying down long ago." Menander in the Epitrepontes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alysiteles (Unprofitable): Inconvenient.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halysion: A little chain or necklace. Menander: "Let him/her give you some little chain to go around your neck."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alyskazein (To shun): To slip out through and to run away. Or to go around and to turn away.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alpha: A cow’s head used to be called this by Phoenicians. Also Moses the lawgiver used to be called so by the Jews owing to the fact that he had much dull-white leprosy ('alphous') on his body. But also Nikarchos son of Ammonios talks this nonsense in On Jews. Also the pig that struck Adonis used to be called ‘alpha’. So was it called by the Asbotians in Phoenicia. Among Phoenicians the rough and wild man used to be called ‘alpha’. Also Osiris is called ‘alpha’ by Byblians, but also scarcely.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amazonion: A temple that Amazons founded. So Isaios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amathias hypsos (Height of ignorance): The expression is well-known and suited to prose. Plato used it in his Letters.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amathia (Ignorance): For 'anaisthesia' (insensibility). Plato.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amathes (Ignorant): For 'apaideutos' (uneducated) and 'akosmetos' (unarranged). Plato. It is also applied to a dull person and one not having learned but knowing by nature.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amaimaketon: Irresistible.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amaltheias bios (The life of Amaltheia): One that is comfortable and blessed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halosima: Easily taken.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Halotoi: Taken, subdued.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alopekeos: A type of vine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hama: At the same time. Also, from different places to one place. Also, to one and the same place.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amergein (To pluck): To gather fruit. Aristophanes, in the Islands: "Someone would be gathering grapes and the other plucking olives."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkmaion(?): Of strong, of manly, of noble people.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Apheis ten hyperan ton poda diokei (Having released the brace, he pursues the sheet): Expression in Hyperides applying to those who, having left more important things, are wasting time with trivial things. And 'hyperai' (braces) are nautical ropes, by which the sailyard is moved from one side to another.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerousion: Honored.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gerrhoin (With screens): From a fence, says Eupolis. And Demosthenes, "They set the 'gerrha' (screens) on fire". Also places that are fenced around. Also Persian shields of wicker.
Notes: Edited by David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>, Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achenia (Want): Being at a loss, poverty. Aristophanes in Amphiaraus: "casting into need." It is said by way of negation of 'echein' (to have). From the 'echo' (I have) comes 'aechen' (poor), 'achen' (needy), and 'achenia'. Others say it comes from sounding empty. And poor men are also said to be 'achenes' (needy).

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geophaneion: A place in which there is a mine.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geopeinai (Poor in land): Having little and <miserable> land.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Boucheta: It is a city in Epirus, said in the neuter and the plural, which Philochoros(?) says was named owing to the fact that Themis went there riding a bull ('boos') following Deukalion's flood.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gethya (Horn onions): Some type of leek. Something similar to a wild leek. Thus Aristophanes.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gepeda (Plots of ground): Sites of houses.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achilleioi: Certain types of barley were called this at Athens, because they are both stout and unwavering. They also used to call the costly sponges 'Achilleioi.'

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gepeda (Plots of ground): Sites of houses.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achne (Froth): the finest part of the water, the foam of the sea.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Gepedon (Plot of ground): A place. Just like the site of a house, that which joins land with houses.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Geteia (Horn onions): Some type of onion.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Giglismos (Tickling): Giggling, laughter from hands, tickling.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Glagos: Milk.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achne pyros (Froth of fire): Smoke. Also 'achne hypnou (froth of sleep).' Hippocrates also [uses] 'achne limou (fluff of famine),' but it means also fine shavings.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaukos (Gleaming/gray): Bright/white, glossy/blue.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaukou techne (Skill of Glaukos): A saying for things that are not easily accomplished, or for things that are done with much care and skill.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bombylios (Bumblebee): A kind of bee, or something similar to a bee, named after 'bombein' (buzzing). And it is also a kind of narrow-mouthed drinking-vessel, since this also buzzes ('bombei'). And a vessel for holding oil, by virtue of its similarity … is also called a ‘bombylios’.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Authochthon (Indigenous): Of the same city.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaukopis (Gleaming-eyed): With beautiful eyes.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achnymene skytale (Lamenting staff): Kratinos said [that this is] that which causes grieving.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achora (Dandruff): In the masculine, the flakes on the head and on the beard. Aristophanes in his Holkades "For he scratches his dandruff, he always pulls out from his chin the grey hairs of Zeus."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aeizon (Ever-living): You will say it with three syllables, as the Attic [writers], and 'aeizoon' with four syllables. And it is similar to 'aeinos' (eternal), which denotes ever-flowing ('aennaon'). So just as from the disyllabic nominative 'soos' (whole) arises the monosyllabic nominative 'sos' and the accusative 'son', so from the monosyllabic nominative 'zos', which also Homer employed arises the accusative 'zon' and, by compound, 'aeizon', as Aeschylus in Glaukos of the Sea [says]: "the one who ate the ever-living, undying grass". And Sophocles said the nominative "aeizos genea" (ever-living race). But from the disyllabic nominative 'zoos' Plato the comic said "philozoos", the genitive of which is 'zoou', which Aeschylus pronounces, by compound, when he says "and may I eat of the ever-living grass."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athenaias (Athenian women): Megakleides says that women were not called [so] but 'Attikai', in his books On Homer, at the same time furnishing also the reason. For, he says, they call only the men from there 'Athenians' but the women 'Attic', so that the married women not shame the unmarried with the appellation. But Pherekrates in Old Women says, "to both Athenian and allied women". And Kantharos in Tereus: "a fair and good Athenian woman/wife." And Philemon in Pterygion: "I mean these here Athenian Hipponikas and Lysistratas and Nausinikas". But others, claiming that Attic women must not be called Athenians, cite as the cause the homonymity that they [would thereby] have with the goddess. For the goddess [Athena] is called 'Athenaia'. But they say that 'astai' (townswomen) and 'Attikai' are said instead of 'Athenians'. Except, though, there was much use of the utterance, applying to women, among the ancients, as the aforesaid poets attest, and Diphilos in Amastris. And also Ion says that Themistokles' daughter is an Athenian foreigner, and Pindar in scholia(?). Phrynichos however, says that the utterance is not Attic and wonders how Pherekrates, inasmuch as he was most Attic, uses the word.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alomenos: Wandering.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amyna (Self-defense/vengeance): Also applying to requital and exaction of justice.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphidromia: A day used to be celebrated for newborn children, on which they used to carry the infant around the hearth, running, and from their family and friends they used to receive poulps and cuttlefish. It was named after the fact that while they were sacrificing to the gods they raced in both directions and ran around with the child.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antitypous anthropous (Resistant men): Hard and unyielding. Metaphorically from the anvil and hammer. "And blos [and] counter-blow."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apo misthomaton thyein (To sacrifice from contracts): So the Attic [authors] used to call public sacrifices, which they used to perform by contracting them out.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apotimetai kai apotimema mai apotiman kai ta ap' auton (Assessors and the thing assessed and to assess and the things from these): Those who renting out the homes of orphans from the archon used to provide a securities for the lease. And it used to be necessary for the archon to send some people to evaluate the securities. The securities used to be called 'apotimemata', and those who evaluated it 'apotimetai', and the task 'apotiman.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apheis ten hyperan ton poda diokei (Having released the brace, he pursues the sheet): Expression in Hyperides applying to those who, having left more important things, are wasting time with trivial things. And 'hyperai' (braces) are nautical ropes, by which the sailyard is moved from one side to another.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Achreston (Unprofitable): For 'achresmodeton' (not having recevied an answer from an oracle). Plato. "I am ashamed, oh foreigner, to send you away without a response having completed a long journey."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Achrysoi (Without gold): Plato, in Book 3 of the Laws, says "But they could never become rich without gold and silver."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Achyron: The storehouse for chaff. Aristophanes in The Banqueters says "...and Hekabe wailing and the chaff house burning."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsestos (Untanned): Not softened. Plato: "Dear sir, I was worn out from running fast."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaphyron (Polished): Someone witty. Thus Menander.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaphein (To scrape up): The Ionians [say] 'glyphein.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glaphyron (Elegant): Pleasant, hollow, deep, wise, experienced, accurate, brilliant.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gleukos (Grape juice): That which trickles down from a bunch of grapes before it is trampled.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glene (Eyeball): Pupil of the eye. Or mountains(?).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glamon: One who is bleary eyed and has wet eyes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gloiazein (To wink): To close the eyes and to wink.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Gloieta (Shifty): One who is filthy and wretched in character.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glouton (Buttock): The curve of the hip joint.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glykyderkes (With a sweet glance): Pleasant in seeing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glykera: A certain courtesan.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glykythymia (Kindly disposition): Pleasure in living and, as it were, a love of life. Also, all pleasure is commonly called [this].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glykys ankon (Sweet elbow): From the bend down the Nile. That was called thus according to euphemism. For it is long and difficult. Plato the philosopher used the expression.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Glyphidas (Grooves): The notches of an arrow, with which we draw the string. From 'engeglyphthai' (to have been carved), that is 'to have been hollowed out.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Grapheus (Painter): For 'zographos' (painter). Demosthenes in Against Meidias. Also 'graphein' (to paint): 'zographein' (to paint).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Griphos (Creel): Net. Also a difficult and complex utterance is called [so].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Daimon (Demon): Causing mental derangement.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Daimonie (Good sir): Dear sir.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Datos: A very fortunate city in Thrace, from which the expression 'Datos agathon' ('Datos of good things'). They name this city and the adjacent land both in the feminine and in the masculine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Dekazon (Bribing in tens): What this denotes is clear. The word was framed from this. Lykos is a hero with the animal's [i.e. a wolf's] shape, and is set up on a monument near the lawcourts in Athens, in front of whom those who take bribes used to gather, arranged in groups of ten. There also [arose] the expression "Lykos' company of ten". Thus, from the 'company of ten' [came] 'to bribe in tens' (dekazein) and 'to be bribed in tens' (dekazesthai).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Diakonisteros kai diakonistatos (More servile and most servile): Also more talkative and more like a thief. {expression} "A Phrygian man struck is better and more servile," says the expression.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Diipolia: A festival held for Zeus, in the month of Skirophorion on the sixteenth.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Yes truly.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naiousin (They dwell): They live.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naichi (Yes): They use this frequently.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Zach Heater <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naken (Wooly-skinned): The hide of sheep.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nakos (Fleece): Hairy skin, or the pelt of sheep.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nakotiltai (Wool shearers): The shearers of sheep.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nama (Stream): Water, that which is drunk.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Namatiaia (Spring water): The water from streams and a spring, not from rain.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Zach Heater <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Namerteia: Truth.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nanos (Dwarf): Applying to little people in Neoclides and Aristotle. And Theophrastus writes "like a dwarf and having large genitals." For, in fact, dwarfs have large genitals.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naxia lithos (Naxian stone): The whetstone.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nasmous (Streams): The outflows.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nannion (Nannion): Apollodorus in On the Courtesans says that this courtesan was called "The Goat" because she ate up Thallos the tavernkeeper. For goats love a young shoot ('thallos'). There is even mention of her in comedy. Antiphanes the Younger in On the Courtesans says that Nannion is nicknamed "The Stage" because she appears more beautiful on the outside.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naxia lithos (A stone from Naxos): The Cretan whetstone. For Naxos is a Cretan city

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nape (A dell): A wooded, mountainous place.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Napu: Mustard.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Narke (Numbness): Irritation of the skin.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naston (Solid): Close packed, full, not having anything light.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nauarchos (Ship commander): The leader of the ships.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nauein (To flow): To approach as a supplicant. When they were in the temples or around the hearth, from 'enausai' (to kindle a fire).
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Zach Heater <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naukleros (Shipowner): Hyperides used the word not only in the colloquial way, but also applying to one who has let either houses or tenements with a view to collecting rents.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nauklerein (To be a ship owner): And to be lord over a home. So Alexis.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naukraria(?) (A naucrary): Demosthenes in Against Timokrates. Perhaps, in Atticizing [writers], it is better taken as Naukratetika(?), so that it would be from a Naucratite(?) ship or Naucratite(?) sailors. For, in antiquity, Naucratis was the ancient emporion in Egypt. And if it was 'naukrarika', it would be "of the Archons." For long ago they used to call archons 'naukraroi', as Herodotus says in book 5 of Histories.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naulochein (To ambush with ships): To lie in wait and ambush ships. Thucydides in book seven. Also such a place in which there are harbors is a 'naulochion' (safe haven).

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nausikydou (of Nausikydos): With the sigma and with similar others doubled. Aristophanes

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nausiporos (Navigable by ship): Penetrated by ships

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautidas (Female sailors): Women as sailors

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naustolia (Naval voyage): Voyage.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nauttian (To be sea sick): They say it with two taus.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naupharkton blepein (To look like a warship): They say this regarding those inspecting all around and proceeding augustly. "By the gods, man, you look like a warship."

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Neales (Freshly caught): Properly, a fish having been newly caught. But a newly salted one is also called [so].

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nympheutria (Bridesmaid): The one beside the bride.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nympheutria (Bridesmaid): A woman being sent with the bride by her parents. Also the newlywed woman and wife. And an older woman like Penelope and Helen. And, among the Athenians, the mother of Zeus. And the goddes upon the waters.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nymphaion: Nymphaion is in Pontus. And Krateros [says] in book 9 of on Decrees that they paid a talent to the Athenians.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalamai (Caves): Holes. And Thalamai is a place sacred to the Dioskuroi.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nymphai (Nymphs): The larvae in the little honeycombs of bees, when they start to make wings. And some simply [call them] winged larvae. And Samians also called the part over the middle of women's genitals the nymph. And the closed up buds of roses [were called] nymphs. And newleywed women [were called] nymphs. And the Muses [were called] nymphs by Lydians. And the outgrowth of all flowers [were called nymphs], it is clear. A whole history has been brought together in thirty three books by Dionysias regarding the Goddesses.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nymphika loutra (Bridal baths): The [water] being taken from the wells from the agora for weddings.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Notoplega (With scourged back): A rogue recieving blows on the back. Pherecrates in Drunkards writes "that the one with scourged back did not serve quickly."

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thakoi (Chairs): Thrones, seats.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thairous (Door-pivots): The sockets of a door.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalamepolos (Chambermaid): She who stays around the bedroom and guards it.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalamos (Bedroom): House or bedroom.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalamidioi(?) kopai (Lower oars): Those [that] drive [the boat] gently.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalattokopeis (You strike the sea with the oar): You speak idly.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda [θαλαττοκοπεῖς](suda:theta;11)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thalassa koile (The empty sea): The theater.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaleia (Plentiful): Feasting. From 'thallein' (to feast).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaliais (Feasts): Festivals.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thallos (A branch): A shoot of olive, or the whole growth.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thama (Often): Continually, frequently, perpetually.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thamakis (Often): Frequently.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thamizeis (You come often): You are frequent, you come frequently.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda [θαμίζεις](suda:theta;36)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thamina kai thaminos (Crowded and crowdedly): Continuously, compactly.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thamnos (Bush): It is a low-growing plant. A thickly wooded place is also called [so].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thanatesion (Deadly): They do not say 'thanasimon' (deadly).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thanaton (Wanting to die): Longing for death. But also one who kills is called [this].
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda: [θανατῶν](suda:theta;45)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thallos (A branch): The wreath of olive is also called [so].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thallophoroi (Carrying a shoot of olive): The oldest men among Athenians used to be called [so].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thargeleia: A daughter of Agesagoras, having been queen of the Thessalians for thirty years, Milesian by descent, and killed by a certain Argive since he had been imprisoned by her.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda: [Θαργήλεια](suda:theta;51)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thargelia: The Thargelia is a festival. It is held in the month of Thargelion, which is sacred to Apollo.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda: [Θαργήλια](suda:theta;50)

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Engytheke: Some say it is an equestrian adornment, others a thing capable of holding equestrian equipment, like an 'enarchos' is for hunting equipment. Kallixenos calls it 'angotheke.' 'Angothekai' hold decorative statuettes of gold and silver.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thargelion: The eleventh month in Athens. It was named [so] since the sun is fiery at that time. They used to call hot 'thargelion'. And the flowers used to wither then.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Edikaiothesan (They were justified): They were judged just, they were considered [just]. It also means the opposite: they were justly condemned. Dio in Roman History Book 15: “Because of their very ancient worth and their old friendship towards the Romans they did not endure being condemned, but the Campanians attempted to accuse Flaccus and the Syracusans Marcellus and they were judged(?) in the senate.” But often he uses this word in the sense mentioned above, as in Book 16: “You are all worthy of dying; but indeed I will not condemn all of you to die, but only a few, whom I have already captured, I will judge, and I let the others go.” And similarly in many other places.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hekatombaion: The first [month] of the Athenians. It is named so, because it is holy to Apollo, and also to Helios, who makes his big circuit during this month.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Tharnytai: 'Tharsynetai' (emboldens).
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu, Aidan Alemifar alemifaraidan@gmail.com

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiereion: Sacrifice, everything sacrificed.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiera syke (Sacred fig-tree): So the one on the road to [Eleusis](https://pleiades.stoa.org/places/579920) is called.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieromenia (Sacred month): The festival days are called 'sacred months.' Demosthenes in [Against Timocrates](tlg:0014;024;29.8).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieromenia (Sacred month): A sacred festival lasting a month.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieromnemones: Those who were sent to the council of the Amphictyons from each city of those who participated in the council. Or, those who offered joint sacrifices to the council of the Amphictyones from each city. They were called this because of remembering ('mnemoneuein') the sacred things ('hiera'), since the Amphictyonic decisions are sacred, and the council of the Amphictyons is sacred.
Notes: The first sentence of this entry = [Suda ι 183](suda:iota;183).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieromystes (Sacred initiate): A person inducted into sacred mysteries, a holy person.
Notes:
Edited by Mackenzie Zalin .
Photios ι 56 = [Suda ι 184](suda:iota;184).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieron gamon (Sacred wedding): Athenians celebrate a festival of Zeus and Hera and call it 'sacred wedding.'

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hieronymos: A general of the Athenians. And there is another Hieronymos from Megalopolis, whom Demosthenes mentions in [Against Aeschines](tlg:0014;019;11.4).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Tharnysthai: To have intercourse.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierosuna: The choice parts of the sacrifice customarily given to the priests in payment for their priestly service.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hierophantides: The women who display the sacred things to the initiates.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Tharraleon (Confidence): Courage.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda: [θαρραλέον](suda:theta;47)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Tharsynos (Bold): Confident.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin jds15@duke.edu
See also Suda: [θάρσυνος](suda:theta;57)

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithoros(?): Proverbial, of those ordered {to come quickly or depart}.
Notes: Photios ι 76 =  [Suda ι 241](suda:iota;241). Theodoridis' supplement to the text is drawn from [Photios π 230](photios:π;230).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithynei: He arranges, he straightens, he makes straight.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithynter (Guide): Driver, pilot, bit, rudder.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithysen (He dashed): He set out in a straight line.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithytenes: Stretched out straight.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thasian (Thasian): They also call cabbage and [pickling] brine [so].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thasios pais Aglaophontos (Thasian son of Aglaophon): Polygnotus the painter signed [his works] thus.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thatera kai Thateron (Thatera and thateron): Both the singular and the plural are said [so]. The masculine is said 'hateros'. The femine [forms] are elided thus: 'Hetera' and 'theiterai'.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithyphalloi: The perjurers(?) and people who follow the phallus wearing women's clothing. And the genitals are sometimes called 'phallus.' And the songs are called [phallic], which are sung over the set-up phallus.
Notes: For the correct text see [Suda ι 250](suda:iota;250).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thateron: The other part.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ithuphalloi: Those who dance the ‘ithyphalloi’ in the orchestra. Certain songs sung over the phallus are called this. And properly the erect member is called ‘ithyphallos.’

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hikanen (He arrived): He appeared.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ikarieus: A deme of the tribe Aigeis. And the people themselves [are called] Ikarians.
Notes:
Edited by Mackenzie Zalin .
The first sentence of this entry = [Suda ι 255](suda:iota;255).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hikelos: Similar.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiketeria: Aeschines in the [Apology](tlg:0026;002;15.4). 'Hiketeria' is the word for an olive branch wrapped in ribbon.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thatton: More swiftly.
Notes: Suda θ 63 gives an expanded version of this entry: [θ63](suda:theta;63)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumata (Wonders): What the wonderworkers show off.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumatizomai (I marvel much): I am amazed.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumasten hosen (How marvelous): That is, very much, so that one marvels.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumastika (Admirable): For 'thaumasta' (marvelous things).

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Eis pyr xainein (To card into a fire): An expression applying to those who do or say something for themselves in vain.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alkatho kai alkathein: Sophocles and Aischylos. It signifies 'to come to aid.'

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathika (Good things): Excellent things.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Allotrionomountes (Assigning to the wrong place): Making an interchange of names, or apportioning one entirely unsuitably to others.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Allos allon: For 'allelous' (one another).

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Halmyron (Salty): Lengthened for the most part. And they also say 'halykon' (salty). Aristophanes in Lysistrata: "By salty Poseidon they are certainly just."

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alogoi eranistai (Unaccounted eranistai): Those who have not yet collected in full the amount falling due to them.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Agamenos (Wondering): Marveling.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganniphon (Much snowed upon): Very snow-covered.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Hamadrya: Plums. Sicyonians [use it].

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganophrosyne (Gentleness): Mildness, softness.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Archen iasthai poly loion ee teleuten (It is much better to heal the beginning than the end): An expression. And it is clear that it is better to ward off when some disease and some other terrible thing (?)is beginning(?) than when it is flourishing and has come to completion.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Dios Korinthos (Korinthos son of Zeus): An expression for those saying the same things. It was spoken for the following reason. The Megarians, subject to the Corinthians, were weighed down by the demands and clearly were greatly vexed at this. And an embassy of Corinthians came to Megara and, when the people paid them no heed, growing irritated with them they kept on shouting, "Korinthos the son of Zeus will not endure these things." Then they say that the Megarians, casting them out, beat them and said, "Beat Korinthos the son of Zeus."

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Dory kerykeion (The herald's spear): An expression for those encouraging and threatening at the same time. The Gephyraians, having been forced to pay a tithe to Delphi by the Athenians and receiving the oracle "home is dear to Gephyraian man," following bulls until those became tired, as the god said to them that they were to remain there when the Athenians were having war made against them by Eumolpos, they traveled to the so-called Tanagra, having given a herald's staff to the one going first, but having armed the youth behind.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Archen Skyrian (Skyrian origin): A saying applied to those who are worthless and possess nothing profitable, inasmuch as [Skyros](https://pleiades.stoa.org/places/541108) is rocky and poor land.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Auto deixei (It will show itself): An expression. [This] omits 'the deed.'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achoreutos (Not trained in the chorus): One removed on account of his lack of eduction in dancing.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achos (Pain): Grief that inflicts silence. From this comes also 'achnumenos (being grieved).'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achranton: Undefiled, untouched. Strictly, that which a hand has not touched.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: A a: A system of water.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Empedokleous echthra (Hatred of Empedokles): It is proverbial. Lysias says, "I was thinking that such a friendship as mine and yours was fitted together so that not even the hatred of Empedokles could become an impediment.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: En Delphois skia (Shadow in Delphi): It has been fashioned from the story of the man hiring an ass, who was prevented by the owner from running under the shadow of the ass. For he had not hired its shadow. Thence therefore the expression is said "concerning the shadow of an ass," and it transferred to the shadow of Delphi.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Eg Kari ton kindynon (The risk in a Karian): Proverbial for those running a risk in other people's things.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achras (Wild pear): The fruit of a wild pear tree. Aristophanes in [The Ekklesiazousai (355)](tlg:0019;028;355) : "Some wild pear has the seeds enclosed within."

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: En to merei tis kai to pyr skaleusato (Let someone in turn also poke at the fire): An expression applying to those who supply unequal shares to a common [enterprise].

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achreiogelos anthropos (Untimely-laughing man): One laughing at and delighting in useless and unworthy men.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Exechein ton helion (That the sun come out). That is, to have commanded, “Come out, dear sun”. A certain proverbial little verse said by children whenever it is cloudy when it is cold. Aristophanes in Nesoi: "You will say then, just like the children: Come out, dear sun.”

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achradas (Wild pears): They call wild pears ('acherdous') this. Eupolis in his Astrateutoi says "They are eating the ripe wild pears." But it is probably the case that the fruit is 'achras' while the tree is 'acherdos.' Pherecrates says "or, of a spinous pear." Menander in his Heron: "But now, I will describe the wild pears to the huntsmen who have come from the city."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aeton hiptasthai didaskeis (You are teaching an eagle to fly): Applying to those attempting to teach certain people things that they understand better than those willing to teach.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achreion (useless): with the accent, like 'ameinon.'

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aena: Small fruitless trees.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Epi sauto ten selenen katheleis (You will bring down the moon upon yourself): The Thessalian women who bring down the moon are said to lose their eyes and feet. The expression has been said then for those who draw evils upon themselves.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akmonides: Charon. Also Ouranos, for he is the son of Akmon.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Erga neon (Deeds of youth): Some expression has been called thus: "Deeds are for youth, plans are for the middle-aged, and prayers are for the elderly."

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akolastos ochlos (Intemperate mob): Euripides said [it], and Sophocles [said] 'intemperate' ('akolaston') body. The Epicureans say 'intemperances' ('akolastemata') to excess, except Anaxandrides has also used the word as well as Aristophanes.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Erebinthinos Dionysos (Chickpea Dionysos): For 'zomos' (soup). An expression. The same [expression] is applied to those offering pretexts for escapes, whether useful or wretched.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achri korou (Up to the point of satiety): It was a saying, that 'that man is senseless to the max,' and 'this man cheated to the max.'
Notes: Cf. [Demosthenes 19.187](tlg:4040;029;187), where τὸ ‘ἄχρι κόρου,’ is a nickname ascribed to Philip.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achremon (poor): A person who doesn't possess money, a poor laborer. Also found are 'achrematoi (without money)' and 'achrematoteron (of the poorer).' And [Thucydides (1, 11, 1.2)](tlg:0003;001;1.1) has said 'achrematia (want of money).'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achuros (chaff heap): the storehouse for chaff. It is also called the 'achureon.'

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: En pitho ten kerameian manthanein (To learn pottery on a large wine jar): A saying applied to those who skip the first lessons and undertake the greater ones.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achura (chaff): also the husks. [Aristophanes in the Acharnians (508)](tlg:0019.019.508) says "For now we ourselves are the pure grain, free of chaff. For I tell you, the resident alients are the chaff of the citizens..."

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Koina ta philon (Common are the things of friends): Timaeus says in the ninth book that this was said throughout Magna Graecia, during which time Pythagoras was trying to persuade those settling it to hold [property] undivided. Menander has used the expression in Brothers.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Achon: a vine.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Bion memagmenon (Kneaded life): An expression applied to those who are counted as blessed [=>εὐδαιμονιζομένων] for a lavish and sweet life.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Dios psephos (Tribunal of Zeus): So called is [the place] in which Athena and Poseidon were brought to trial. Kratinos in Archilochois "There, they are called 'the seats and the gametables of great Zeus.'" For the place, in which they were brought to trial, is called the tribunal of Zeus. And the expression is applied to the holy and untouched.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: En pitho ten kerameian manthanein (To learn pottery on a large wine jar): A saying applied to those who skip over the first lessons and undertake the greater ones.
Notes: Photios ε 746 = first half of Suda [ε 1426](suda:epsilon;1426)

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Exo belon kathesthai (To sit out of the range of arrows): An expression exhorting to put oneself far from the enemy arrows.
Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>. Cf. Suda [ε 1822](suda:epsilon;1822)

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoinion: A sanctuary of Dionysus, after which also [is named] a clan.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theognis: Was one of the Thirty Tyrants of Athens. Theognis is also a poet, but he was a Megarian.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoinion: The Rural Dionysia used to be called the Theoinia, at which the gennetai made sacrifices. For they used to call Dionysus 'Theoinos' (wine god).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theioteles physis (Divinely perfect nature): The envoys who accomplish the will of the gods. Also said is 'theoteles physis.'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theokrines: Demosthenes in For Ktesiphon. He was a sycophant.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoranomoi (Market supervisors): The magistrates who manage goods for sale in the market. There were ten, five of whom they used to deploy [to administer] those [goods] in the city, and five [to administer] those [goods] in the country.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Alethes (Truly); Whenever the first [syllable] has an acute accent, it indicates something said in questioning, as in "really[?]", "truly[?]".

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anakalypteria (Unveiling presents): Gifts given to brides from the husband as well as relatives and friends, whenever they unveil themselves ('anakalyptontai') for the first time to be seen by their husbands. These are also 'epaulaia' (wedding presents).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Artynantes (Having put in order): Having prepared.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Aryballos (Bag or purse): A purse with draw cord.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Arybas: A proper [name]. He was a son of Alketos, and king of the Molossians.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anastata poiein (To create devastation): Plato, for he says, "Everything has been devastated, as it seems." So Alexis and Menander and Euripides. And Demosthenes in On the False Embassy: "Their city has been devastated."

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Aryei: He assists.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Arythmos (Irrhythmic): Unshapen, unorthodox, not having rhythm. For 'typos' (blow) is rhythm.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Exo Glauke (Away Glaukos): An expression. For the ocean ['glaukos'] (a type of fish) indicates a storm.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Arysamenos: Having drawn water.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Deuro (Hither): Some think it is deployed to refer to time, but all the orators use it to refer to place, as Aischines [does] in Against Timarchos.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Dikaiopolis: A city in Thrace.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Heba (Is in the prime of life): Is in peak shape, is fresh.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ebaion: Small, little.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebaskei (Comes to puberty): Peaks.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Healoken (It was captured): It was taken.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebe: Youth, prime.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Kyon epi phatnen (A dog at the manger): An expression applying to those who neither use [something] nor allow others [to].

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Anemata (Undistributed): Undivided.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eis hen elthon (They came to one): For 'they agreed'.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Moriai elaiai (Sacred olive trees): Sacred to Athena, from which the oil was given as a prize to the victors at the Panathenaia. The first were twelve in number, those transplanted from the acropolis to the Academy. So named either after the fate ('moros') and murder of Halirrhothios or because all Athenians used to distribute and share ('emerizonto') the oil from them.
Notes: Photios μ 529 = first half of Suda [μ 1248](suda:mu;1248). Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com> and Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Kyon par’ enterois (A dog among entrails): An expression applying to those who are unable to enjoy what is put before [them]. Or applying to very useless and unprofitable things. Since for the dog [entrails are] hard to chew and hard to swallow.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eis melittas ekomasas (You burst in on bees): Expression applied to those who contrary to expectation suddenly find themselves in a bad way.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hei boulontai (As they wish): According to what they wish.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Elateia: Biggest city of those in Phokis. Some, however, pronounce it with a rho, thinking it better to write 'Elatreia'.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebrynomen (I was living delicately): I was relaxed.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebyllian: To be in the prime of life, to flourish.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hermione: An inviolate place, or a city, the one in the Peloponnese which has Demeter shrines and Persephone sanctuaries.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Egamen: I admired.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: E gar (In truth): For 'ouch houtos' (not so).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Egasanto: They were wondering/admiring.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Egasthen: I wondered/admired.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hermokopidai (Herm-mutilators): Those who cut off the the herms' heads and genitals. And they say Alkibiades did this in cooperation with Corinthians.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hermokopidai (Herm-mutilators): Those responsible for mutilating the herms were called so. Thus Aristophanes.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Bebaioseos (For warranty): It is the name of a suit, which those who have purchased something bring(ing?).

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Es korakas (To the crows!): To the darkness!, to destruction!

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Leukoma: It is a wall whitened with gyspum suited for the writing of certain civic matters

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Nai ma Dia (Yes by Ζeus): It is an Attic usage. This is the same as "nai ma ton Dia" (Yes by Zeus).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Engya (Was giving a pledge): Was agreeing to give; the one receiving 'engyato' (was accepting a pledge).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Egeira (I roused): I provoked.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hegeisthe moi: Lead me.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hegemoneuo (I rule): I administer.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Naikisereis (Ones who sneer): In Pherecrates and Hermippus. It indicates the opposite of telling the truth.
Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com> and Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ephesia grammata (Ephesian letters): Certain spells that are difficult to understand, which [they say] Kroisos also spoke on the pyre. And when a Milesian and an Ephesian were wrestling on Olympus, [they say that] the Milesian was unable to wrestle owing to the fact that the other man had Ephesian letters around both his ankles. But after this became clear and they [i.e. the letters] were taken away, the Ephesian fell thirty times consecutively.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Text: Ten cheira prospheronta ton theon kalein (To call on the god while offering one's hand): When an ox-driver was driving a wagon from a village, and when this [sc. the wagon] fell into an cavernous ravine; help being necessary, he stood idle and prayed to Herakles, for he was accustomed eagerly to honor him out of all the gods. The god appeared standing next to him and said: “lay hold of the wheels and goad the cows; and then pray to the god, whenever also you yourself do anything; do not, however, pray idly.” From this it was introduced as an expression.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alyei (He is distraught): He is troubled, disgusted, disheartened, at a loss.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: (?)Halourgaion (Purple): For 'halourges' (purple)(?). Aristophanes.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alocheutos: Unborn.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thronion: It is a city in Lokris.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thystion: A city in Aitolia, but some say 'Thytion' without the sigma.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Halousa: Having been taken.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Thyteion: The place where they used to sacrifice.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alydis (To another place): Change.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kantharou melanteros (Blacker than a dung-beetle): A saying. Menander in Thesauros.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alydis (To another place): In another place.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kerameikos: There were two Kerameikoi, one inside the city [of Athens] and one outside. There they used to bury those who had died in war at public expense and give funeral orations.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Nastos (Solid): A type of a flat cake. Also, 'nastophagein' (to eat cakes). And they call leavened bread generally large [bread] this.
Notes: Edited by Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com> and Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kerkouros (Light vessel): They call a kind of ship so.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alyxai: To have fled. Or, to have scraped down.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kerkopes: Criminals, traitors, cheats, fawners, who, just as the fox deceives hunting dogs, trick simpler people by means of the tail ('kerkos') of their words.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Naubates (A marine): One onboard but not rowing. Or a sailor.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ptolisma: City

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Anelktais ophrusin semnon (Haughty with upturned eyebrows): It is said in Cratinus

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Text: Anektemai (I have regained): for I have taken back; Sophocles said [it]

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Naukleros (Ship-owner): The master of the ship. And the one sailing with it with a view to receiving fares.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Haloai: Threshing floors. Or gardens.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Anektemai (I have regained): For 'I have taken back'; Sophocles said [it].

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Gethosune (Joy): Delight.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Anelktais ophrusin semnon (Haughty with upturned eyebrows): It is said in Cratinus.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Naukraroi: The current demarchs in Athens long ago [were naukraroi]. Also those who let public contracts.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Harmostai (Harmosts/Governors): Those dispatched as magistrates by the Spartans to subject cities.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Gingron: Sexual divinity.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Alypon anthos(?) anias (Painless bloom(?) of grief): If you should wish to speak concerning some thing which frees [one] from pain, you would use it in this way, as Sophocles in his satyric Dionysiakos(?) for the satyrs in the chorus when they first tasted wine: "Wherever did I find a bloom(?) so grief-free of distress?" The entire little song is very true to daily life; for along with the rest of its vividness it has a style that is relaxed and suited for speakers who are drunk. One must match the relaxations of the style to the sentiments expressed and not constrict and add knots anywhere, but rather keep the relaxation pure.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Lykou dekas (Ten-company of Lykos): Proverbial. Since Lykos the hero had a statue of him placed by the law courts. The sycophants used to sit near there. Three obols a day had been set apart for him.

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Kertomios: Provocative.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agorasten (Buyer): Him who purchases prepared foods, whom Romans call a 'caterer'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anelpistos (Without hope): Without expectation in On the Crown, Demosthenes [says].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anemokoitai (Wind-lullers): Those who put winds to sleep. They say that such a breed exists in Corinth.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anenechtheisas (Having been brought back): For  'having brought back'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anentes (Having permitted): Having persuaded.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anexeureta (Undiscovered): Thucydides, in book three: "undiscovered number". So also has Hellanikos used [it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anexiteton: Without exit.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anexetastos (Unexamined): Demosthenes in the fourth of the Philippics and Aischines in Against Ktesiphon.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anexodon (Without outlet): Euripides said [it] in Erechtheus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anepalto (Bounded): Sprung up.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anepatesas (You trampled up): For 'you trampled down.'

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anepaphon (Untouched): Irreproachable, pure, intact, unhandled.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anepaphroditos (Without charm): Not pleasing and disagreeable.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anepachthes (Not burdensome): Without weight, light.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apomisthoi: Those who have not received pay. So Demosthenes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apophyxis (Escape): Lysias in Against Hipponikos has said, "escape from a suit". But 'escape' applies to this meaning quite rarely.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phylakterion (Guard house): A place where the guards live.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phyla (Races): Nations.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phykia (Wrasses): Marine animals or the foam.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phryx aner plegeis ameinon kai diakonesteros (A Phrygian man is better and more servile after being beaten): Since Phrygian slaves seem to be rather idle and sluggish.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phrynon: This man was one of the ten ambassadors with Aischines and Demosthenes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phryktoria (Signaling with beacons): Nighttime guard duty: either torch or burning.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phrourion (Citadel): Stronghold.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phryagma (Neighing): The sound emitted through the nostrils of horses and mules with a fierce snort. It is also said applying to laughing.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phroureseis en Napaktoi (You will stand guard in Naupaktos): [That,] when scant wages were given to those who were guarding Naupaktos and necessities were selling for a lot, the expression arose. But some say that Philip, when he captured Naupaktos, on Achaians' advice, slew all of its guards. Theopompos too recounts this in the fifty-second book.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Philios Zeus: [Zeus] who watches over friendships. Menander in Androgynos: "I call to witness, Kraton, Zeus Philios". Pherekrates in Krapataloi: "To the judges now judging I say not to violate your oaths nor judge unjustly, or, by [Zeus] Philios, Philokrates(?) will tell another tale to you, much more abusive than this."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phasiansoi (From the river Phasis): Cocks and certain birds.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phasganon: Sword.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phasi: They say.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pharmaka (Drugs): Painters' pigments, and doctors' remedies.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Phalanx: In the feminine, the spider. Plato in Hellas: "To us, the laws seem like these fine spider's webs, which the 'phalanx' weaves on the walls."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hys hypo rhopalon drameitai (A pig will run under the club): An expression in Deinolochos applying to those who cast themselves into ruin.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Para kophon apoperdein (To fart next to a deaf person): An expression [applied] to senseless people.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: A (Alpha): Alpha, with circumflex, denotes ‘would that.’ For so Kallimachos has used it. But it also denotes the connecting word ‘O,’ as Homer: “O, wretched men.” But when it is pronounced short and aspirated it indicates ‘whichever,’ and in Demokritos ‘one’s own,’ and also in Homer, ‘his own things:’ “each to his own home.” And 'ha' (which) is deployed also for 'hon' (of which), as also in Euripides, in Medea: “having done what I intend and obtaining what I will.” And so also Sophokles, saying, “You will obtain what you seek.” But if it should be with smooth breathing and circumflex, it indicates ‘now,’ but short and smooth it indicates a negative response. So, if the word is monosyllabic, when it is by itself, it establishes an absolute meaning, but when used as a part of a word the alpha denotes privation, as in 'anandros' (un-manly), 'akakon' (un-harmed), but it also indicates greatness, as in “wide-mouthed ('achanes') sea,” but also plenitude as in “in much-wooded ('axulo') woods,” and commonality, as in 'adelphos' (brother), one from the same womb ('delphys') or cervix, and badness, as in 'amechane' (unmanageable), for 'kakomechane' (evil-plotting) and other such.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Habrodiaitos (Living daintily): Luxuriator, living luxuriously. Also graceful: one who is luxurious and soft. Also a meadow graceful and moist and blooming.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathe tyche (Good fortune): Some think that this was written first ... but some add on 'and god', as Plato [does] in the third book of the Laws: "Now indeed we call on god and good fortune in our prayers". And Timokles: "God, forsooth, and good fortune is present".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agallesthai (To be delighted): To joy in, to be high-minded, to pride oneself. Plato in the Laws calls paintings 'agalmata' (delights). Thucydides says, "Each exalts in having a country among the Hellenes", for 'boasts.' Also many others. They say also, 'one exalts the gods,' and 'I shall exalt' and 'Exalt!' [active] and 'Exalt!' [middle] and 'one exalts' [middle] land 'let one exalt.' Usage is abundant among the ancients.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agathon agathides (Balls of goods): The expression is applied among the comic authors to many goods.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiknoumai: I come, I supplicate.
Notes: A longer version of this entry is recorded at [Suda ι 270](suda:iota;270).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiknoumenos: Begging.
Notes: This entry and the preceding are combined at [Suda ι 270](suda:iota;270).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hikesthen (The two arrived): They were present.
Notes:
The lemma probably refers to a Homeric passage such as [Iliad 1.328](tlg:0012;001;1.328), where there is an identical scholion.
This Photios entry also = [Suda ι 260](suda:iota;260).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiketo (Let him arrive): Let him be present.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hikonto (They arrived): They were present.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ikria (Benches): Straight boards; or the planking of a ship.
Notes: [Suda ι 275](suda:iota;275) gives an expanded version of this entry.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: (?)Hagneuetai ten polin (One purifies the city): For 'wrongly marked according to accusation'. For 'cleanses'.(?)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aizeoi (Vigorous): Youths boiling in their blood, or those who are very hot and fierce. Or high, great, and mighty.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Astathmetotaton (Most unsteady): Concerning which no one could conjecture or estimate, whatever one has in mind or what to do(?). Demosthenes in On the False Embassy.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Asynthetotaton (Most unbound by covenants): Demosthenes in On the False Embassy deploys the word applying to a mob, for 'most untrustworthy' and 'unreliable' and 'not making pledges of good faith owing to unreliability'. Or not-agreeing and discordant; for, contracts are agreements. Or for 'most lacking in understanding'. Homer [says it] for 'that in regard to which a person cannot grasp what ever one thinks'. For he says, "You, understand and hear me".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aspharagon (Throat): Throat, stomach, gullet. The part that grows from acanathus plants is also called [aspharagon]. 'Aspharagos' is also a type of plant that is useful for cleansing. So the Attic authors produce [the word] with the phi, but the masses being imprecise say it with pi. And they call simply the shoots of greens 'asparagoi'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Attikois grammasin (In Attic letters): Demosthenes, Against Neaira, for ‘in ancient [letters].' For the alphabet of 24 letters was at some late date discovered among the Ionians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hautaii (These): The appending of the iota among Attic [authors] not only applies to singulars but also to plurals.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphrodisios logos (Aphrodite's speech): Plato said [it] in Zeus Kakoumenos. Also the same [author said] 'aphroditaridion' (sweet little Aphrodite) diminutively: "O wretched me, you will destroy me. Sweetest little Aprodite, I beg you, do not disregard me." But Aristophanes [says] 'Aphroditidion' (sweet little Aphrodite), and the same [author] called wine "Aphrodite's milk".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphrodite psithyros (Whispering Aphrodite): There is in fact at Athens a sanctuary of Whispering Aphrodite, after the fact that the women who pray [to her] pray into her ears.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agyrtika: Common lies.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agyrtode (Beggarly): Vulgar.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agyrrhios: An Athenian demagogue, not obscure.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Egeneto kai Mandroni sykine naus (Even Mandron has a fig wood ship): Said applying to those who are fortunate beyond their worth. For Mandron was selected admiral among the Athenians, though he was unworthy of the office. The fig-wood ship denotes cheapness.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naustathmon: The harbor

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naustoloun: Equipped as a ship

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Naustolian: A sailing journey

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautike syngraphe (Marine contract): The marine loan, which one makes against security.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautillomenos: Sailing

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautodikai: Nautodikai: At Athens, those who introduce lawsuits for xenia.
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com> and Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautodikai: The 'nautodikai' were a certain magistracy in Athens. Krateros at any rate says, “if someone born from two foreign parents joins a phratry [=> φρατρίζῃ], it is for him who wishes of the Athenians--to whom suits are available--to prosecute, and bring suit before the nautidikai on the last day of the month."
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com> and Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nautodikai: Magistrates who hear cases in reference to shipowners and those who work around the emporion, as also 'nauphylakes' (ship sentinels): certain magistrates in charge of guarding the ships.
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com> and Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nauphrakton kai naupharkton: They call naval strength [this].

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Neales (Freshly caught): The alpha is lengthened. Aristophanes in Lemnians: "until it is freshly caught in respect to its very peak." Menander.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumazo (I wonder at): When we combine it with a genitive, it denotes 'I observe', but with an accusative 'I approve'.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com
See also Suda: [θαυμάζω](suda:theta;68)
