Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaumastoteron (More wonderous): So Plato.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thapsinon chroma (Yellow colored): For 'xanthos'.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thapsos (Wood used for yellow dye): Wood with which they dye hair or wool yellow. What Sappho calls, “Scythian wood”.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theater (Spectator): One who is watching a performance, or one who organizes a performance.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: (?)Theatrokorasia (Spectator rule): Mob rule.(?)
Notes:
Edited by Zach Heater <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
See also Suda: [θεατροκορασια](suda:theta;90)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theien (They might set): They might make(?).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theinai (To set): To make.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theion (Divinity): For god.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelgei (Cheats): He loves, mistreats, impairs, darkens, deceives, or inflames.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelgetron (Charm): Something leading into pleasure.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelein (To want): For 'dunasthai' (to be able).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelemos (Willing): For 'hesychos' (quiet).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelete (Desired): Fruitful and most fertile.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelkto (Charmer): A sycophantic [woman].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themethla (Foundations): The innermost parts, the things in the depths.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themenos ta hopla (Taking up arms): For 'perithemenos' (donning) and 'hoplisamenos' (arming). Demosthenes and Homer and Aeschines.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themin: Justice.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiktar (Close): Near. It was said from 'ephikneisthai' (to approach). Thus Plato.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ikteros (Jaundice): They say it is a yellowing disease stirred up by anger, so that it makes the eyes of those who are taken hold of by it yellow and dark, like those of kites, from which it is named.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Iladon (In troops): In a crowd, in bands. It can also indicate ‘thick.’
Notes: This entry = [Suda ι 286](suda:iota;286). Probably a gloss on [Homer, Iliad 2.93](tlg:0012;001;2.93).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ikteros (Jaundice): They say it is a yellowing disease stirred up by anger, so that it makes the eyes of those who are taken hold of by it yellow and dark, like those of kites, from which it is named.
Notes:
Edited by Joshua D. Sosin .
Reproduced as part of [Suda ι 279](suda:iota;279).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilapinazo: I feast.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilapinas: Sacrifices, festivals, feasts.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilas (Troops): Groups or rows; and 'ilarchas' are troop-leaders.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hilasmos: {Kind, very mild} forgiveness.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hilasterion (Propitiatory): Sacrificial.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ileos: An animal's hiding place.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hileos: Propitious and kind.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilias kakon (An Iliad of troubles): This used to be said as a proverb for 'great troubles.'

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilingia (He is dizzy): When a twisting happens around the heart, darkness follows. And they call this 'ilingos."

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilion: The pubic hair.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilis{s}os: A river in Attica.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Illein (Plait): To hold together.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry = [Suda ι 310](suda:iota;310).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: ἰλλόν· στρεβλόν, στραβόν.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Illoptein: To look at with squinting and bent eyes.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Illoptei: He squints.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himan (To draw): To draw up; for having put on straps (himantes) they used to draw up or let down.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himantas (Straps): Those of the sails. Aristagoras.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himantes (Straps): Thongs, bands.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himantosis (Strapping): Binding of boards placed in houses.
Notes:
Probably a gloss on [Sirach 22.16](tlg:0527;034;22.16.1).
This entry = [Suda ι 333](suda:iota;333).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himasen: He whipped.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himaios: The milling song.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Imbrioi: Those who secretly escaped trials, since they were thought to be in Imbros.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himeiro: I desire.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himeroenta (Causing desire): Shining(?).
Notes: Reproduced as part of [Suda ι 350](suda:iota;350). The definition here has crept in from an adjacent notice in the [scholia to Iliad 3.395-7](tlg:5026;001;3.395.1); see Theodoridis on this entry and Adler on Suda 350.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himantosis (Strapping): Binding of boards placed in houses.
Notes:
Probably a gloss on [Sirach 22.16](tlg:0527;034;22.16.1).
This entry = [Suda ι 333](suda:iota;333).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oa (Sorb apples): A kind of hard-shelled fruits, similar to small apples.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oarismoi: Conversations.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obelos: Obelisk.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obolou chimaira en Haidou (A she-goat on a spit in Hades).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obolostatesai (to weigh obols): Receiving interest.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obria kai obrikala (Cubs): The cubs of lions and wolves. Aeschylus uses it in his Diktyoulkois (Netfishers).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obrimos: Strong.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ho ge: Which indeed ('ho de').

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ogkian (Uncia [a unit of measurement]): A fixed standard. Sophron and Epicharmus [use it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Antiatas: Those from the city of Antion, which is 300 stades from Rome

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apobates kai apobainein kai apobatikoi trochoi (Dismounter and to dismount and dismount courses): A dismounter is a certain equestrian competition, and to dismount is to compete in the dismounter, and those [events named] after this competition are dismount courses.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Ableden: A key-note.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Basilis (Queen): The wife of the king, as also 'balanis', the wife the 'balaneus' (bath man).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Brochos (Noose): A rope with a loop, which when it is drawn throttles him who has it on. Or something wooden, like a pillory placed around the necks of lawmakers in Lokris.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bru: They say [it] without the omicron applying to children asking to drink.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelai (To exalt): to honor. The usage belongs entirely to the Attic writers. And you will say 'agelo' (I will honor) and 'agaloumen' (we will honor) and 'agalle' (pay honor) and 'agallei' (will honor the god), for 'will pray' and 'will honor'. And 'ago' (I lead) for 'I honor'. So 'agein' and 'agelai' are Attic [words], but whereas 'agein' is ordinary, 'agelai' is comedic and nearly an obscure term. So then one ought to avoid the word that belongs to obscure terms. But if you were keen on an archaic sound and a solemness of speech, you would use this sort of style of words, says Phrynichos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Brya: Seaweed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bryazei (Swells): Again(?) behaves luxuriously, flourishes, enjoys oneself.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Brygmos (Biting): Grinding of teeth or sharpening of molars.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bryei (Flourishes): Blossoms.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Brykynistai: Diviners.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bryllein (To cry for drink): To drink. So Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Byttake (Parrot). An Indian bird. So Ktesias.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bolis  (Cake used in sacrifices): Barley cake, So Aristophanes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomon (Altar): Stavesacre(?). Spartans [say].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bon (Ox): Shield. Argives [say].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Bonysoi: Settler, ox-tender.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Dipodia (Two-step): A kind of Spartan dance.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Anathema (Offering): The Attics [write] all such [words] with an eta too.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Empousa: A daemonic apparition sent by Hecate, which seems to change into many forms. Aristophanes in The Frogs. 'Empousa' comes from 'empodizein' (to hinder), or from the fact that the other foot is bronze. Or because it appeared to initiates out of dark places. She was also called Onopole(?).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Anapephlasmenon (Masturbated): Holding one's member erect; for the Attic [writers] say that to soften up (anamalattein) members is 'to masturbate' (anaphlan).
Translation: Anapephlasmenon (Masturbated): Holding one's member erect; for the Attic [writers] say that to soften up (anamalattein) members is 'to masturbate' (anaphlan).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zagreus: Dionysus, in poets. For Zeus seems to have had intercourse with Persephone, from whom [came] chthonic Dionysus.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Aproikon (Without portion): The Attic [writers pronounce it] with accentuation like 'anthropon' (man).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zagra: A kind of verbal abuse. Thus Timostratus.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Argas (white, shining): some say this was a bad poet, but others that the 'argas' is a type of snake.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zakoton: Exceedingly inclined to anger. For ‘kotos’ (grudge) [is] ‘orge’ (anger).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zale (Storm): A great whirlwind. From the excessive gathering [of winds]. Also ‘zaploutos’ (very rich), [for] a very wealthy man. In the Republic: “As it were, standing under a wall as in a storm of dust and whirlwind brought by wind.” And in the Timaeus: “When it was overtaken by a tempest of winds driven by air”. For he wants to show the twisting and sweeping motion. Some [use it for] a furious wind, a turbulent blast. Clement: “It is possible for a sort of storm to be a great gathering of wind”. Some [refer to] ‘chalazan’ (hail) [as] ‘zale’ (storm).
Notes: Photios ζ 9 = [Suda ζ 13](suda:zeta;13). Edited by Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Pharmakos (Scapegoat): Purification, with short alpha. But the Ionians, lengthening it, say 'pharmâkos'. For they, on account of their proximity to the barbarians, soiled the heritage of their dialect, its metres, its quantities, and Hipponax also makes this clear.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ogkulomenos (?) (To be swolled): Arrogant.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ogmos (Furrow): The path in a line of reapers. Also furrows of grain.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odax (Biting the lip): Having bitten with the teeth.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odaxesmos (Itching): Scratching. Also grinding of teeth.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zamolxis: Enslaved to Pythagoras, as Herodotus [says] in Book 4, a Skythian, who having returned [home] taught that the soul is immortal. But Mnaseas [says] that Kronos [=> Κρόνον] was worshipped among the Getai and called Zamolxis. But Hellanicus in The Barbarian Customs says that he, having been born Greek, revealed the mystic rites to the Getai in Thrace, and said that neither he himself nor those with him would die, but they would have all good things. Having said these things he at once built a dwelling underground. Then, disappearing suddenly from the Thracians, he lived in this place. The Getai longed for him. In the fourth year he appeared again, and the Thracians believed him in everything. Some say Zamolxis was a slave to Pythagoras the Samian, son of Mnesarchus, and he played these tricks when he had been freed. But it seems to me that Zamolxis lived much earlier than Pythagoras. But the Terizoi and Krobuzoi consider themselves immortal, and they say that those that have died depart like Zamolxis, but will come again. And they ever believe that [he] spoke these things in truth. And they sacrifice and feast sumptuously on grounds that he who has died will return again.
Notes: Photios ζ 11 = [Suda ζ 17](suda:zeta;17). Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com> and Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodagos (Guide): On account of the alpha, not 'hodegos.'

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodaios Hermes (Hermes of the Crossroads): The [god] of Crossroads.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odaktazein: To bite.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hod' ego: I myself.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodesai (To sell): To sell. Euripides [uses it] in his Alope and Cyclops.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodios (Guardian of travelers): An epithet of Hermes.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aristotle(?) [says that he was] a painter during the time of Isocrates.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeuxileos: To whom the people are subjugated ('hypezeugmenoi').

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeus Ktesios: Whom they would set up in storehouses as a bringer of riches.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zephyros: Westerly wind.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ze (Live): For ‘zethi’ (live). Euripides.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zelotypia: Jealousy from suspicion; a man's [=> ἀνδρὸς] suspicion against his own wife toward another licentious man.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodoidokos (Highwayman): A knavish thief on the roads.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odontismos (Teeth gnashing): A form of flute playing.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zelotypoun (Being jealous of): Aeschines, for 'hating'. For ‘zeloun’ (to praise) is to congratulate, but  ‘zelotypein’ (to envy) is to have come into hatred.
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com> and Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodopoioi (Trailblazers): The curators of roads.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zelou (Emulate!): Imitate!

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodoures (Beginning of a road): First.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zelo (I praise): I bless.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodoureis (You watch the road): You go forward.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodourous (Highwaymen): Men doing evil on the roads.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odynephatos (Painkiller): The thing making pains go away.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odussea (Odyssey): The farthest length. And similar things.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ododen (He has smelled): He smells.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zelotos (Enviable): Deemed happy, laudable.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ozai: The skins of the wild ass.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ozein (To smell): They do not only say 'ododenai' ('to have smelled').

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ozos: Branch.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hothi: Where.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oietas (Villagers). The townspeople. Sophocles [uses it] in Andromeda.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zemian labein (to incur a loss): For ‘zemiothenai’ (to incur a fine). Thus Sophocles.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiai (Sheepskins): Hides, sheepskins.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zesei: For ‘zesetai’ (he will live).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakizei (He mans the tiller) He pilots.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakistes (Helmsman): Pilot.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakistes (Helmsman): Pilot.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakostrophos (Tiller turner): Helmsman.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeugle: The end of the yoke, through which the animals put their heads.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zeugle: A yoke.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakostrophon (Tiller turning): Piloting.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiakostrophos (Tiller turner): Helmsman.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oignuei: He opens.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidainon: Swelling, breathing(?).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hileo: Propitious.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hileoterion: Propitiatory.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidainei: It causes to swell.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Himas<s>o (I will whip): I will strike, I will beat.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidei: It makes swell, it has distended.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidema: Swelling. An inflammation. An abscess. So it is said from a metaphor for bodies both with regard to swelling and to character.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidemata (Tumors): Swellings or inflations.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thaleroi (Fresh): [Boys who are] moist, young, in their prime, or swift.
Notes: Edited by Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com> and Matt Farmer <farmermc@missouri.edu>

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidesis(Swelling): Tumor. Boil.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: In common usage they say 'thatton' (faster) or 'baden' (step-by-step). Faster or slowly.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theepolein (To minister in things divine): To go around with images of gods exacting money.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theein kai thein: To run.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bryton (Beer): A barley drink, but (others say that it is) beer.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bryttontes: Oryttontes (digging).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bybliophoron (Papyrus-bearer): The letter-carrier.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byblos: Papyrus.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brytia (Marc): The pulp from pressed grapes/olives, which they call stemphyla. The Attic (authors call it) the olives' 'grounds' (alesmata).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byzen (Closely pressed): Completely, compactly, continuously, fully.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bynein (To stuff full): To compress.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brytidai: Name of an Attic clan ('genos').

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brychios (From the deep): Plunged in the water.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byodes (Full of seaweed): Stinking.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bromasthai (Bellowing): The braying of a hungry ass . Also ‘food’ (broma): the same sound.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bromes (Of food): Of eating, of nourishment.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byousin (They stuff full): They block.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byrsodepses (Tanner): Leather-worker, one mending animal hides.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bysauchen (Short-necked): One who draws in the shoulders up to the neck.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byssodomountes (Pondering deeply): Examining in depth.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byssos: Depth.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bystra (Plugs): Morsels from green vegetables.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bon (Ox): Shield. Argives [say].

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomax: Beggar at altars ('bomolochos'). This (is one who) takes from alatrs before the offerings are made. It is deployed applying also to the effeminate.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Eetioneia: So the other point of the Piraeus was called after Eetion who had won the land.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomakes: Beggars at altars ('bomolochoi'). So Telekleides.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomax (Little altar): Altar, diminutively. So Aristophanes.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomoi (Altars): So ascents are called, (and) beds of straw.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bystax: What by us [is called] 'mystax' (upper lip, mustache). They shorten the second [syllable], saying 'mystaka'.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Eemen(?) (We knew [=> ᾖσμεν]): We knew.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Ethadon: Accustomed.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: He themis (As [is] custom): As [is] law, as [is] fitting.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Etheios (Honored): Among Ionians, a greeting of a younger man to an older man.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Êthê (Custom/herding together): Herdings together. "to both haunts and pasture of horses." It is also written 'ethê'.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thiasoi maiolei(?): In a frenzied dance.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theiasantes (Having been inspired): Those having become possessed.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thiasotes (Member of a thiasos): A participant in the sacrifices. Orgeones used to be called this as well. They were so called after the 'thiasos' (revel), which is the assembly after the drinking.
Notes: Edited by Joshua D. Sosin <josuad.sosin@gmail.com> and Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Themisteuein (To deliver oracles): For 'chresmoidein' (prophesy). Lysias. The name came from the fact that Themis once held the oracle before Apollo.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Themison: The name of a tyrant. Demosthenes in For Ktesiphon.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Themitos (Rightfully): Lawfully.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Themistos (Righteous): Just.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themista (Right): Law or justice.
Notes:
Edited by Zach Heater <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
See also Suda: [θέμιστα](suda:theta;117)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themisteusantos (Having judged): Having ruled, having judged.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Thenar (Palm): The hollow of the hand. It was also said applying to the wick(?) of the foot.
Translation: Thenar (Palm): The hollow of the hand. It was also said applying to the wick(?) of the foot.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theodmetos (Godbuilt): Having been made by the gods.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theodromon: One going in the manner of God.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoeides (Godlike): One that has a form similar to the gods.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoeikelos (Godlike): Similar to god.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theothyta: Sacrifices.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theogeiton: Demosthenes. Dinarchus and others call him Theogenes.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoklytos: Honored by heaven.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theometi: Godly-minded, divinely-wise.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theomanteis: Those being inspired.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theopropia (Prophecy): Mistake(?) Also 'theopropion'. An oracle from a god. Or an oracular utterance.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com;
See also Suda: [θεοπροπία](suda:theta;173)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theopolein (To minister): To go back and forth about the gods.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theopropos: A seer or prophet of a god.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoremosynen: Divine teaching, instruction.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theorryton: Coming from a god, or pouring forth.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oidma (Swell): A wave or the sea.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiesthai (To think): To have in mind.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiessi (For sheep): For sheep.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oizus (Misery): Suffering. Toil.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikea (Household slave): The ancient Athenians [called] a slave born in the house 'oiketen.' The Attic [authors] also call all persons in the house 'oiketas.'

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikarion: The little house.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikeios (Domestic): Private.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikeus: Household slave.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theoseptor: God-fearing.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikidion (Little house): They lengthen the second syllable, as also 'chrysidion' ('small gold coin') and similar things

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikiskos (Cage): Partridge cage. Aristophanes [says it] in The Storks.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikogenes (Homeborn): A home bred slave.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikeos (Of a household servant): <***>.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikema (Dwelling place): Dinarchus [says it] for 'prison' ('desmoterion'). And Aeschines [says it] for 'brothel' ('porneion').

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiktiston (A most pitiable thing): A pitiable thing.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oimoge (Lamentation): Groaning.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oimozei (He wails): He groans.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oinara (Tendrils): The shoots of the vine.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oin(ie?)s (Oeonoe): One of the ten tribes among the Athenians

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oinopazon (Drinking wine?): Drinking wine. Being well entertained in a symposium.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oistha (You know): For ᾽oidas᾽ (you know). It also said without the sigma. But it is sometimes with the sigma either on account of meter or on account of not clashing with the consonant(?) ('symphona').

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Neochmon: New

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Kynosoura (Dog's tail): Lakonian tribe. Also a promontory of Marathon

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippake (Mare's milk cheese): A Scythian food prepared from horse milk.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Theteuein (To be a laborer): To work for a wage.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Theseion: [The Theseion] is a precinct dedicated to Theseus

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Theraion: A many colored garment.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Theratoras: Huntsmen.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ek klimakos (By the ladder): In gymnastic contests, whenever the boxers were delaying, a ladder would be brought in, so that standing apart and taking a position they would stay in the same place with the consequence that the directed blows could not be avoided by running around, but standing in this manner they would defend with outstretched hands.
Notes:
Edited by: Matthew Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Edited by: Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy:
Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
John-Paul Smith-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebdomeuomena (Receving a name on the seventh day): They used to celebrate the seventh and tenth days for newborn children, and used to give them names at least, some [say] on the seventh, but others on the tenth.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Gastris (Glutton): One who is unrestrained concerning his stomach. And they also call one who has intestinal worms thus.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Gameseiein (To wish to marry): To be eager for marriage.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galos (In-law): Husband's sister.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galeos (Dogfish): A form of fish.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galene: A name for a whore. So Theopompos.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galine(?): Weasel. A pet name.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galaxia (The Galaxia Festival): A festival in Athens, <led by the mother of gods, in which they ate 'galaxia'; it is a barley porridge in milk>.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galepsos (Galepsus): It is a city of Thrace. It was named from Galepsus, the son of Theseus and Telephe.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Galeotes (Gecko): The spotted gecko, in Attic.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Gakinian: Earthquake. Kallias.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theostyges: Hated by the gods.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theophoria: Divine possession.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therapis: A woman that serves a god.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therapontes: Slaves. Servants.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θεράποντες](suda:theta;230)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theretai: It is being burned.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θέρεται](suda:theta;234)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theriston(?) kai theristrion: An outer garment for summer use.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [Θέριστρον](suda:theta;239)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therizein (To reap): The cutting of produce.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therma (Heat): Burning. Also the city of Therma, after which the bay is called.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therman: A Thracian town.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thermaystris: An eager and fiery dance.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thermopylae: Some call this city Pylai. But Phileas says it is called Thermopylae, since Athena made hot ('therma') baths for Herakles there.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thermos: Over-bold.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmothetes: A lawgiver or a guardian of the laws.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmothetai (Legislators): An office of six Athenian men who who used to take care of the laws and who used to introduce impeachments before the people and election votes and all 'probolai' and 'graphai paranomon' (public suits for illegal proposals); they were also revisers of the laws.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com and Aidan Alemifar alemifaraidan@gmail.com

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmothetai (Legislators): It is a certain office at Athens; being six in number they are indeed among the so-called nine archons. They are called thus because they used to have the care of the laws. That they revised the laws every year Aeschines has said in Against Ktesiphon.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com and Aidan Alemifar alemifaraidan@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θεσμοθέται](suda:theta;267)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmophoria: The name of a festival.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmophorion hemerai (Days of the Thesmophoria): 4; the tenth [of the month] was the Thesmophoria, the eleventh the descent, the twelfth the fast, and the thirteenth was the 'kalligeneia'.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesmophoros (Lawbearer): One who introduces the laws.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com and Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θεσμοφόρος](suda:theta;271)

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athroizei (Collects): Gathers.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kynna: Name of a prostitute.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kynosarges: Kynosarges [was] a certain one of the gymnasia among the Athenians.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Mekyberna: Mekyberna is a city in Thrace twenty stades from Olynthos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agallios: Abusive.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalmos: Abuse.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Angaros (Courier): Sluggish. But among the barbarians the public letter-carrier is also called [so]. Whence also to serve on public business is also 'angareuesthai'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Angaros (Courier): Workman, servant, porter. Whence we call involuntary compulsion 'angareia' (impressment into service) and service arising from force.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Angaroi (Mounted couriers): Those who carry documents in turns. The same are also [called] 'astandai' (couriers). The words are Persian. Aischylos in Agamemnon: "Beacon sent beacon hither from courier fire. Ida to Hermes' rock on Lemnos, and from the island the Athoan heights of Zeus received the great torch third". The word is applied also to freight carriers and in general the senseless and servile. Also 'angarophorein', applied to carrying freight, especially in turns. Menander in Poloumenoi: "He carries also these things which you now make--make--, though it is possible for someone bursting with countless good things to spend the night and day feeding"; and in One about to Marry: "Barbarian, courier in fact, and thoughtful of nothing". And in Thais: “Powerless, a courier, a plague, although I have suffered these things now I suppose I would have her happily.”. And they call 'aggareuesthai', just as we do now, being compelled into freight carrying and some such service. Menander furnishes also this in the Sikyonian: "A sailor puts in, he's judged an enemy. If he has something soft, he's pressed into service."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agamemnoneia phreata (Agamemnonian wells): They give an account that Agamemnon dug wells around Aulis and in many places in Greece.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganakton (Being vexed): It is applied in Plato also to those who are distressed.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganaktikon kai aganakteteon (Apt to be vexed and one must be vexed): Plato says the one in the Republic and the other in the Letters.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Αganopidos (Mild-eyed): Looking gentle.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganon (Broken): That which has been broken. The first [syllable] is acute. And this word is rather tragic.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thespesios (More than human): Divine, wonderful, gentle.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganophrones hedylogoi sophiai broton perissokalleis (Gentle of mood, with sweet-speaking wisdom, exceedingly beautiful of mortals).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agan teinein (To strive too much): To strive against and act against and, in arrogance, not to yield in any manner. The word is suited to prose.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agalaktia (Want of milk): Autokrates: "Lambs bleat for want of milk."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agai (Beaches): Shores. So Sophokles has used [it]. But the tragic poets also used to call wounds thus, and injuries. For an injury is as it were a 'katagma' ('breach') of the flesh.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thespizei (He decrees): He frames laws.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agametos (Unmarried): For 'agamos' (unmarried) in Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agapan (To be content): To be satisfied by a thing and seek nothing more.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thespismata: Divine decrees.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agasaito (Would be amazed): Would marvel.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agastho tini (I am amazed at someone): For 'I marvel at someone'. Xenophon: "Whenever I am amazed [i.e. delighted] at one of the soldiers".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agassei (Overdoes it): Strikes too much. 'Agassei' is from 'agan' (too much), as 'liazei' (to be over-enthusiastic) is from 'lian' (very much).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: You will say 'agasta' (admirable) and 'agastos' (admirable) and, adverbially, 'agastos' (admirably), as Xenophon [shows].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agastonos: Much-groaning.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agastou (Admirable): Marvellous.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thessalon nomisma (Thessalian custom): This saying is applied to cheating.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [Θεσσαλῶν νόμισμα](suda:theta;260)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agasikles: A proper name; who is said to have shared in the judging with the Halimousians and owing to this, though he was a foreigner, to have been registered [as a citizen] in the polity.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agasmata (Objects of adoration): Objects of awe, what one would stand in wonder of. Sophokles has used [it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agauriama (Insolence): Vanity.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Age deta (Come on!): Come!, attend!, here now!

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agein (To carry): For 'megalynein' ('to make great'). Homer: "And the Achaians would have made great my fame",

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelaios (Belonging to a herd): For 'common', 'paltry'. The word is perhaps from animals that herd together, to which meaning also Plato has applied the word, in the Politikos. But it has been transferred [as metaphor] to people who are rather ignoble. So Isokrates in his speech the Panathenaikos. And [they called] common [bread] 'herd bread'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agenes: Isaios, for 'apais' ('childless').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agennos (Ignobly): In a cowardly fashion.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agerastos (Without gift of honor): Without honor.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agermos: Assemblage.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thetes: (Adoptive father): One who has adopted some sons. But a ‘thetes’ is perhaps one who has received something for a pledge.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com; Somewhat similar to Suda: [θέτης](suda:theta;293)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelaton (Driving out the polluted): For 'chasing', 'banishing'. So Nikomachos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ankyle kai araphe (Ankyle and Araphe): A deme of the tribe Aigeis.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglaotimon (Splendidly honored): Brilliant, honored.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thettalike enthesis (Thessalian mouthful): A great bit of food.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglottia (Tonguelessness): Quiet, silence.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagneia (Purity): Cleanliness.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnias: A proper name.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thettalis (Thessalian): A sort of shoe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnos (Chaste-tree): A plant, which they also call 'lygos'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnodikos (Ignorant of right): Not knowing what is right.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theton: Adopted, not lawfully begotten.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θετόν](suda:theta;295)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnodikeis: The gods.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agnoie (Ignorance): Pain. Also 'agnoein' (to be ignorant), to be pained.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnopoleisthai (To be purified by sacrifices): To be cleansed by offerings.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thettalos: One of the children of Cimon was called thus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnousios: Hagnous is a deme of the tribe Akamantis, whose tribesman is an Hagnousios.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thettalon sophisma (Thessalian trick): Used [in reference to] battle and military formation and deception and of thousands of other things which are the responsibility of those that draw up battle formations. For the god told Aratios(?), who was on the attack going down, to be on guard, lest the ones opposing him escape his notice and come out against him, having furnished greater and more fervent prayers. But he vowed to sacrifice a hecatomb of a hundred men to Apollo. Having brought what he wanted to a successful issue, he delayed the sacrifice, because it was not appropriate for a holy place.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theodosia: A land lying near the Scythians, which Satyros died besieging.
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade clinton.kinkade@gmail.com; See also Suda: [Θευδόσιος](suda:theta;301)

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agorasai (To buy): To purchase.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoraioi (Frequenting the market): Those who are engaged in the market.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoraios Zeus (Market Zeus): An altar at Athens, which used to be called 'Market Zeus'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agorasmata (Bought/sold goods): They call merchandise [so]. Also 'agorasmaton' (of bought/sold goods). Also 'agoraseos' (of purchase), 'of buying'.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thegontes: Sharpening.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agriothymos (Wild tempered): Wild in spirit.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroikos (Boorish): Senseless, grouchy. Or one who dwells in the country.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelazein (To suckle): To feed with milk. The ancients all [say it] thus, but especially the Ionians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agroboas aner (Wild shouting man): He who speaks boorishly and neither urbanely nor harmoniously. So Kratinos.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchaze (Back!): For 'Withdraw!'. So Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchaske (Gape!): For 'anachaske' (gape!). So Pherekrates.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agchemachos (Fighting hand to hand): Fighting at close range.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchi: Near.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thelynoi (Effeminate): Quiet people.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themakeus (Demesman from Themakos): Themakos is a deme of the tribe Erechtheis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themachos: A deme of the tribe Erechtheis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Themones: The heaps of uncut grain.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theramenes: This man was killed when Critias brought charges against him under the Thirty.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com; See also Suda: [Θηραμένης](suda:theta;345)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therikleous teknon (Child of Therikles): A wine-cup, which Therikles is said to have made first.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therikleion: A glass drinking cup.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Therontes (Hunting): Looking out for.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theseion: [The Theseion] is a precinct dedicated to Theseus.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com; See also Suda: [Θησεῖον](suda:theta;367)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thesomai (I will place): I will define, I will make, I will display.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Theteia (Service): Obligation to remain in service or servitude.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thetes (Hired / bound laborers): Those who slave for food.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thinganei: He touches.
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin joshuad.sosin@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θιγγάνει](suda:theta;383)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Threskeuei (He worships): He serves the gods, he ministers to the gods.
Notes: See also Suda: [θρησκεύει](suda:theta;486); Edited by Tori Lee toriflee@gmail.com

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Threskos (Superstitious): Holding opinions other than the right ones.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thyechooi: The priests who sacrifice to the gods on behalf of others.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thyeketadai(?): A deme of Hippothoontis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thylakos: A stitched leather bag.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thylakophoroi (Bag-carriers): Miners, because they carried ‘thylakoi’ (stitched leather bags).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thylegmata (Offerings): Pastries, first fruits, barley-groats, which they mixed with wine and olive-oil, pouring them forth into a sacrifice.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thymalgea: Distressing.
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan jmccrossan123@gmail.com; See also Suda: [θυμαλγέα](suda:theta;545)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thymalops (Piece of burning wood): One of the gods is so called. Also burning coals. The burning coals or half-burnt wood. Or sparks.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thymelon: Altars.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Thymedia: Delight, luxuriousness, good cheer.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agorazein (To buy): To purchase something and to spend time in the agora.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchithyros (Next door): Neighbor.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchimolon: Coming near.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchimos: For 'close by'. Euripides: "But close by is this woman sacred to Phoibos".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchinoia (Shrewdness): Intelligence.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchinous (Shrewd): Intelligent, sharp in the mind.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchista: Nearest.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchisteia (Nearness): Kinship. Also 'anchisteis' (close kin): those from siblings and cousins and uncles, on the father's and mother's side, closest to the deceased. But those outside of these are only 'kin' (syngeneis). And those who are commingled with households by marriage are called 'oikeioi' (members of household).

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchisporoi (Close in seed): Close in descent.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchou: Near.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anchomalou (Nearly even): Equal, close to even.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apopsophein (To break wind): To fart, saying [it] politely. More politely: 'to blow through' or 'to blow off.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Leuken mazan phyro soi (I am mixing a white barley cake for you): An expression applying to those who promise great things.
Notes: See also Suda: [λευκὴν μᾶζαν φυρῶ σοι](suda:lambda;324)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Leonta xyras (You are shaving a lion): An expression said applying to those who attempt the impossible.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: La{m}bda: The Lacedaemonians used to paint [lambda] on their shields, as did the Messenians. Eupolis: "He was stunned when he saw the gleaming lambdas." Thus also Theopompus.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labais (Grips): Touches or pretexts or censures.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labein timorian (To get revenge): To have been vindicated.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labra(?): Public alley, road, street through which people flow.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labragoren (Braggart): One who talks vehemently.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labronion: A type of cup, broad in construction, and having big handles. Thus Menander.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labein timorian (To get revenge): To have been vindicated.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Labon (Having taken): Properly both 'having bought' and 'having hired.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagiska: A certain prostitute, whom Lysias mentions.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagesis: A Sicilian goddess.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagnas (Lechers): Those inclined toward sex.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagmata(?): Sacred first-fruits.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagnos (Lecher): Prostitute, shameful man, inclined toward sex.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagoia: They call rabbit ('lageia') meat [this]. Thus Aristophanes.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagoos katheudon (A rabbit sleeping): An expression [applied] to those who are pretending to sleep.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lathyrous: Chickling peas.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lathon (Having escaped notice): For 'lesomenos' (about to escape notice).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laia: Left. {Or a sleeveless tunic.}

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lailaps (Hurricane): Storm and darkness with winds.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laima: It was said from 'laiman' (to be hungry); arrogance.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laimargia (Gluttony): Intense desire.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brosimon: For 'edible' (broton).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brotais (Edible): For 'consuming'. Thus Sophocles

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Broton (Food): Eating, nourishment.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byas ophthe kai byai ophthesan (The owl was seen, the owls were seen): Dio in Roman Histories says often that these would appear to the Romans as a portent. And it denotes...

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Byba: Sated, full. Also they used to say it for 'large'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brotos (Mortal): A perishible person.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boomen (Let us shout): Let us swear.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bops: A fish.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Botores: Cattleherds, herdsmen.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Botaneira (Man-feeding): The nurse of heroes.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Botein: To plow, as Laconians say.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bomakeumasi: With ribald jests ('bomolocheumasi').

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boroi: Eyes.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boson (Roar): Come to the rescue. Cratinus.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bos (Ox): Hide, shield.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bostrein (To call on): To summon, to shout.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bromos (Oat): A seed similar to threshed barley.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brotoenta (Gory): Bloodied.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brotachous: Frogs as Ionians say.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brotoeidesin: of mankind.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brikala: Some legumes.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Gangile (Jowl): That which is in the fleshy parts on the jaws and hips. So Kallias.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Gaza: A city of Libya

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Gazophylakion: 'Thesaurophylakion' (treasure guard). For 'gaza' (treasure) is 'thesauros' (treasure).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Galeron (Cheerful): Cheerful. Calm, quiet, gentle.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Gale chiton (A tunic for a weasel): The saying itself is used applying to wrongdoers and ones who let nothing go.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Galenian (To be at peace): To be glad, to delight in, to rejoice, to be relaxed.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laion: Left.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laiphos: A cloak.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laipseron: Quick, light, nimble. Laconians [use it to mean] half-dry.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakeryzesthai (Make a noise): Compose, or reproach.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakedaimon (Lacedaimon): They accent the vocative with a circumflex on the penult. Thus Aristophanes.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakeryza korone (A cawing crow): One that calls loudly.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakein (To bark): For 'phthengesthai' (to shout).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakiadai kai Lousia (Lakiadai and Lousia): A deme [of the tribe] Oineis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakisma: Tear.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkoplouton (Pit-wealthy): They used to call Callias the Athenian this, for a reason such as the following: When Xerxes was defeated in the naval battle at Salamis, he fled Athens. One of the Persians had taken up quarters in the house of Callias, and left his baggage there, but when the barbarians made their sudden flight, the servants of the Persian threw a lot of gold into a pit; he hoped he would return later and retrieve it, but it is said that this never happened, since Callias took possession of the gold first.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkos (Pit): A kind of hole prepared inside a house to receive water or for storing other things.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkos (Pit): The Athenians and some of the other Greeks, making holes in the ground wide and round and square, and plastering them, collect wine and oil into them; and they call these ‘lakkous.’ And Demosthenes in Against Aphobus for Giving False Testimony: “Taking the things from the house and leading away the slaves and destroying the ‘lakkos’ and breaking down the doors and only neglecting to burn down the house itself he moved to Megara.”

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakonizein (To be a Laconian): To make use of boys. Aristophanes in Thesmophoriazusae II.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkopedon (Scrotum): The testicles. Thus Antagoras(?).

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganaktesis (Vexation): Applying to fortune, Thucydides in the second book: "Neither does it hold vexation ('aganaktesis') for the invading enemy."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: En chroi koura (A cropping on the skin): [A cropping] that is bald and up to the skin; and an 'on the skin cropper' is one who crops in this manner. And simply(?) 'on the skin' means 'close(?).' Thus also Thucydides: “They say that the ships sailed ‘on the skin.’”

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ethnos (Tribe): Not only the large and populous clan, but also, in a special sense, a certain part of the city. So Demosthenes in Against Aristocrates, and in the ninth of the Philippics.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Heiloteuein (To be a helot): To be a slave. For Helots were those who were not slaves of the Lacedaemonians by race, but were the first of those living in the city of Helos who were mastered.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakonikon tropon (The Laconian way): To finish; or for women to give themselves to strangers, since the Laconians guard their wives least of all.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Onchos: The windpipe, the larynx.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lankryzesthai(?): To reproach.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Heilotes (Helots): The slaves of the Lacedaemonians. [They were called] Helots because they were first defeated and enslaved in Helos.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Edeatros (Taster): The word is Greek, but the custom Persian. He was a pre-taster, at first, and would eat before the king for safety. Later, it became customary to call ‘edeatros’ the person in charge of the whole service and preparation. <Thus in the first lexicon. In the second I found the following:> Edeatros: The one in charge of the twins(?) and such preparation; the word is Macedonian.
Notes: Edited by Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com> and Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Enchytristriai (Urn-women): The women who bear drink offerings to the dead. Minos or On Law [uses the word].They also used to call injuring 'putting in an urn' (katachytrisai). <So Aristophanes>. Also that they are called 'enchytristrias' who purify the polluted by pouring the blood of a sacrifice over them; also dirge-singers [are so called], and still further that the midwives, the ones that expose newborns in urns, [are so called].
Notes: Edited by Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>, Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>, and Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obolos (An obol): The interest. A kind of currency. And the obol is six(?) 'chalkoi' among the Athenians. A 'chalkos' is seven 'leptoi'. And a talent of now four pounds of silver is also eight of coins and six of <***>. And a mna is 1/60 of a talent. And a talent of gold is six times as much.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ek dyo tria blepeis (You see three from two): Applying to those who owing to old age or some other condition neither have sharp sight nor have their senses intact.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ilθs: Filth.

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Egallen (Was glorifying): Was exalting. Dio in the 16th 'logos' of Roman [History]: "Both owing to these things, then, and because he was glorifying the god strictly." Thus, both others and Eunomios the impious have used this word, <and this man himself [used it] often>.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Kydos (Reproach): Reproach in the masculine. Also an expression, “to incur the penalty of 'kydos', <applied to those who> acted the sycophant.”

Author: Clinton Kinkade <clinton.kinkade@gmail.com>
Translation: Lykos peri phrear choreuei (A wolf dances around a well). An expression applying to those who toil at something in vain. Also because it goes around [it] unsuccessfully, whenever it is thirsty, since it is not able to drink. <Or> since, when it chases something, the thing chased falls into the well <...>.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Text: Ikria (Benches): The ones in the agora, from which they used to watch the Dionysiac competitions before the theater was built in the [sacred precinct] of Dionysus.
Translation: Ikria (Benches): The ones in the agora, from which they used to watch the Dionysiac competitions before the theater was built in the [sacred precinct] of Dionysus.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Acharton(?) (Undefiled): <...> untouched. Strictly, that which a hand has not touched.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Eleokopous (marsh-cutters): <Lysias> [uses this to mean] those who cut marshes ('hele'), with the 'epsilon' inserted, as in “marsh-bred celery” in Homer. <But perhaps the word has come from 'eleon' (table), which is a wooden ..., >.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: <Eithyphalloi: It means three things, and it is written with the diphthong 'ei'. First it is a kind of dancing song, second leather genitals, and third a certain rite for Dionysus.>

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Engastrimythos (Ventriloquist): Belly-prophet, what [we call] nowadays a Python. Sophocles [says] 'sternomantis' (chest-prophet). Plato the philosopher [calls it] a Eurycles, from Eurycles, a prophet of this kind. <Aristophanes’ in Wasps: “imitating the prophecy and idea of Eurycles.”> Philochoros in Book 3 <of On Prophecy> said that women were ventriloquists too.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ekkekophth' he mousike (The art had been cut out): They say that whereas the ancients engaged in philosophical inquiry in the symposia, later people introduced singing girls and cithara girls and dancing girls. Whence some people would use this expression when censuring innovation.
Notes: Edited by Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com> and Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ektithenai ta brephe (To expose infants): For 'to set out (infants) in deserted places, for food for beasts or also for destruction otherwise'.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Enegraphe (He was enrolled): He was made a citizen, having come from the ephebes.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hektemoroi (Sixth parters): Those who work the land on condition of [payment of] a sixth part.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkoscheas: Men who have a hanging scrotum, which is the container of the testicles.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkoscheon: Effeminates.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakpatein (To trample): Pherecrates in Petale: "Beat me, hit, trample, push, bite."

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakones (Laconians): Name of a dice throw.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakonikai: A formal mens' shoe.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Matthew Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>,Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>,John-Paul Smith-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>,Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Epaktos horkos (Imposed oath): Whatever [oath] a person himself willingly imposes on himself, that is chooses. But others [say] the opposite: one that is imposed from elsewhere, but not chosen voluntarily. There are three types of oath: an oath of abjuration, an oath of affirmation, an imposed oath.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lalistaton (Most talkative): Wise in speaking. 'Euglottos' (with good tongue) and 'euphonos' (with good voice) are also said.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lalisteron (More talkative): More babbling.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamia: A beast.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampadion (Little torch): What they nowadays call a torch ('lampas'). Thus Deinarchus and Plato.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampas (Torch): A contest at Athens held for Pan and Prometheus.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampe: A thick foam on the surface of wine.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: They are called 'epaulia' inasmuch as the bride then for the first time spends the night ('epeulistai') in the groom's house. Also the things after the day following the wedding are called 'epaulia' after fact of the gifts from the bride's father being brought to the groom and the bride in the form of procession. For a boy would lead, holding a white mantle and a burning torch, and next after him a basket carrier, and then the rest of the women follow in order, bearing gold objects, dishes, unguents, litters, combs, beds, perfume jars, sandals, chests, sweet oil, salts. Sometimes they carry also the dowry along with the bride. But others say that the second day after the wedding is called 'epaulia', on which the bride first spends the night ('epaulizetai') with the groom.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampene: A type of carriage. Thus Menander.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampouris (Shining-tail): The fox, in Aeschylus.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampran hemeran legousin, ou katharan: They say 'a shining day,' not 'a clean [day]'.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamprai: A deme [of the tribe] Erechtheis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamios: Someone was called this in Athens, just like Mnesitheos.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamptreis: Twin demes of the tribe Erechtheis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamproeimon: Wearing resplendent clothes.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampros: ... the foam floating on wine and other liquids.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampropsychos (With shining soul): For 'megalopsychos' (great-souled).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamptris(?): Lamptrai is a deme of the [tribe] Erectheis; there are two Lamptrai, one coastal, the other inland.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampon (Shining): A dice throw. Thus Eubulus.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamynthios: A poet of love songs.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamyron: Well-spoken, witty, striking, pleasing.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lax enteinon (Stretching with a foot): Striking with a kick. 'Lax' is a sort of sound made by the digits of the foot.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lax podi kinesas: Moving [him] with the flat of the foot.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laxeuterion: A house-building tool, since 'laoxoos' is a house builder.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Laoxoos: Stone-cutter.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapades(?): Oysters; also 'lapades(?)': containers.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Balantiotomos (Cutpurse): A thief.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Balmos (Swelling): Breast.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapathon: A hole as a trap for animals; and a plant for emptying the stomach, whence also 'lapaxai': to empty. Homer: "He emptied the troops of young men," for 'he emptied it by destroying.'

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Balian (Spotted): Speckled.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapatton: Softening and making loose.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampros: Conspicuously ('phaneros'), not gloriously ('endochos'). And in Thucydides: "the treaty having been conspicuously dissolved" and in many other ancient [authors].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapittein:To lie and boast. And 'lapiktes': a liar, [spelled] with a kappa, like 'salpiktes' (horn-player), 'suriktes' (flute-player); but Dorians [spell it] with a sigma, 'lapistes' and 'salpistes.'

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Babaxai: To dance a Lydian dance.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bambalyzein (To chatter): To tremble from the cold.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapieis: You will brag.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapistes: Liar, rash person.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Lapistria: A woman raised up, roving, willing to boast.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Barbiton (Lyre): Psaltery, cithara.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Basilides: Sandals.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelas ponon (Herds of troubles): Euripides said [this], but Plato, "herds of men", and Aischylos, "unlaughing faces."

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: <Βασίλεια>· ἡ βασιλεύουσα.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Basilinda: A certain game in which they proclaim certain people kings.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Basileion: For 'basilikon' (royal).

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikothi (At home): At the house.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Basimos (Accessible): Passable, of easy access.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikoi: In the house

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Agelastos (Not laughing): Someone not prone to laughter. Also a sullen person. There is also a stone in Athens so called. And Aeschylus says as well “sullen heart”. Doubtless [this] did not prevent one from saying 'sullen mind' and 'sullen thought' and the like.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikoi genoimen (I wish I were at home): [It is said] for people praying to flee terrible things.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagios (Sacred): August. Also 'hagion': august thing and honored thing. But someone defiled could also be called 'hagios', after 'agos' (pollution), as Kratinos [shows].

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
