Translation: Diathesis (Disposition): Isocrates [uses it] for 'prasis' (sale). But Antiphon for 'dioikesis' (administration). Also 'diathesthai' (to dispose) applying to 'dioikesai' (to administer). And 'diathesthai' (to dispose) is taken for 'synthesthai' (to compose), as Hypereides and Demosthenes [say].

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hei: For 'hos' (as), 'kathos' (according as).

Author: John McCrossan <jmccrossan123@gmail.com>
Translation: Hebedon (From the youth upwards): Being in the prime of youth; or campaigns; or [the] contingent all [arranged] according to age.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Ap' onou katapeson (Having fallen from a donkey): A saying derived from those who make an attempt at horsemanship while not even being able to use donkeys. Aristophanes in The Clouds: "Why, I ask, do you talk nonsense as if having fallen from a donkey?" But the philosopher Plato says the expression not after the animal, but after the mind ('nou'). For he says in the Laws: "[I must not], as if my mouth were unbridled, be forcefully carried away by the discussion and, as the saying goes, 'fall from a mind.'"

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Automatoi d'agathoi (Good men, acting on their own): An expression said three ways. "Good men, acting on their own, go for good men's banquets." But "Evil men, acting on their own, go to good men's banquets." Plato used the first in the Symposium, while Kratinos [used] the second in the Pylaia. "Here we are, again, as the old saying goes, namely that good men, acting on their own, go to the banquet gentlemanly spectators."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphanisin (Disappearance): Demosthenes in the counter-suit Against Apatourios.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsamene (Having grasped): Having attached to.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsallakton (Untouched): Untested.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsaustos (Without being touched): Pristinely.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsauston: Untouched.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apseudia (Truthfulness): The truth. And also said are 'apseudein' (to not lie) and 'apseudes' (without deceit).

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apseudestatos mantis (Most truthful prophet): Kratinos says "heeding me, honor the god, since he is a most truthful prophet."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apseudomantis (Of no false diviner): Nikochares in Agamemnon "But I know that this woman is no false diviner and one who fulfills." <...> "And you will know my craft, truly no false diviner."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apseudousa (Not lying): Telling the truth and not erring in speaking.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsephistos: For 'not having voted.' Aristophanes has said [it].

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsimachos anthropos (Foolhardy man): As in, a man who in any case picks a fist-fight. Thus Theopompos.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsimachia (Skirmishing): Entanglement in battle.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsimesia(?) (Trivial enmity [=> ἁψιμισία]): A minor disagreement.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikotrips: Household slave.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsorroi (Going backwards): Hastening backwards.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikuporeia (Household stores?): The provisions in the house.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsopheti (Noiselessly): Softly.

Author: Tori Lee <toriflee@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikotr(ubl?)ion (Little household slave child): A small home-born slave child.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aps: Back again.

Author: John Paul Aldrup-MacDonald <jpr.macdonald@googlemail.com>
Translation: Porthmos: Demosthenes [in] For Ktesiphon. It is a city of Euboia.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Eiresione: A branch of olive wreathed with wool and with every kind of fruit of the earth hung on it. A child with both parents living used to carry it out and place it before the door of the temple of Apollo during the Pyanepsia. For it is said that Theseus, at the time when he was going to Crete, went to Delos because of a storm and vowed to Apollo that he would crown him with olive branches, whenever he was saved having killed the Minotaur, and that he would make a sacrifice; and so he garlanded his suppliant-branch, and boiled pots of gruel and soup and established an altar. Therefore, it seems, it is called Pyanepsia, like Kyanepsia, since they used to call kyamoi (beans) pyanoi. They used to hold it when they needed to ward off famine, and the children sang the following: “Eiresione bears figs and fat loaves and honey in the comb and olive oil for anointing and an unmixed cup, so that you get drunk and go to sleep.” After the festival they place them from the fields beside their doors. Crates the Athenian in On Sacrifices at Athens (says) that once when barrenness took hold of the city they wreathed a branch with wool as a suppliant-branch and dedicated it to Apollo.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Aloia (He was smiting): He was striking, from which also 'patraloias' in Attic, 'parricide'.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiere (Sacred): Marvelous.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obelias artos (A spitted loaf): One that is baked upon spits. The ones raising spitted loafs in the Dionysia were also called 'obeliaphoroi' (spit-bearers). The word is also used for laborers and countryfolk.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Obolos heliastikos (Heliastic obol): One which was given to the men sitting as jurors.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ogkoi (Barbs): Pointed objects.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Odme (Odor): Unpleasant odor. Smell.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Hodorein (To watch the road): To guard the road.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baskainei (Maligns): Blames.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baskainei (Maligns): For 'accuses' and 'blames' and 'accuses maliciously'. So Demosthenes in For Ktesiphon. And in the following he says, "no measure of mine is skanderous and harsh and malicious" for 'fault-finding' and 'sycophantic'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bassaros: Fox according to Herodotos.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Basmoi: Steps.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bastasas (Having lifted, tested): For 'having approved'. So Eupolis.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bastrachelisai: To twist the neck, for Boiotians (call) necks 'bastrachai'

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Batos (Passable): A passable place.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Battalos (Stammerer): Gross, shameful.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Larinoi boes (Fattened cattle): Some [say that they are] the cattle of Herakles having stolen them from the cowherd Larinos in Epirus, as Lycos [says], when he was driving off the cattle of Geryon; but Proxenos [says] that Heracles himself sent some to Zeus of Dodona; and Apollodorus [calls] well-fed [cattle] 'larinoi' (fattened), for 'larineuein' (to fatten) is 'to feed.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Larkos: It's a basket, into which they use to put coals. Lysias used the word and Aristophanes and others.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Larynga (Larynx): They say it as masculine. Thus Eupolis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Himeros: Desire.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Himertos (Desirable): Beautiful, lovable, longed-for.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Himonia: The well-bucket's rope.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Inasthai (To be purged): To be purified, to be emptied out. And 'hyperinos' [means] one who has been purified.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hindalletai: It seems, it resembles.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hindalmata: Phantasms, dreams, things which one perceives but which do not exist; likenesses, copies.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ines: Sinews.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Innos: [The offspring] from a mule and a female horse. A mule lives for fifty years. A 'ginnos' [can be born] from two horses if the mother horse is ill during the pregnancy, as with a dwarf.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Inukios oinos (Wine of Inukos): Sweet. Inukos is a Sicilian village, where there is very fine wine.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ixale: She-goat, since 'ixaloi' are he-goats. And 'ixalos' [means] good at leaping.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Good of someone: instead of "because of something." Menandros, "this is someone's good."

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Bottomless: That which does not have limits owing to its size. And there is a lake in Argos, which is called this.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: A barbarian mixture made from spices, namely from garden cress, garlic, mustard, and raisins, which they employ as a laxative.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agapan (To greet with affection): To receive favorably.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agersikybelis (Mendicant priest): Kratinos [mentions] Lampon the seer as a beggar and a sacrificer. For the axe is a 'kybelis'. But others write in drama that he who raises ('egeironta') the axe above himself is an 'egersikybeli'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageorgiou dikazesthai (To prosecute for lack of cultivation): It is said as [prosecution] for desertion, failure to marry, failure to submit accounts, and it denotes: whenever one after receiving a plot of land [in lease] leaves it uncultivated and unworked, then the owner prosecutes the one who received.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageraton (Ageless): Sophokles said this in the masculine, but Xenophon in the feminine. Also 'ageron' (ageless), Plato in the masculine, Euripides in the feminine. Also in the neuter, Thucydides and Plato, in the Timaios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agero (Ageless): Also 'ageron' with the ny. But others say that without the ny it is feminine. And others that the [word] with the ny indicates the accusative case, but that the [word] without this [indicates] the genitive and dative.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adynaton eran (To desire impossible things): Euripides said [it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adyopeton (Not to be put out of countenance): Not respecting persons. Or unsoftened in the face of entreaties and inattentive and hard.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Adyton: Cave. Or the hidden part of the sanctuary.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aei koloios para koloion hizanei (The jackdaw always sits alongside the jackdaw): A proverb. It is not only that the animal is fond of its own kind and flies in a flock, as starlings [do], but also it is caught by its own reflection, attacking it after it’s been seen in water, as Klearchos says.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aedona (Nightingale / Flute): It is on the one hand the bird, but by way of metaphor the tragic authors call the mouthpiece of pipes [so], and sometimes also the flute. The word is Didymus'.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Iporos: Bitter about penalties.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippagretai: These were three magistrates at Sparta.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippalektruon (Horse-rooster): Griffin; since it is four-legged and has wings and a hooked beak. Some [say that it is] a big rooster; some [that it is] a fake [word].

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hipparchoi: These were two [magistrates], who led the cavalry, each having chosen for himself five tribes. They are the commanders of the cavalry just like the taxiarchs - ten in number, one from each tribe - are of the hoplites.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ipes (Wood-worms): Little animals destructive to wood things and crops(?).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ipnos (Oven): 'Phournos' [Latin 'furnus'] (Oven). Or kiln. Or lamp.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ipnos (Oven): A part of the house, which is called by us 'mageireion' (kitchen). And strictly the oven is called 'ipnos.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hipperon (Horse-fever): Love for horses.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippeios (Equine): A race of four stades.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippelaton (Suitable for horsemanship): Roomy, wide, smooth, stripped bare.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippikai: Belonging to horses; [as in] 'hippikai neurai' (horse sinews).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippotamadai: A deme of [the tribe] Oineis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippobotos (Horse-nourishing): Having a lot of land, capable of raising horses ('hippous').

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippodamoi (Horse-taming): Engaged in horses.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Batania (Flat dishes): Platters. So Alexis.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bate: A deme of (the tribe) Aegeis.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bater (Threshold): The leading edge of the pit [for the long jump] in pentathlons.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Batia: A certain house named after Baton, (its) master. Or an implement or a certain territory or an adornment.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baukalan (To lull to sleep): To put down to sleep.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baukides: Women's sandals, after which also 'baukizesthai' is to be coy. And dainty is 'baukon' (prudish).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baukismos: An Ionian dance. So Ameipsias.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baunos: Furnace.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Athyroglossos (Babbler): Euripides in Orestes: "a certain babbling man". It is derived either from the gate (‘thyra’) not being shut on the tongue (‘glotta’), or from ’athyrein' (to mock), which is to communicate unintelligibly. And it denotes one who is ’athyrostomos’ (‘with ungated mouth’), who does not hold his tongue.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aisakos (Myrtle-branch): The branch of myrtle, holding which in place of a lyre they used to sing during carousal. But others say it is a branch of sweet bay, holding which they used to hymn the gods.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aion (Age): Marrow, as Hippokrates [says], or living, or life. Or everlasting time.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Procheirotonia (Preliminary vote): Some such thing seems to happen at Athens, whenever, after the council has deliberated, its resolution is brought to the people. First there is a show of hands in the assembly as to whether it seems best that the people take consideration concerning the preliminary deliberations, or whether the preliminary decree suffices.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Presbyteros Kodrou (Older than Kodros): Saying applied to those who are really old, [derived] from Kodros who was king at Athens.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pyrrha: a city, one of those in Lesbos.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Sagra: A river in Italy and a place, whence the expression, "Truer things than those at Sagra."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Anthemokritos: He was an Athenian herald, and was slain by Megarians because he forbid them from tilling the sacred land.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Arrhenikon (Orpiment, i.e. arsenic sulfide): The Attic [writers] do not call the painters' pigment 'arsenikon'. Aristophanes in The Feasters: "Thus the orpiment is here: now bid".

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Battarismoi (Stutterings): Fooleries.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bater (Threshold): The leading edge of the pit [for the long jump] in pentathlons. "You have struck the threshold of the argument," someone says, as in the most critical and primary thing.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baukalan (To lull to sleep): To nurse little children with a song.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bdallein: To milk.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bdelletai: Milks. But Plato says 'bdalletai'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bdelyros (Loathsome): Foul acting.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blepedaimon (Ghostlike): One who is distorted as to his visage and, as it were, stricken by a daimon.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bletos (Stricken): Astonished.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blepoi(?) (Looks): For 'glance'. So Aristophanes.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blepontes (Ones seeing): For 'ones living'. So Sophokles.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blema (Cast): For a missile that has been cast. So Herodotos.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blespein: Cast down.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Be de (And went): Proceeded.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Leads (agei): Instead of "brings" (komizei) or "leads" (hegeitai). Also "agei" as in "honours" (tima) or "venerates" (sebetai). Demosthenes uses "agei" in the Against Timokrates to mean "cost" or "amount of weight," saying "and the dagger of Mardonius, which was ("ege") three hundred darics" and in Against Demades, "it was (ege) five mnai."

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: "Ignoble and narrow speech": for those who are mute or have a quiet and unpleasant voice.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: "Glorify": to honour (timesai) a god, to glorify (aglaisai). Eupolis in the Demes, "Let us now also dedicate the twofold sacred boughs to them and let us glorify them as we approach. Greetings all! Welcome!" Aristophanes in Peace, "And we will all invoke you in holy sacrifices and massive processions personally, forever." Hermippos in the Bakers, "Well now I shall glorify the gods †of the sort who† and I will burn incense to them, since the child has been saved." Theopompos in Penelope, "And I will glorify you on the first of the month with little statues and laurel, forever."

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Ageless: Things that don't get old; holy or august.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: "To hallow": to harvest, to burn in a holy manner

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: "has led" (ageochos): "has brought" (enegkas)

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Of ritual (hagisteias): Of holiness (hagiosynes), of purity (katharotetos), of service (latreias)

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Bundlebearers: Those who carry bundles on ships or upon animals. Bundle-carriers: They are the same carriers, or children who follow the bundlebearing asses. And those who sell the bundles are called bundle-sellers. And bundles (angalides) are packages of firewood, whch are, so to speak, bundled together (angalisasthai).

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Bundles: portions

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: From the b'ginning (angathen): syncope of "from the beginning" (anekathen). Thus in Aischylos.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: I drive w'full strength (angratos): Xenophon said it in syncope instead of "with full strength" (ana kratos). And you would do better not to use this word.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Links: the rings in chains

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Artositein (To eat bread): The opposite of 'opsophagein' (to eat delicacies). Plato in Hyperbolus has used the word.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Broken (aganon): Sophokles, At Tainaron. He calls wood, which is broken or uncut, "aganon" (with the last syllable unaccented)
Notes: Sophokles, Herakles at Tainaron, Fragment 231 P. = 198b R.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blax (Stupid): Moron.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Artopopon (Baker): The Attic authors and the Ionians also [say] 'artokopon' (baker). And 'artopopein' (to be a baker) is in the Monotropes of Phrynichus.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Artos: The name of a ruler of the Messapians, whom Polemon said the Athenians made a 'proxenos'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Asemantois (Unmarked): Unguarded, not having leaders, those in charge. And the metaphor comes from seals.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Atrypheros (Not delicate): The word is in the Baptai of Eupolis: "because he is not an indelicate or ugly man"

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aphrodision (Belonging to Aphrodite): Aphrodite's business. It is understood to apply to lechers, who are lustfully and excessively inclined to intercourse. Also, perhaps Aphrodite's seat is an 'aphrodision'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Achyros (chaff heap): Like 'aoidos' with the accent, also with the middle syllable lengthened. <The> same is <also>  a barn for chaff ('achyrobolon').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Barathron (Pit): There was a hollow place at Athens called 'orygma' (pit) and 'barathron', into which they would cast evildoers. This later was filled in when, casting in the Phrygian for showing the mysteries of the Mother of the gods, they killed him and the goddess got angry; and pursuant to an oracle they also founded a sanctuary of the goddess. But Aristophanes (says that it is) a little women's ornament.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Basilike diadrome (Royal race): The race that took place in the presence of the king. This man was one of the nine archons at Athens, who(!) was called 'royal race'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Batalos: Proper [name]. He is ridiculed in comedy for effeminacy. Eupolis calls the anus 'batalos'. And perhaps from this they also call kinaidoi 'bataloi'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Olizon (Smaller): Littler.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Olisboi (Dildos): Leather genitalia.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkades (Trading vessels): Ships.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkeion (Basin): Kettle having three copper feet.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holken (Dragging): Bringing. Turning.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkoi (Straps): Ropes suitable for dragging.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkos anthropos (Attractive man): An attractive and alluring man.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkos (Furrow): Road. Or leading of a stream. Or tail. Or strictly the tail of serpents is a 'holkos', but also by misuse the length of a ship's keel is. For they would extend them in a snake-like way through the whole ship.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holkous (Channels): Harbors.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Holokarpoumenon: Offered whole.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ortygokopos (Quail-striker): A game, in which they stand quails in a ring, which they strike them in the head; and he who strikes the quail in the ring takes in order whichever ones he can; and he who misses allows the other one to strike the quail; and they do this by turns; thus, in Alcibiades he says "No, but you should be looking at the quail-striker, Meidias, and other such." In Phaedo (?) [he says] that the contest is not against whoever happens along, but against those who are best; wherefore one must not be negligent.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippothoonteion (Temple of Hippothoon): The hero-shrine, from the son of Alope and Poseidon, for whom also the tribe [is named.]

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippokleides: The female genitals. From 'hippeuein' (to ride).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippolytus: An example of self-control.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippotes: Cavalryman, equestrian.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippou trochos (Horse wheel): The ‘trusippion’ (horse-brand), since horses exhausted by age were branded with a wheel when the generals declined them.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippoporne (Horse-prostitute): For 'megaloporne' (mega-prostitute). Rare.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hip{p}oumenos (Squeezed): Pressed, forced.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippourin (Horse-tailed): One having a crest made from horse hair.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippophorbos: Horse keeper, since feed is 'phorbe.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Hiptatai: He flies.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Iros: The beggar.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Is: Power, sinews.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isazei: Be equal.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isaia (Equal): Portion.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isai psephoi (Equal votes): Aeschines in Against Ctesiphon: "Another private citizen sailing to Rhodes was indicted one morning because he bore fear in a cowardly way, and then he got equal votes: If one voting pebble had gone the other way, he would have been banished and died."

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isa bainon Puthoklei (Walking like Pythokles): Demosthenes in Against Aeschines for 'always being with and not being apart even a little.' And Menander: "An expensive prostitute walking beside him with equal steps."

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isaios (Isaeus): One of the ten orators, student of Isocrates, teacher of Demosthenes, Athenian by birth. But Demetrios says he was a Chalcidean.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isakioi: Manly.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isan: They went.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Issa: An exclamation for those who have lost their lot and are doing completely poorly. It's in Menander's Messenia and elsewhere.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isthi: Know.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isthmion: The thing around the mouth of a well.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Iskein: To speak. The little word is ancient.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ismen: We know.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ismenias: One was a famous polemarch among the Athenians(?).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isobolon: Equal in weight.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoklees: Equal in fame.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoktiton: Having an equal state.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isopale: Equal in allotment, for allotment is 'palos.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isorrhopon: Equal in heaviness, equal in weight.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isosthenes: Equal in power.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isostasion: Equal in weight.
Notes: Edited by John McCrossan jmccrossan123@gmail.com; See also Suda: [ἰσοστάσιον](suda:iota;664)

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoteleis: Paying equal taxes, paying taxes equal to the city-dwellers, that is to the citizens.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoteles: A freedman <who> partakes of the laws but isn't subject to the metic-tax.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isodaites: A certain foreign god, for whom common little women and not at all serious ones used to celebrate rites.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isourgos: Working equally.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isopharizein:To make oneself equal.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isophua: Equal.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histiaia: A deme of [the tribe] Aegeis.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histe: Histanai(?) in the imperative.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: (?)Histiatoria: Restaurant(?).

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histiatoria: The places in which they used to have feasts, which now are called 'hagneuteria.'

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histion: Sail.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histiophoros: Sail-bearing.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histopede: A piece of wood upright from the keel, to which the mast has been bound.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Historesai: To view.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histor(?): The peg fixed to the end of the pole.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Histos kai keraia (Mast and yard-arms): The mast is the long piece of wood stretching upwards; the yard-arms are the sideways parts, so that it's like the letter 'tau.' Often the peplos of Athena was suspended on such an arrangement of pieces of wood and led the procession.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischanei: He impedes.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischandros: A tragic actor.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ische: Hold back.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischesthai: To stop.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischion: The hollow part of the buttock, in which the hip-joint turns.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischiazein: To shift oneself (?)from one side to the other(?) a lot when walking.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischnomuthias (Subtle dispute): Quibbling.

Author: Robert Carpenter <robert.carpenter227@gmail.com>
Translation: Isoeures aulos (Equal breadth pipe): One having an equal breadth. Just like 'teichos' (wall) [is to] 'euteicheis' (well-walled) and "sthenos' (strength) is to 'isosthenes' (equal strength), so 'heuros' (breadth) [is to] 'isoeures' (equal breadth).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Belos (Tread): Threshold of a gate. Or heaven.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Berekes: The doughs out of which barley cakes are made.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Beseis (Woman from the deme Bessa): Bessa is a deme of the tribe Antiochis.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bibazetai (Is made to go to): Applying to 'is mounted'. And The ancients used to call 'mounting' 'going to'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bibazei (Makes go to): Breeds, makes mount.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Biola: Shoes, sandals.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bionai (To pass one's life): To live.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bioto (May he/she pass his/her life): May he/she live.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blaisos (Crooked): Paralytic

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blakas: A certain moron ignorant how to decide his business.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blakeia (Stupidity): Disdain, folly.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blakeuei (Is slack): Is soft.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blaste (Growth): Offspring.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blautas (Slippers): Certain sandals.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blennon (Drivelling): Dull. So Sophron. It also denotes 'slothful'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blenna (Snot): Mucous discharge. Sophron says it with pi, 'plenna'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blechemata (Bleatings): Sounds of cattle.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boen (Shout): Battle. Also a loud sound.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bombyx (Deep-toned flute): A herdsman.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bombos (Booming): Some noise.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bombesen (Boomed): Made a noise in some way.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boudoro nomo (In the cow-flaying manner): In the way they skin cattle.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boron (Gluttonous): Voracious.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bosin (Food): Nourishment.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bota (Grazing beasts): Cattle.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boteres (Herdsmen): Shepherds.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Borboryge (Gurgling): Uproar.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boulytos (Ox loosening): The late afternoon, when cows are released from work.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boulimos (Ravenous hunger): Intense famine.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Glossalgia (Endless talk): Empty talk.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Glossargon ethos (Garrulous manner): For 'fast' and 'mouthy'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Glossokomon (Sarcophagus): Wooden box for remains.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Glochinas: Angles.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Glottas (Tongues): The mouthpieces of pipes. Thus Eupolis: "If the tongue will not be fixed, it is unclear if it will be quiet."

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Geomorion: Field.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Geolophon (HIll): Mountainous hill, height of land. They also call the dense and senseless man thus.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Geonomas: Those who distribute the land in colonies. So Kratinos.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Barymenis (Rage-heavy): Vengeful.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Barypemon (Miserable): Wretched, depressed, ill-born.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Besas hestekas (You stand there like Bes): As in gaping. This man stands gaping and chattering and rather stupid.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Biote kai biotos (Life [fem. and masc.]): Life and things related to living. Also substance.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Plynteria: A festival of the Athenians.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pnyx: Assembly at Athens; either from the mob packing itself ('pyknousthai') in there; or from the buildings around it being packed together ('pykna').

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Politeia (Polity): The rhetors are accustomed to apply the word to the democracy in particular. Both Isocrates in the Panegyricus and Demosthenes in the Philippics.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Porthmos: Demosthenes, For Ktesiphon. It is a city of Euboia.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Poros: Demosthenes in the Appeal Against Euboulides; Poros is a deme of the tribe Akamantis. And the demesman is Porian.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Prastillos: a Macedonian city.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Probouleumata (Preliminary Decisions): The decisions of the council concerning decrees, which they would decide before the assembly. For decrees first entered the council; then, if the council accepted [a given decree], it was introduced to the assembly already preliminarily ratified and preliminarily decided. But if the council did not accept, it was not introduced to the assembly, but the one who introduced it was convicted of introducing an illegal decree. After, however, the assembly also ratified, the preliminary decisions were valid, unless someone filed a charge [against it].

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Probouleuma (Preliminary decision): That which was decreed by the council before being introduced to the assembly. Demosthenes in Against Aeschines.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pyr epi pyri (Fire upon fire): An expression which Plato also has mentioned: evil upon evil.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Salabakho: Name of a prostitute.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Sigeion: It is a city in the Troad, not far from Troy.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Skepsis: it is a city in the Troad, which Demosthenes mentions in Against Aristokrates.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Pandosia: A city, one of those in Kasopia.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ophrynion: It is a city in the Troad. Demosthenes in Against Apatourios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Nothing sacred: Heracles said looking at the image of Adonis; as only those who have done mortals some benefaction ought to be honored, or because slaves who fled to it had no amnesty.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ostrakou peristrophe (Spin of a potsherd): An expression said applying to those who do something quickly.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Isopaches: Having an equal thickness ('pachos').

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Isomekes: Similarly: for compounds from 'mekos' (length) are accented on the penult: 'eumekes' (of good length), 'oligomekes' (of little length), 'isomekes' (of equal length).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischnomuthountes: Speaking precisely.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischuriskos(?): For 'ischuros' (strong). Thus Alexis.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Isonia: Having the same price.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itaburion: A mountain so called.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Italiazein:To spend time in Italy.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Italiodes (Italian): A braggart, because of the Pythagoreans; or a lecher, because of Sybaris.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Italiotes (Italian): A Pythagorean, since they spent time there.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itamos (Vehement): Shameless, hard, wild; from 'iesthai,' which is 'to rush,' since shameless people are like that.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itamos (Vehement): Shameless, hard, wild; from 'iesthai,' which is 'to rush,' since shameless people are like that.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Iteon: One must go.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Iteas: Shields.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Iteais(?): A deme of the tribe Akamantis.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Iten (The two went): They went.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Ites: A vehement man. Thus Aristophanes: "Bold, glib, daring, rash."

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itelon: Not faded, but indelible. Thus Aeschylus.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itria (Cakes): Dry, shaped ones.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itux: A bird.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itys: Rim of a shield.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boeikon: The sound of oxen. So Pherekrates.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Kepos: a city on the Bosporos so called.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boetheias kai boethein (Aid and to come to the aid): Not only to be an ally, but also, as soon as one has learned of the attack of the enemy, to rush out against them. It is said so from 'running' ('thein'), that is to say, running ('trechein') with a 'shout' ('boe').

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boides (Like an ox): Mild. It is from Menander.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boios: For 'boeios' (related to oxen).

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Market mind-set: entirely thrifty and vulgar, neither subtle nor reflective, for market people are ignorant and uneducated. Used thus by Euripides (fr. 1114 N.2).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Oietheis (Having thought): Understanding.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Oiesis (Swelling): Swelling, a suspicion.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikositos (One who eats at home): A man who eats the household stores and his own [food], not the [food] of his neighbors.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikouros (Tending the house): Managing the household. Or a house guard. For a guard [is] an 'ouros'.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Hermos: is a deme of Akamantis. Dionysios says Hermos is neuter, like "erkos" (fence)

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Latris: Serving woman, slave woman, beggar.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Laura: Alley, by which the people ('laos') comes and goes.

Author: Chris de Lisle <cmdelisle@gmail.com>
Translation: Hermes: a kind of toast, like "of the good spirit" and "of Zeus the saviour."

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Lithon hepseis (You are boiling a stone): Expression: you are attempting the impossible.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Logographos (Speech-writer): He who writes suits or the speeches for suits.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Lytra (Ransom): Pay. Or what is furnished for liberty with a view to ransoming (someone) from enslavement to barbarians.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Megarians' tears: since lots of garlic grows in the Megarid, it became a proverb applying to those who cry pretend-tears.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Mys leukos (White mouse): Domestic mice are excessively inclined towards breeding, especially the white ones; these are female. The expression is said applying to those who are intemperate concerning sex.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikuria (Toys): The things which mothers leave behind or bring to the houses having departed from the children. Or toys.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oikonomous (The men managing a household): The ones governing in the house.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oimesen (He darted): He started. And dartings. Rushings.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oimoktian (?) (Groaning): For 'oimoxeian' [lamentation].

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Onanthe (Bloom): The germination of the vine. And a sweet smelling mountain plant.

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Oispote (Sheep dung): Sheep's filth, the oil from sheep wool. Aristophanes in Lysistrata: "having washed out the sheep dung from the city, on a couch."

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Metragyrtes (A wandering priest [of Cybele]): Someone going to Attica initiated the women in the mother of the gods, as they say. And the Athenians killed him, having thrown him into a pit upon his head. But when a plague came, they received an oracle to appease the murdered one. And because of this they made a council chamber in the place where they killed the 'metragyrtes'. Enclosing it they consecrated this [place] to the mother of the gods, having also dedicated a statue of the wandering priest. And they began to use the Metroon as an archive and a law depository, having filled in the pit.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Neoria kai noosoikoi (Shipyards and ship-sheds): Perhaps the whole place is called 'neoria' (shipyards), into which the triremes are hauled up and hauled down from again from it, as Lycurgus and Andocides indicate.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Nikanor (Nikanor): There have been three Nikanors. The son of Balakros. Another [the son] of Parmenion. And another, Stagarite by decent, whom Hyperides mentions in Against Demosthenes.
Notes:
See also [Νικάνωρ](suda:nu,376)
Edited by Joshua Sosin

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Νotheia (Βastard's inheritance): That which is given to the bastards from their father's estate is so called. It was up to one thousand drachmas. So Lysias and Isaeus and Aristophanes and Hyperides and Demosthenes in Against Aristocrates.
Notes:
See also [νοθεῖα](suid:nu,448)
Edited by Joshua Sosin

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babalon: Private parts.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babaktes (Reveller): Dancer, hymn-singer, a mad person, a shouter; whence also Bacchus.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babous: A proper name.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Baiton kai Baitas: For 'stupid' (m.) or 'stupid' (f.). So Philemon.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babazein (To exclaim baa): To say something not articulate. Some [say] "to shout."

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babrazon (chattering): having clamored vehemently.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babai: An utterance of surprise.

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation: Babaka (Chatter): The marriage(?).

Author: David Stifler <david.wf.stifler@gmail.com>
Translation:
"Babaktes (Reveller): The mad and uncontrolled, and more specifically Pan.
"

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hina: Where. Antiphon in On Concord: "where one shrinks from no act."
Notes:
[Antiphon Soph. fr. 55](tlg:1147;003;55.1).
This entry is reproduced as part of [Suda ι 360](suda:iota;360).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippodamou nemesis en Peiraiei (Distribution of Hippodamos in Piraeus): There was a Hippodamos the son of Eurykoon(?), a Milesian or Thourian astronomer. He arranged ('dieneimen') the Piraeus for the Athenians.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippodameia: A place in the agora of the Piraeus, called this because of Hippodamos the Milesian architect who established the Piraeus and the roads of the city.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippothoros (Horse-covering): Breeding horses; since 'thoros' is semen. It's also a pipe song.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Hippodameia: An agora in Piraeus so called because of Hippodamos the Milesian architect who built the Piraeus for the Athenians.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
TranslatedBy: Isegorei: He speaks on an equal basis, he speaks as an equal.
Translation: Isegorei: He speaks on an equal basis, he speaks as an equal.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade
This entry is reproduced as part of [Suda ι 626](suda:iota;626).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Isthmia: [Things] around the mouth, around the throat.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry is reproduced as part of [Suda ι 638](suda:iota;638).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Histori: To a witness, or to a judge.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry is identical to [Suda ι 698](suda:iota;698), and probably originated as a gloss on [Iliad 18.501](tlg:0012;001;18.501).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ischyrikoi: Strong ('ischyroi').

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Ionokysos (Ionian-assed man): Effeminate [man]. Thus Cratinus.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Labyrinthos: Spiral-shaped place; and it is said about nonsense.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry is reproduced as part of [Suda λ 11](suda:lambda;11).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bouphonia: A festival at Athens, in which many oxen were sacrificed. And this was celebrated on the fourteenth of the month of Skirophorion.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutypos (Ox-butcher): A certain priest, who used to sacrifice oxen during sacrifices by smiting them.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutypos (Ox-butcher): An ox slayer, one who smites oxen with an axe.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boutypos (Ox-butcher): A certain priest, who used to sacrifice oxen during sacrifices by smiting them.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: He kyon epi tes phatnes (Bitch at the manger): Expression applying to those who neither use [something] nor give a share to others.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kirraion pedion (Kirraian plain): Kirra is a city thirty stades from Delphi. And so Aischines seems to call the area lying next to this city 'Kirraian plain.'

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kyklopes: savage men.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Kyrene: name of a prostitute.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Komai (villages): small cities.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Mia lochme (One thicket): An expression: "One thicket does not produce two robins", applying to those who are eager to profit from something small. A robin is a bird which is solitary and lives alone.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Oisyme: a city in Thrace.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsis (Felloe): So they used to call the wooden rim of the wheel, and the tire upon it. But Homer called the circular wheel a 'kyklos' and the felloe an 'itys.'

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Hapsides (Wheels): Covered carriages.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Apsyxein (To swoon): The opposite of 'to be of good courage'. And it indicates being very fearful.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aoton (The choicest): Flower, decoration, crown.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aotebein(?) [=>ἀωτεύειν]: To weave/construct.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aori, aoria (At an untimely hour, dead of night): Pherecrates in the Krapataloi: "And they were walking away from dinner. But it was just then dusk, and not the dead of night." And they also call the season ('hora'), 'aoria' (unseasonable). Aristophanes in the Acharnai: "Then, when they have arrived late, next they will jostle--don't you know."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aori, aoria (At an untimely hour, the wrong time): That which is contrary to the appropriate time or hour. But they say 'at an untimely hour of the night' and 'at an untimely hour by night.' But Aristophanes said also "the man died an untimely death," that is, before the appropriate time.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aoroi podes (Ugly feet): Fore-feet. "She had twelve feet, all of them ugly." And Philemon, "Did I not tell you, you rogue, to buy the fore-feet? But you bring the hind feet."

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aoroi (Untimely ones): Those who die before their time. The word is customary for many and especially for Alexandrians. But it is Attic. Aristophanes: "For others, too, children died untimely."

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aiei georgos eis neota plousios (The farmer is always rich next year): It is said also without the iota: 'aei georgos'. Also Theopompos the comic poet has mentioned the expression in Peace as being inscribed also at Delphi: "Then also at Delphi let it be inscribed and erected: 'it was always the good farmer first fleeing great hunger'." Mention [of this] is in others too, as Eirenaios says.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aoron (Untimely): Unbecoming, unpleasant.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Apage xenon en cheimoni (Arrest a stranger in a storm): An expression applying to troublesome people.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Aoroleios (Unnaturally smooth): The man who is smooth contrary to age and to youth.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Es ton limena (To the harbor!): For whenever they are seen from the city, they row more vigorously, whence the elliptical expression, "Attic [man] to the harbor", for "strong" is missing.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Theos he Anaideia (The god Shamelessness): Said applying to those who profit on account of shamelessness. Shamelessness was even honored in Athens, and there was a temple of hers, as Istros [said] in book 14.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Thessalon sophisma (Thessalian trick): Applied to those that do not fight fairly in the lines, but do bad deeds.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zetetai (Inquirers): A certain office set up in Athens at appropriate times, before which those who owed money to the state and had not paid it were exposed.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zetein (To seek): Attic authors use it applying to wanting: “Nor seek you to learn something.”

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hyper ta Kallikratous (Beyond the things of Kallikrates): Klearchos says that a certain Kallikrates became very wealthy in Karystos. If ever, then, the Karystans were marvelling at someone for [his] wealth hyperbolically, they used to say "beyond the things of Kallikrates". But Aristotle says in the Athenaion Politeia that a certain Kallikrates first increased the jurors' pay [=> μισθοὺς] to excess; whence also the expression is said.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hygiesteros omphakos (Healthier than an unripe grape): Expression, so also 'healthier than a tick/Kroton', for many people from Kroton [were] athletes. Also 'healthier than a round gourd'.

Author: Mackenzie Zalin <mackzalin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hygra keleutha (Watery paths): The way through [the] sea.

Author: Zach H <zach.heater.2001@gmail.com>
Translation: Zetesetai: For ‘zetethesetai’ (He will be sought after).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bebrithyia (Having been weighed down): Heavy, strong.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blakeuetai (Is slack): Is soft.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blechron: Weak in Homer and Alkaios [=>Ἀλκαίῳ]. But Pindar says the same [word] for 'strong'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bliton (Stupid): For 'mad'. Or dumb.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blittein: To extract honey from the honeycombs.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blitadas: The ancients [called] cheap women [so], as Krates says.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Blimazon (Squeezing): Distilling from the honey.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bolborychein (To dig bulbs): For 'to dig through walls'.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bombylion: Creature. Or the cup called [so].

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Honeybees buzz ('bombousin') whenever someone approaches smelling of myrrh.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganon: Sophokles in At Tainaron said that 'aganon' wood, with barytone accent, is that which has been chopped or that which is unhewn.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aganon: Fine, pleasant. Aristophanes in Lysistrata: "She seems to me even to be much younger and to look finer".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agei (One fetches): For 'one carries off' and 'one leads.' Also 'agei', i.e. 'one honors' and 'one reveres'. Demosthenes in Against Timokrates says that 'agei' is a thing's value or the amount of its weight, saying, "and the short sword of Mardonios, which weighed ('ege') three hundred drachmas". Also Against Demades: "It weighed ('ege') five minas".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagiasai (To make sacred): To offer, to burn in holy fashion.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ankylia (Loops): Chains' links.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Akylometai (Of crooked counsel): Of bent counsel.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ankylon (Crooked): Curved, curving.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ankylocheilos (Crooked-beaked): Bent-beaked.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Ankyrai (Anchors): By way of metaphor, 'safeties'. Sophokles: "But children are a mother's anchor in life".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglai(?): Eye. Euripides.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglaia (Splendor): Brilliance.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglaiais (With splendors): With brilliances.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aglaokoitos (Splendid-bedded): Very honored.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnisai (To cleanse): To destroy, by antiphrasis. Also to offer as sacrifice. So Sophokles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Hagnites (Purifier / One requiring purification): Suppliant and cleansing. For the one who is purified of defilement and the one who has cleansed are so called.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agomenon ton hemeteron (Our own things being led off): For 'being plundered and pillaged'.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Agoraian (Forensic): Forensic speech.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aieton kantharos maieusomai (I, as dung beetle, will hatch an eagle): An expression: For dung beetles remove the eagle's eggs, by rolling them, since eagles gather up the dung beetles.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Aietoi (Eagles): The front-faces [=> προνώπια] of the temples and the coffers of the roofs, owing to the fact that they look like an eagle's wings.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Amphexomai (I shall put around myself): That is, 'I shall put on'. Pherekrates, in Ant-Men: "But I surely do have clothes, which I shall put on".

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Engye (Pledge): The marriage agreement.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Heilotes (Helots): Among Lacedaimonians, bastards and those born slaves from war captives. After ‘Helos’. Helos was a city in the Peloponnese. And slavery is ’heiloteia’ (helotage).

Author: Jacob Brakebill <phoenixetdraco@gmail.com>
Translation: Itea: From whom the deme [is named] Iteaios.

Author: Joshua D. Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com>
Translation: Itea: The demesman from which is an Iteaios.

Author: Aidan Alemifar <alemifaraidan@gmail.com>
Translation: Xenapatas (A treacherous breeze): In a special sense, applying to whenever the winds do not blow on the seas as they do in the harbors. Euripides says in Sthenoboea, "someone honors the treacherous breeze of man."
Notes: Edited by Joshua Sosin <joshuad.sosin@gmail.com> and Robert Carpenter <Robert.Carpenter227@gmail.com>

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagorizomenoi (Nudging): Jabbing, hitting the flanks.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lagoos peri ton kreon (A rabbit for its meat): An expression. For the rabbit (‘lagos’) is a cowardly creature; whence a person from Rhegium was called a rabbit, since they used also to mock the people of Rhegium for cowardice. But there is a certain expression “a rabbit runs the [race] for its meat” applied to those who are risking their lives and therefore competing mightily.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry is reproduced as part of [Suda λ 30](suda:lambda;30).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakataratoi: Those greatly accursed; Also, 'lakatapygon,' great bugger.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
See also [Photios λ 51](photios:lambda;51).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakkoi: Pits, anointing buildings, receptacles for oil and wine.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade
See also Photios [lambda 45](photios:lambda;45) and [46](photios:lambda;46)

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lakratidas: Chilled things, since in the archonship of Lakratidas there was a lot of snow.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
See also [Suda λ 70](suda:lambda;70).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamia: Douris in Libyca Book 2 records that she was a beautiful woman; after Zeus had sex with her, she was struck by the jealousy of Hera, and the children she bore were destroyed. Therefore she became ugly because of her grief and snatching up the children of other people she killed them. There is also a city in Thessaly, from which the Greeks set out after the death of Alexander, with Athenians in command, and laying claim to their freedom they defeated Antipater. Menander in Andrygynos: “Having filled, he somehow carried off from the battle line all the women in Lamia.”
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
This entry = [Suda λ 84](suda:lambda;84), and see also [Photios λ 62](photios:lambda;62).
The passages referred to are Douris FGrH 76 F 17 and Menander fr. 51 K-A.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lamia: A women in Athens spending her time in the Agora, holding a club and breaking wind. It's also an animal.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
See also [Photios λ 61](photios:lambda;61).

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampados (Of the torch): The Athenians hold three festivals of the torch: Panathenaea, Hephaestia, and Promethea. Istros says that it used to be the custom for the Athenians to make a torch when sacrificing to Hephaestus as a memorial of him inventing(?) the use of fire and teaching it to others.
Notes: Reproduced as part of [Suda λ 88](suda:lambda;88). The reference to Istros is to FGrH 334 F 2.

Author: Matt Farmer <ierthling@gmail.com>
Translation: Lampadion (Little torch): Aristophanes in Acharnians: “greasy wool.” Some [say it means] thin tuft of wool, to which the flocks of wool are attached; others a type of binding; others a frame into which those missing a foot fit their leg; others stock and reeds with which they bind people who've broken their leg.
Notes:
Edited by Clinton Kinkade .
See also [Suda λ 87](suda:lambda,87).
The quotation from Aristophanes is [Acharnians 1177](tlg:0019;019;1177).

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Baon(?): Simmonides [says] for an ox. And Homer ([Iliad, 7,238](0012:001:236378)) [says]: to direct an ox <baon>(?)’.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bremei (Rings): Stirs up, produces a sound.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bretas (Image): Likeness, statue.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Briaroi (Strong): Severe, wild, stubborn, fearsome.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Brabeutes (Judge): Administrator, interpreter, boundary-marker

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Boupais (Cowboy): A youth, adolescent, cowherd.

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>

Author: Abbot Henderson <abbothenderson@gmail.com>
Translation: Bouplex (Ox-goad): Axe, whip, ox-goad.
